PORTLAND, 5933 NE WIN SIVERS DRIVE, #205, OR 97220U, UNITED STATE, December 8, 2023 /EINPresswire 
/ -- The low cost airlines market was valued at $155.02 billion in 2016, and is estimated to reach $440.46 billion by 
2030, growing at a CAGR of 10.4% from 2022 to 2030.
Request The Sample PDF of This Report: @
The domestic segment was the highest revenue contributor to the market, with $88,286.0 million in 2021, and is 
estimated to reach $310,556.3 million by 2030, with a CAGR of 10.2%. low-cost airlines airline is a passenger 
airline, which offers travelling service at relatively cheaper rate compared to other airlines (full service or traditional 
airline). Rise in economic activities, ease of travel, expansion of the travel & tourism industry, rapid urbanization, 
changes in lifestyle, consumers' preference for low-cost service along with non-stops, and frequent service act as 
the key driving forces of the global low-cost airlines market. In addition, increase in purchasing power of middle-
class households, especially in developing regions, and high internet penetration coupled with e-literacy foster the 
Low Cost Airlines Market growth.
However, factors such as volatile crude oil price and increase in terrorism & crime rate, political uncertainty, & 
natural calamities hinder the market growth. Furthermore, increase in cases of COVID-19 and high investment & 
operational cost but low profitability act as the key deterrent factors of the low-cost airlines industry. On the 
Low-Cost Airlines Market Incredible Possibilities, Growth With Industry Study, Detailed Analysis And Forecast 
To 2030
contrary, sustainable airport governance and operational & financial improvements are anticipated to open new 
avenues for the growth of the global low-cost airlines market during the forecast period. The global low-cost airlines 
market is segmented into purpose, destination, distribution channel, and region. By purpose, the Low Cost Airlines 
Industry is fragmented into leisure travel, visiting friends & relatives (VFR), and business travel. On the basis of 
destination, it is bifurcated into domestic and international. Depending on distribution channel, it is divided into 
online and travel agency. The Low Cost Airlines Market has been further analyzed across North America (U.S., 
Canada, and Mexico), Europe (UK, Italy, Spain, Germany, France, Latvia, and rest of Europe), Asia-Pacific 
(Philippines, Indonesia, Thailand, Singapore, Malaysia, Vietnam, China, India, Australia, and rest of Asia-Pacific), 
and LAMEA (Latin America, Africa, and Middle East).

Ryanair to fly from Kaunas to Berlin, Zadar, Pisa
Ryanair to fly from Kaunas to Berlin, Zadar, Pisa
Intellinews - Baltic States Today
December 8, 2023 Friday
Copyright 2023 Emerging Markets Direct Media Holdings LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 142 words
Body
The Irish cheap flight airline Ryanair has announced it is planning to launch regular flights from Lithuania's second-
biggest city Kaunas to Berlin in Germany, Zadar in Croatia, and Pisa in Italy during the 2024 summer season, BNS, 
a Lithuanian newswire, reported on December 7.  
Lietuvos Oro Uostai (Lithuanian Airports, LTOU) said on December 6 that, based on information from Ryanair's 
ticketing systems, the airline will operate three weekly flights between Kaunas and Berlin from late March, and two 
weekly flights to Zadar from early June.  
The exact date and frequency of the flights to Pisa are expected to be specified in the near future.  
Ryanair last week announced plans to reintroduce 15 regular flight routes to Lithuania for the spring and summer of 
2024.  
The airline offers flights to a total of 52 destinations from Lithuanian airports. 
Load-Date: December 8, 2023

'Disruptive' passenger diverts flight
'Disruptive' passenger diverts flight
Daily Mirror
December 8, 2023 Friday
Edition 1, Ireland
Copyright 2023 Reach PLC All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 6
Length: 87 words
Body
A RYANAIR flight had to be diverted after one of the passengers became "disruptive" on board.
The incident, which happened on a flight from Dublin to Lanzarote on Wednesday morning.
The plane re-routed to one of Morocco's major cities, Agadir.
Once it landed in the local airport, the plane was met by Moroccan police on the runway.
Policemen removed the disruptive passenger and took them into custody.
In a statement Ryanair said: "Following the disturbance, the flight continued to Lanzarote and arrived with a short 
delay."

IAG slides 3%
IAG slides 3%
Spanish News (English Language)
December 8, 2023 Friday 12:10 PM EST
Copyright 2023 A Data Pro Ltd All Rights Reserved
Length: 140 words
Byline: SeeNews
Body
Spanish airline company IAG slides 3% as JP Morgan's report influences the airline's performance, retracting gains 
made post-Gaza conflict.
Following the US entity's sector update, advising underweight for the IAG, analysts foresee challenges for 
traditional airlines amid potential capacity increases and economic slowdown.
They favor low-cost carriers like Ryanair for better margins and growth.
In a day where the European travel sector falls 0.75%, IAG leads declines, despite earlier recovery.
While JP Morgan's assessment differs, with 71.9% advising buying, an 18.8% hold, and 9.4% sell, overall optimism 
is reflected in a Bloomberg consensus target of EUR 2.38, indicating a 30% potential increase.

Morgan) by Gema Escribano.

RYANAIR WELCOMES HIGH COURT RULING CONFIRMING SCREENSCRAPING IS UNLAWFUL
RYANAIR WELCOMES HIGH COURT RULING CONFIRMING 
SCREENSCRAPING IS UNLAWFUL
Contify Aviation News
December 7, 2023 Thursday 6:30 AM EST
Copyright 2023 Contify.com All Rights Reserved
Length: 628 words
Body
Ryanair welcomes the High Court ruling that prohibits screenscraper Flightbox from unlawfully scraping Ryanair's 
website. The ruling aims to protect customers from price gouging by OTAs who overcharge for air fares and 
ancillary services. Customers face difficulties accessing their bookings and receiving important flight updates. The 
ruling reinforces Ryanair's determination to ensure customers have access to the lowest fares and can manage 
their bookings directly through Ryanair's website or mobile app.
Key Highlights:
* OTAs not only overcharge for fares, bags, and seats but also block customers from managing their bookings or 
receiving flight updates from Ryanair
* Ryanair does not have a commercial relationship with any OTA or screenscraper
* Ryanair encourages customers to book directly through their website or mobile app
Original Press Release:
Dec. 7 -- Ryanair Group issued the following news release:
Ryanair, Europe's No.1 airline, today (7 Dec) welcomes the judgement of the Irish High Court granting a permanent 
injunction prohibiting screenscraper Flightbox from breaching the binding Terms of Use of the Ryanair website by 
using bot technology to unlawfully scrape Ryanair's website for OTAs.
Ryanair has long campaigned to protect customers from price gouging by OTAs who continue to dupe 
unsuspecting consumers by unlawfully scraping Ryanair's website, including by overcharging for air fares and 
ancillary services, using fake customer accounts, fake customer payment cards and fake customer emails. This can 
be hugely detrimental to customers who, apart from being overcharged, cannot access their Ryanair bookings, 
make the necessary security declarations, access refunds, or receive direct email communications (such as online 
check-in reminders) from Ryanair. This historical and precedent-setting Court ruling is a major step forward in 
RYANAIR WELCOMES HIGH COURT RULING CONFIRMING SCREENSCRAPING IS UNLAWFUL
protecting unsuspecting consumers from being overcharged by OTAs (see table below), and will help to ensure that 
Ryanair customers always get the lowest fares, the best customer service, and real time email communications.
Ryanair's Dara Brady said:
"We welcome this High Court ruling which established that this screenscraper is bound by the Terms of Use of the 
Ryanair website, which prohibits screenscraping. Ryanair has been granted a permanent injunction to stop this 
unlawful screencraping of Ryanair's data in breach of Ryanair's Terms of Use. The Ryanair website is the only 
website authorised to sell Ryanair flights.
OTAs have for years relied upon screenscrapers (such as Flightbox), fake customer accounts, single-use payment 
cards and fake customer email addresses to make bookings on Ryanair's website in breach of the Terms of Use. 
This can cause huge inconvenience and expense to customers as often OTAs not only overcharge for fares, bags 
and seats, but they also block customers from managing their bookings or receiving important flight updates from 
Ryanair (such as online check-in reminders).
This historic High Court ruling has reinforced Ryanair's determination to pursue justice for our customers to ensure 
they get access to the lowest fares, cannot be overcharged by OTAs, and that they have direct access to manage 
their bookings and to receive up to date flight information.
Ryanair does not have a commercial relationship with any OTA or screenscraper and we strongly object to OTAs 
mis-selling our flights and overcharging consumers. We encourage our customers to book directly with us through 
ryanair.com or our mobile app."
Disclaimer: Table can be viewed at: https://corporate.ryanair.com/news/ryanair-welcomes-high-court-ruling-
confirming-screenscraping-is-unlawful/
Source: Ryanair Group
[Category: Transportation Infrastructure, Transportation/ Logistics, Regulatory and Legal]

RYANAIR CONCLUDES THE CELEBRATION OF ITS 25 YEARS IN ITALY WITH A SPECIAL CHARITY 
FLIGHT
RYANAIR CONCLUDES THE CELEBRATION OF ITS 25 YEARS IN ITALY 
WITH A SPECIAL CHARITY FLIGHT
Contify Aviation News
December 7, 2023 Thursday 6:30 AM EST
Copyright 2023 Contify.com All Rights Reserved
Length: 855 words
Body
Ryanair concluded its 25th anniversary celebration in Italy with a special charity flight for Make-A-Wish Italia. Over 
the past 25 years, Ryanair has been proud to serve the Italian market, offering increased connectivity and travel 
opportunities for both domestic and international flights. The airline has transported over 500 million passengers 
since its first flight in Italy in 1998. As part of its anniversary celebrations, Ryanair gifted a trip to 20 children and 
their families to Reus in Spain, including visits to Port Aventura and Ferrari Land.
Key Highlights:
* Ryanair has raised over (EURO)270,000 in charity through its collaboration with Make-A-Wish Italia
* Ryanair gifted a trip to 20 children and their families to Reus in Spain, including visits to Port Aventura and Ferrari 
Land
* Ryanair aims to transport 300 million passengers per year by 2034
Original Press Release:
Dec. 7 -- Ryanair Group issued the following news release:
LET YOUR DESIRES FLY
Ryanair, the number 1 airline in Italy, today (6 December) concluded the celebration of the twenty-fifth anniversary 
of activity in the Bel Paese with a special charity flight for Make-A-Wish Italia (4-6 December). Ryanair is delighted 
to operate in Italy and for the last 25 years we have been proud to serve the Italian market, offering greater 
connectivity and broader travel opportunities for all Italians, both domestic and international, with over 500 million 
passengers carried by its first ever flight into the country, from Treviso to London in May 1998. Ryanair also 
continues to help fuel inbound tourism to all Italian regions and supports local economies, making the best of Italy 
accessible to the rest of the world .
RYANAIR CONCLUDES THE CELEBRATION OF ITS 25 YEARS IN ITALY WITH A SPECIAL CHARITY 
FLIGHT
For its Silver Wedding Anniversary, Ryanair continues to operate in Italy with:
Disclaimer: Table can be viewed at: https://corporate.ryanair.com/novita/ryanair-conclude-la-celebrazione-dei-suoi-
25-anni-in-italia-con-uno-speciale-volo-di-beneficienza/
To conclude the celebrations and remember these great goals, Ryanair has decided to give a trip to 20 children 
from Make-A-Wish Italia and their families, offering an unforgettable holiday in Reus in Spain, within the Port theme 
parks Aventura and Ferrari Land. Ryanair has worked closely with Make-A-Wish Italia since 2019 and has raised 
over (EURO)270,000 for charity through this incredible collaboration. Ryanair has a strong link with this 
organization and the airline's crews are extremely passionate about supporting the incredible work they do in Italy, 
for example by promoting the sale of scratchcards on board to raise funds.
Mauro Bolla, Head of Communication of Ryanair Italy, Albania, Cyprus, Greece and Romania declared:
"Ryanair is delighted to partner with Make-A-Wish Italia and operate a special flight to offer children and their 
families a flight for an unforgettable holiday. This trip was the perfect way to end the celebrations for our 25 years in 
Italy and to express our passion for Italy and the people who live here, in a special and unforgettable way. Over the 
last 25 years Ryanair has transported over 500 million passengers to/from Italy, bringing families and friends 
together and offering unforgettable experiences. We look forward to continuing our wonderful collaboration with 
Italy, and expect to carry 300 million passengers per year by 2034."
Sune Frontani, President and co-founder of Make-A-Wish Italia declared:
"I would like to express my sincere thanks to Ryanair: choosing to celebrate its twenty-fifth anniversary by offering 
sixty of our children and their families a holiday is a gesture of great generosity and altruism, which fills me with 
positivity and optimism for the future ", declared Sune Frontani, President and co-founder of Make a A Wish Italia, 
at the departure of the flight. "These families who daily face the challenges that a serious illness brings, deserve to 
spend moments of joy and serenity and to benefit from everything that this journey will mean: growth, inspiration, 
trust, fun but above all strength and determination. The collaboration between Ryanair and Make A Wish Italia, 
which has been active for five years, is a concrete example of how companies can contribute to making the world a 
better place."
Giacomo Cattaneo, aviation commercial director of SACBO, declared:
"We are happy and honored to greet Ryanair's 25 years of activity in Italy with a special event, knowing that we 
have contributed to providing a travel experience that starts from our airport, where hospitality is the calling card of 
our level of assistance. Meeting so many young people with smiles and serene faces of the family members who 
accompany them adds great honor and satisfaction to the work of those who work at the service of passengers. We 
hope that the participants in the special charity flight will keep a nice memory of their transit through the airport, 
keeping the free gadgets they received from us, knowing that they will always find us ready to host them when they 
want to fly again."

Ryanair is accused of 'stealing customers' by www.Booking.com CEO Michael O'Leary had labelled travel firm 
'internet pirates'
Ryanair is accused of 'stealing customers' by www.Booking.com; CEO 
Michael O'Leary had labelled travel firm 'internet pirates'
Irish Independent
December 7, 2023 Thursday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2023 Independent Newspapers Ireland Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: BUSINESS WEEK;NEWS; Pg. 2
Length: 607 words
Byline: JOHN MULLIGAN
Body
Internet travel giant www.Booking.com has accused Ryanair of "stealing customers away" from the company in the 
latest salvo fired in a major legal battle between the pair in the United States.
Ryanair has sued www.Booking.com and its subsidiaries for alleged screen-scraping of its fares. Now 
www.Booking.com wants the court's permission to amend its counterclaims against the carrier, partly on foot of 
comments Ryanair CEO Michael O'Leary made to the Irish Independent following the airline's annual general 
meeting in September.
www.Booking.com claims it has seen a "dramatic escalation" of customer complaints after the airline allegedly told 
customers who paid for seats through www.Booking.com that their reservations were "blocked", or that they would 
have to pay a (EURO)55 verification fee at the airport.
That has prompted www.Booking.com to add a potential claim of "unjust enrichment" against Ryanair, if the 
Delaware court dealing with the case approves its amended counterclaims. Ryanair has opposed the effort to file 
the amended counterclaims.
Ryanair has sued www.Booking.com and its subsidiaries including Kayak, Agoda and Priceline for alleged screen-
scraping of its fares.
Screen-scraping involves a third party accessing an airline's website and often offering that airline's fares to its own 
customers via its own website.
Ryanair is accused of 'stealing customers' by www.Booking.com CEO Michael O'Leary had labelled travel firm 
'internet pirates'
The pair have been locked in the legal fight in the US since 2020, with a suite of executives from both sides, 
including Mr O'Leary, having been deposed in recent months.
Ryanair has claimed that www.Booking.com and its subsidiaries are depriving the airline of the "opportunity to 
maximise its revenues" from its own website, and of bypassing the carrier's website security.
Ryanair failed earlier this year to have all of Booking's counterclaims thrown out. Instead, the court dismissed just 
one of the counterclaims - for defamation linked to Ryanair's public statements.
But now Booking Holdings has sought leave to amend its counterclaims against Ryanair, including making a fresh 
defamation claim on foot of Mr O'Leary's comments in September and emails allegedly sent by the airline to 
www.Booking.com customers.
It has told the court that the specific defamation counterclaim against Ryanair was previously dismissed because 
the court deemed that there was "no suggestion" that the online travel agents being referred to [in Ryanair's public 
statements] is www.Booking.com."
"That is no longer the case," lawyers for Booking Holdings and its subsidiaries have insisted.
They have pointed to comments made by Mr O'Leary to the Irish Independent immediately following the airline's 
annual general meeting on September 14.
"We have a great case," Mr O'Leary told the Irish Independent. "What www.Booking.com and the other OTAs 
(online travel agents) does is unconscionable. They mislead customers. They're internet pirates for a start."
During his deposition on September 26, Mr O'Leary was quizzed about the comments by Booking's lawyers.
"Ryanair's false and misleading statements disparage and delegitimise Booking.com's valid commercial activity, 
unnecessarily confuse and burden customers, degrade the customer experience, and as such, undermine trust and 
confidence in www.Booking.com and deter customers from using www.Booking.com in the future," the OTA's 
lawyers have claimed.
Booking Holdings and its subsidiaries want significant damages awarded against Ryanair and the airline prevented 
from contacting www.Booking.com customers or making "false" statements about the travel agent.
Yesterday, Ryanair released a survey which it claims is "exposing the scams and overcharging of these OTA 
pirates".
Load-Date: December 7, 2023
End of Document
Ryanair's denial of e-boarding pass fee is absurd: NI passenger
Ryanair's denial of e-boarding pass fee is absurd: NI passenger
Belfast Telegraph
December 7, 2023 Thursday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2023 Belfast Telegraph Newspapers Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 19
Length: 476 words
Byline: Eimear McGovern
Body
A NORTHERN IRELAND man has said claims by Ryanair that customers haven't been required to pay for seating 
in order to download a digital boarding pass on their phone are "absurd".
There has been confusion after some customers hit out at the budget airline for an apparent change in policy - a 
change the airline denied was in force.
Passengers happy to accept a random seat allocation say they were offered the option of queueing at a Ryanair 
check-in desk to print a paper boarding pass at the airport, or to pay to reserve a specific seat in order to display an 
e-boarding pass on their smartphone. Previously, those accepting a random seat would have received a free online 
boarding pass on their phone as well.
However, a spokesperson for Europe's biggest budget airline, when contacted by the Belfast Telegraph, said: 
"There is no charge for a Ryanair digital boarding pass - ever."
Both e-boarding passes and printed passes are typically offered without a requirement to pay for seat selection by 
most airlines.
One local man, who recently travelled from Dublin to Faro, said he checked in for a flight on Saturday.
"I was surprised to see that I was checked in but a [smartphone] boarding pass was unavailable unless I chose to 
select and pay for a seat," he said.
He was further advised to "proceed to the Ryanair desk to collect my boarding pass for free, or I could choose a 
seat [and pay] and get an instant boarding pass".
Ryanair's denial of e-boarding pass fee is absurd: NI passenger
He added: "The fact Ryanair are saying in your article they do not charge is absurd - if I wanted it [his boarding 
pass] instantly I had to pay for it."
The man said he enquired at the desk whether he would be required to go through the same process on the return 
trip and was told by the attendant she wasn't sure.
"She told me that they are trialling this in some airports but she wasn't sure which ones," he explained.
"Clearly they didn't put a lot of thought into it."
The issue is still far from clear at present.
A spokesperson for Ryanair said in response: "As per our statement, which this passenger correctly points out, 
there is no charge for a Ryanair digital boarding pass - ever."
The airline also told media: "All Ryanair passengers can pay for a reserved seat if they so wish, or if passengers 
wish to avoid this seat fee, they can select a randomly allocated seat entirely free of charge."
Queries to the 'Ask Ryanair' account on X (formerly Twitter), stated that "due to popularity of reserved seats, 
Ryanair is keeping seats available until the end for those customers wishing to purchase.
"Some passengers will be assigned the last remaining seats at the airport for free."
The Belfast Telegraph asked Ryanair specifically: can passengers who don't choose a seat - and who therefore 
avoid the seat fee - also get their digital boarding pass for free on their mobile phone?
So far there has been no response to this question.
Load-Date: December 7, 2023
End of Document

IRISH END-OF-DAY STOCK REPORT
www.buysellsignals.com
Ryanair Holdings PLC's (I: RY4B EUR18.54) stock price hit a 52-week high of EUR18.65 during the day. In the past 
month the stock has hit a new 52-week high nine times, pointing to a significant uptrend. 
Ryanair Holdings' stock price increased 11.0c (0.6%) from its previous trading session to close at EUR18.54. 
Compared with the ISEQ Overall Index which fell 72.1 points (0.8%) in the day, the relative price increase was 
1.4%. 
Ryanair Holdings PLC is Ireland's largest Airline company by market cap. 
There were 1,220,000 shares worth EUR22.6 million ($24.4 million) traded today. The volume was 0.7 times the 
average daily trading volume of 1.8 million shares.

Travel firm fury at cheap airlines ceo says reform is needed over 'unfair' practices
Travel firm fury at cheap airlines; ceo says reform is needed over 'unfair' 
practices
Manchester Evening News
December 7, 2023 Thursday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2023 Reach PLC All Rights Reserved
Section: BUSINESS; Pg. 14
Length: 351 words
Byline: Alistair Houghton
Body
TRAVEL giant On The Beach has slammed low cost airlines for their 'anti competitive behaviours' - and has vowed 
to keep pursuing Ryanair after a £2m court victory.
The Manchester group has announced record revenues for 2023 - and also said it had won a legal claim against 
Ryanair over outstanding refunds on cancelled or changed flights. It said it had been awarded £2m plus interest and 
costs.
OTB said it intended to pursue Ryanair 'for further sums due in similar circumstances.' .' And it also called for action 
from the Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) over the actions of low-cost airlines.
In his statement to the Stock Market this week, CEO Shaun Morton said the travel industry urgently needed 'holistic 
and comprehensive regulatory reform' to create a level playing field for businesses and consumers.
He said: "The market power of the few airlines operating popular leisure routes from the UK, and how that power 
manifests itself to the detriment of consumers, poses a serious threat to fair competition and choice for consumers. 
Low cost airlines ('LCA') are using anticompetitive behaviours to stop consumers booking through online travel 
agents, harming consumers in the process. These increasingly sophisticated anti-competitive behaviours include 
blocking OTA (online
We continue challenge anti-behaviour CEO Shaun travel agency) bookings, reducing or removing seats to certain 
destinations, making them completely unbookable by OTAs or consumers unless booked directly with the airline; 
and false and misleading smear campaigns that cast doubt in the minds of consumers about the validity and 
benefits of booking package holidays with OTAs."
Travel firm fury at cheap airlines ceo says reform is needed over 'unfair' practices
to Ryanair on its competitive
He added: "We continue to challenge Ryanair on its anti-competitive behaviour and withholding of refunds through 
ongoing litigation. We recently successfully sued Ryanair for £2m of outstanding flight refunds."
Morton
Ryanair was approached for comment but had not responded.

Ryanair UK : Flight from Dublin Airport to Lanzarote forced to divert to Morocco due to 'disruptive' passenger
Ryanair UK: Flight from Dublin Airport to Lanzarote forced to divert to 
Morocco due to 'disruptive' passenger
National World
December 7, 2023 Thursday
Copyright 2023 JPIMedia Publishing Ltd All Rights Reserved
Section: TRAVEL
Length: 282 words
Highlight: A Ryanair flight from Dublin Airport to Lanzarote was forced to land in Morocco after a passenger 
became "disruptive" on board
Body
A Ryanair flight from Dublin Airport to Lanzarote had to be diverted to Morocco after one of the passengers became 
"disruptive" on board yesterday morning (Wednesday 6 December). The incident caused the flight to divert to one 
of Morocco's major cities, Agadir.
Once it landed in the local airport the plane was met by Moroccan police on the runway and policemen removed the 
disruptive passenger and took them into custody. The disruption caused by the passenger "is now a matter for 
[Moroccan] police". The flight continued to Lanzarote and arrived "with a short delay". 
A spokeswoman for Ryanair told Dublin Live: "This flight from Dublin to Lanzarote (December 6) diverted to Agadir 
when a passenger became disruptive onboard. Crew called ahead for police assistance and the aircraft was met by 
local police upon arrival who removed the disruptive passenger. The flight continued to Lanzarote following a short 
delay."
It comes after a Ryanair flight heading from London Gatwick to Morocco was forced to divert and make an 
emergency landing at Faro in Portugal on Tuesday morning (5 December) after the pilot fell ill. 
Portuguese paper Correio da Manha said the pilot had told passengers before landing that he wasn’t feeling well 
and the diversion triggered a ‘red alert’ at the airport. The 18 passengers on board were forced to wait at the 
Algarve airport to take off again. A spokesperson from Ryanair told The Daily Mail: “There was no ‘emergency 
landing’. This flight from Stansted to Morocco diverted to Faro when one of the pilots became ill. The aircraft landed 
normally, and passengers were transferred to an alternative aircraft operated by another crew before continuing to 
Morocco.”
Ryanair UK : Flight from Dublin Airport to Lanzarote forced to divert to Morocco due to 'disruptive' passenger

A Ryanair flight from Dublin Airport to Lanzarote was forced to land in Morocco after a passenger became 
"disruptive" on board. (Photo: AFP via Getty Images)

New Ryanair flights from Exeter Airport to Palma
New Ryanair flights from Exeter Airport to Palma
Contify Aviation News
December 7, 2023 Thursday 6:30 AM EST
Copyright 2023 Contify.com All Rights Reserved
Length: 378 words
Body
Ryanair is launching new flights from Exeter Airport to Palma, Majorca. The twice-weekly service will start in May 
next year and operate through to October. Ryanair also operates year-round flights to Alicante and Malaga in 
Spain. Exeter Airport offers 24 destinations across eight countries, including flights to the USA and Canada via 
Dublin. The full list of destinations available from Exeter Airport in 2023/24 includes Cyprus, France, Greece, 
Lapland, Spain, Portugal, Turkey, and various UK and Ireland destinations.
Original Press Release:
Dec. 7 -- Exeter Airportissued the following news release:
- Ryanair is launching new flights from Exeter Airport to Palma, the Mediterranean capital of Majorca in the Spanish 
Balearic Islands.
The twice-weekly service will start in May next year and operate through to October. Tickets are on sale now at 
ryanair.com
The new route complements Ryanair's other Spanish services to Alicante and Malaga, which both operate year-
round, and follows the launch of a summer route to Faro in Portugal in June this year.
Stephen Wiltshire, managing director of Exeter Airport, said: "Majorca has always been a popular route from Exeter 
and we're delighted that Ryanair will be offering passengers more choice and great value.
"We're committed to providing a wide range of travel options from Exeter Airport and this latest announcement 
provides even more convenience for travellers."
Exeter Airport offers 24 destinations across eight countries including Spain, Cyprus, Greece and Turkey, and flights 
to the USA and Canada via Dublin. There is also a range of UK destinations available year-round.
Here is the full list of destinations available from Exeter Airport in 2023/24:
* Cyprus: Paphos
New Ryanair flights from Exeter Airport to Palma
* France: Chambry
* Greece: Corfu, Crete, Rhodes, Zante
* Lapland: Enonteki
* Spain: Alicante, Gran Canaria, Lanzarote, Majorca, Malaga, Menorca, Tenerife
* Portugal: Faro
* Turkey: Antalya, Dalaman
* UK & Ireland: Belfast, Dublin (with seamless connections to the USA and Canada), Edinburgh, Glasgow, 
Guernsey, Isles of Scilly, Jersey, Newcastle
For more information, visit Exeter Airport's website at www.exeter-airport.co.uk
Source: Exeter Airport
[Category: Transportation Infrastructure, Transportation/ Logistics, New Offerings, Business Expansion]

Ryanair passengers queue for boarding passes after changes to procedure
Ryanair passengers queue for boarding passes after changes to procedure
The Irish Times
December 7, 2023 Thursday
Copyright 2023 The Irish Times All Rights Reserved
Section: FINANCE; Pg. 16
Length: 349 words
Byline: BARRY O'HALLORAN
Body
BARRY O HALLORAN  A Ryanair passenger who paid more than EUR 230 for return flights from London had to 
queue for about 20 minutes for a boarding pass after the carrier recently changed its rules.
The airline has been under fire this week after it emerged that some passengers who do not pay for reserved seats 
had to queue for boarding passes.
One passenger who contacted The Irish Times paid £200 (EUR 233) for return Stansted-Dublin flights this week 
and had to queue in the London airport for a boarding pass as they did not pay to reserve a seat. The passenger, 
who was travelling to Dublin on short notice for personal reasons, paid £180 for the outward leg from Stansted and 
£20 return.
When the individual checked in online, they opted for a randomly selected seat, a service for which Ryanair does 
not charge. 
Boarding pass Once they requested their boarding pass at the end of the process, they received a message 
saying:  This is not a mobile boarding pass, you must collect your boarding pass at the airport check-in 
desk . They estimated that they had to queue 15-20 minutes at Stansted Airport to get their printed 
boarding pass.
The individual says they chose to pay £9 to reserve a seat on the return leg to avoid waiting at the airport for a 
pass.
Ryanair introduced this procedure recently, sparking reports that the carrier was attempting to charge for boarding 
passes or to prompt more passengers to pay for seats.
However, Ryanair pointed out that it did not charge for digital boarding passes.  All Ryanair passengers can pay for 
a reserved seat if they so wish or if passengers wish to avoid this seat fee, they can select a randomly allocated 
seat entirely free of charge,  said the airline.
Ryanair charges EUR 8-EUR 21 to reserve seats, asking more for  legroom  seats at emergency exits or at the front 
of the aircraft.
Ryanair passengers queue for boarding passes after changes to procedure
It has three fares: basic, which allows the passenger one small on-board bag; regular, which includes a 10kg that 
can be stowed overhead; and plus, which includes a 20kg check-in bag. The airline maintains that it has to charge 
for extras to keep fares low.
Load-Date: December 6, 2023
End of Document

Ryanair reveals full details of new budget flights from Norwich Airport
Ryanair reveals full details of new budget flights from Norwich Airport
Evening News (Norwich)
December 7, 2023
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2023 NLA Media Access Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; FRONT PAGE; Pg. 4
Length: 312 words
Byline: BETHANY WALES
Body
Ryanair's new routes out of Norwich airport will create more than 60 new jobs and bring more than 60,000 
passengers through the terminal each year, the company has revealed. The budget airline confirmed it would begin 
operations at the airport for the first time, with 12 flights a week to and from Malta, Alicante, and Faro starting on 
April 1.
The new jobs created will boost the number of people employed at the airport by around a quarter.
The company said the new routes would also bring more than 60,000 additional passengers to the airport, with 
return tickets currently available to Alicante from £29.99.
It added that the budgetfriendly flights would be "exciting" for passengers, who it said had been "forced to pay sky 
high fares by the high fare carriers who dominate at Norwich Airport".
Ryanair's head of communication, Jade Kirwan, said: "Our new Norwich operation will bring competitive fares and a 
wider selection of summer routes to our customers in Norwich and the wider Norfolk region, and also support 
important regional development through increased connectivity, inbound tourism, and local job creation."
Norwich Airport currently operates flights to 18 destinations in nine countries, with connections to 150 more 
locations via Amsterdam.
Journeys to Malta and the Spanish port city Alicante have been previously available with KLM and the now-
dissolved Flybe, but services were cancelled shortly before the Covid pandemic.
The airport said that although passenger numbers had fallen due to the pandemic, they had returned to around 
80pc of their pre-Covid levels, and that the arrival of Ryanair was due to push that up to 90pc.
Ryanair reveals full details of new budget flights from Norwich Airport
Richard Pace, managing director of Norwich Airport, added: "Alicante, Faro and Malta are hugely popular 
destinations and with twice-weekly flights it means we can offer passengers even more great choices from their 
local airport."
Graphic
 
Andrew Bell, chief executive of Regional & City Airports (RCA), which owns Norwich Airport; Steve Lilley, RCA's 
aviation development director; Jade Kirwan, Ryanair head of communications; and Brian Mitchell, senior analyst, 
Ryanair Commercial Image: NORWICH AIRPORT
Load-Date: December 7, 2023
End of Document

Will Ryanair's arrival bring economic take-off?; Opinion SERVING THE COMMUNITY SINCE 1870
Will Ryanair's arrival bring economic take-off?; Opinion SERVING THE 
COMMUNITY SINCE 1870
Eastern Daily Press
December 7, 2023
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2023 NLA Media Access Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: LETTERS; Pg. 36
Length: 301 words
Body
There's no doubt that attracting budget airline Ryanair to Norwich for the first time is quite a feather in the cap for 
the city's airport.
When flights start leaving from the runway next year it will mark the first time the Irish company has operated from 
Norwich.
The airline predicts it will increase the number of passengers passing through the airport terminal's doors each year 
by some 60,000 people.
And it says that will create more than 60 new jobs - which would increase the number of people employed at the 
airport by around a quarter.
That is a significant number of new jobs for the city, which will provide a boost to the regional economy.
Passengers will no doubt welcome new flights to and from Malta, Alicante and Faro, particularly if Ryanair is true to 
its word about people not having to pay "sky hire fares" to jet off on their holiday getaways.
Campaigners, who have long criticised the aviation industry for fuelling climate change, are less likely to be 
impressed.
And a word of further caution is, perhaps, needed. There have been too many occasions when airline operators 
have turned up offering flights from Norwich Airport only to not stay the course, or whose services have left 
something to be desired.
Will Ryanair's arrival bring economic take-off?; Opinion SERVING THE COMMUNITY SINCE 1870
TUI has come in for strong criticism over the past couple of summers after a catalogue of delays and disruption, 
with some holidaymakers being diverted to other airports because of issues with some of the planes which were 
being used.
Hopefully, Ryanair's intentions are a vote of confidence in the city - a sign that its fluctuating fortunes are on the up.
Passenger numbers dropped off because of the Covid pandemic. They are now around 80 percent of pre-Covid 
levels. It is predicted the arrival of Ryanair will push it up to 90pc, which will be a welcome boost for airport bosses.
Load-Date: December 7, 2023
End of Document
Feather in the cap for city airport bosses; OPINION
Feather in the cap for city airport bosses; OPINION
Evening News (Norwich)
December 7, 2023
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2023 NLA Media Access Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: FEATURES; LETTERS; Pg. 32
Length: 364 words
Body
There is no doubt that attracting budget airline Ryanair to Norwich for the first time is quite a feather in the cap for 
the city's airport.
When flights start leaving from the runway for the first time next year it will mark the first time the Irish company has 
operated from Norwich.
The airline predicts it will increase the number of passengers passing through the airport terminal's doors each year 
by some 50,000 people.
And it says that will create more than 60 new jobs - which would increase the number of people employed at the 
airport by around a quarter.
That is a significant number of new jobs for the city, which will provide a boost to the regional economy.
Passengers will no doubt welcome new flights to and from Malta, Alicante and Faro, particularly if Ryanair is true to 
its word about people not having to pay "sky hire fares" to jet off on their holiday getaways.
Campaigners, who have long criticised the aviation industry for fuelling climate change, are less likely to be 
impressed.
And a word of further caution is, perhaps, needed. There have been too many occasions when airline operators 
have turned up offering flights from Norwich Airport only to not stay the course, or whose services have left 
something to be desired.
Tui has come in for strong criticism over the past couple of summers after a catalogue of delays and disruption, with 
some holidaymakers being diverted to other airports because of issues with some of the planes which were being 
used.
Feather in the cap for city airport bosses; OPINION
And there have been fanfare announcements before, only for flights to be cancelled because the demand for them 
was simply not there.
It also worth remembering that Ryanair is not the first big name budget airline to have a base in Norwich.
Flybe - once Europe's largest independent airline - used to offer a number of flights from the city until it pulled out in 
2019, filing for administration a year later.
Hopefully, Ryanair's intentions are a vote of confidence in the city's airport.
Passenger numbers dropped off because of the Covid pandemic. They are now around 80pc of pre-Covid levels. It 
is predicted the arrival of Ryanair will push it up to 90pc, which will be a welcome boost for airport bosses.
Load-Date: December 7, 2023
End of Document
RYANAIR ASKS FOR IMMEDIATE OPENING OF MONTIJO AIRPORT TO STIMULATE GROWTH AND 
REDUCE FARES IN LISBON
RYANAIR ASKS FOR IMMEDIATE OPENING OF MONTIJO AIRPORT TO 
STIMULATE GROWTH AND REDUCE FARES IN LISBON
Contify Aviation News
December 7, 2023 Thursday 6:30 AM EST
Copyright 2023 Contify.com All Rights Reserved
Length: 907 words
Body
Ryanair is urging the Portuguese Government to open Montijo Airport urgently to address the capacity crisis in 
Lisbon. The airline argues that the current Lisbon Airport no longer meets the needs and that Montijo should be 
opened to provide additional connectivity and tourism growth. Ryanair also criticizes ANA, the airport's owner, for 
increasing airport fees and harming Portugal's connectivity, tourism, and low fares. The airline has already been 
forced to reduce operations in response to the fee increase.
Key Highlights:
* Passenger fees in Lisbon have increased by 50% since 2019, while most European airports have reduced fees to 
recover traffic and growth
* Ryanair has been forced to withdraw an aircraft from its base in Madeira and reduce traffic in Faro and Porto due 
to the increase in airport fees
* Granting the concession for Montijo to a competitor of AFA would accelerate its opening and bring more traffic, 
tourism growth, and thousands of new jobs to Lisbon and Portugal
Original Press Release:
Dec. 7 -- Ryanair Group issued the following news release:
- INDEPENDENT PROVIDER REQUIRED TO OPERATE MONTIJO AND BREAK ANA'S MONOPOLY
Ryanair, Portugal's main airline, today (7 December), calls on the Portuguese Government to stop wasting time on 
'studies' and 'commissions' and deliver much-needed growth in air transport and tourism to Lisbon. The solution to 
Lisbon's capacity crisis is obvious and lies across the bay in Montijo. Ryanair calls for the urgent opening of Montijo 
Airport following yesterday's announcement by the Independent Technical Commission regarding the new airport in 
the Lisbon area. The current Lisbon airport (Portela) no longer meets the needs and Montijo must be opened 
RYANAIR ASKS FOR IMMEDIATE OPENING OF MONTIJO AIRPORT TO STIMULATE GROWTH AND 
REDUCE FARES IN LISBON
urgently to provide Lisbon and Portugal with the additional connectivity and tourism/job growth needed to stimulate 
the economy.
Montijo Airport should be reopened to break the monopoly of ANA, the company that owns the airport, on access to 
Lisbon airport. ANA, which is increasing airport fees by 17% from 2024, is harming Portugal's connectivity, tourism 
growth, job growth and undermining low fares for Portuguese consumers and visitors. It is no longer acceptable for 
Portugal's citizens and visitors to be exploited by ANA's refusal to accommodate further growth or efficiencies at 
Lisbon Portela Airport.
The French-owned ANA monopoly faces no competition in Portugal, which allows it to increase prices without 
penalty. In Lisbon alone, passenger rates have increased by +50% since 2019, despite most European airports 
reducing passenger rates post-Covid to recover traffic and growth. The Portuguese Government has failed to 
ensure that airports, which play a vital role in the national infrastructure, are used to drive growth for the benefit of 
Portugal's citizens and economy, rather than enriching a French-owned airport monopoly operator.
Ryanair has already been forced to withdraw one aircraft (a $100 million investment) from its base in Madeira this 
winter, while also reducing traffic at Faro and Porto in response to ANA's 17% increase in airport charges from 
2024. However, a decision by the Portuguese Government to grant the concession for Montijo to an AFA competitor 
would accelerate the opening of Montijo and bring more traffic and tourism growth, as well as thousands of new 
jobs to Lisbon and Portugal.
Michael O'Leary, Ryanair Group CEO, said:
"The Portuguese Government has been idly talking for years about a second airport for Lisbon, while Montijo 
should have been opened years ago. We are almost in 2024 and we are still waiting for the Portuguese 
Government to make a decision on where to place a new airport for Lisbon. ANA, the French airport monopoly, 
claims that Portela is full and cannot issue any more slots. Any sensible government would ensure that the capital's 
airport has the capacity to grow. The Portuguese Government failed to do this, and the solution is across the bay in 
Montijo.
The time for studies, commissions and more politics is over. Lisbon's citizens and visitors deserve growth in 
frequencies and new routes, and this can only be delivered in Montijo. The airport in Montijo already exists, needs a 
modest investment in terminal infrastructure and could be ready by the summer of 2024 or 2025 if the Portuguese 
Government would just make a decision.
As the former Minister of Transport, Pedro Nuno Santos, said, Portugal is wasting a lot of time postponing this 
decision on the second airport. The decision must be made now. The Portuguese Government must wake up and 
open Montijo to prevent the French monopoly VINCI from enriching itself at the expense of Portugal's citizens and 
visitors with inflationary price increases in Lisbon, Portela, whilst artificially restricting capacity growth in Portela. 
Competition for Montijo will bring growth, choice and lower fares for Portugal's citizens and visitors, and Montijo 
must be opened urgently, preferably under the management of a new airport operator, if the future growth and 
health of Lisbon's tourism industry is to be maintained. guaranteed.
The time for hesitation and delay is over. The time to select Montijo as Lisbon's second airport and allocate its 
operation to an airport operator competing with the French monopoly VINCI has long passed ."
Disclaimer: The Above Content is Auto-Translated
Source: Ryanair Group

Ryanair flight from Dublin to Lanzarote diverted to Africa due to 'disruptive' passenger
Ryanair flight from Dublin to Lanzarote diverted to Africa due to 'disruptive' 
passenger
irishmirror.ie
December 7, 2023 Thursday 3:57 PM GMT
Copyright 2023 Reach PLC All Rights Reserved
Section: IRISH NEWS; Version:1
Length: 244 words
Byline: By, Rayana Zapryanova & Clare McCarthy
Highlight: The plane was diverted to Morocco and met by police on the runway who removed the passenger and 
took them into custody
Body
A Ryanair flight from Dublin to Lanzarote had to be diverted to a country in north Africa yesterday after a passenger 
on board became "disruptive".
The incident, which happened after the flight left Dublin Airport yesterday morning, December 6, caused the flight to 
be re-routed to one of Morocco's major cities, Agadir. 
Once it landed in the local airport, the plane was met on the runway by Moroccan police who removed the 
disruptive passenger and took them into custody, Dublin Live reports.
After this disturbance, the flight continued to Lanzarote and arrived "with a short delay". 
A spokeswoman for Ryanair told the Irish Mirror: "This flight from Dublin to Lanzarote 6 Dec diverted to Agadir 
when a passenger became disruptive onboard. 
"Crew called ahead for police assistance and the aircraft was met by local police upon arrival who removed the 
disruptive passenger. 
"The flight continued to Lanzarote following a short delay."
Meanwhile, the Ryanair spokesperson said the disruption caused by the passenger "is now a matter for [Moroccan] 
police".
Ryanair flight from Dublin to Lanzarote diverted to Africa due to 'disruptive' passenger

DAILY ADR AND DEPOSITORY RECEIPT REPORT
www.buysellsignals.com
Ryanair Holdings PLC's (O: RYAAY $126.35) ADR price hit a 52-week high of $126.90 during the day. In the last

increase was 1.2%. 
Ryanair Holdings PLC is the International Depository Receipt (IDR) market's largest Airlines company by market 
cap. 
Today its volatility (highest price minus lowest price/lowest price) of 2.8% was 1.3 times its average daily volatility of 
2.1%. Today the ADR traded at its twenty-six-month high of $126.90. The last time the price hit that high level was 
on Monday, Nov 08, 2021. The low for the day was $123.49.

ADR Daily: Ryanair Holdings ADR (RYAAY: US$123.60) hits year-high 10th time in three months
Ryanair Holdings PLC's (O: RYAAY US$123.60) ADR price hit a 52-week high of US$124.16 during the day. In the 
last three months the ADR has hit a new 52-week high ten times, pointing to a significant uptrend.

increase was 2.2%.

SECTION 6  ONGOING BULLISH PARAMETERS6.1  The Best Periods [3 Mo, 1 Yr] with Price Change % > 15.31-
Year price change of 41.9% for Ryanair Holdings outperformed the change of 17.9% in the ISEQ Overall Index for a 
relative price change of 24%.
6.2  Annualised Period-based Total Shareholder Returns [TSR %]: The Best Periods with TSR > 9.2%
6.3  Low Debt to Equity (%) and ReducingThe debt to equity ratio of 24.6% is under a safe benchmark figure of 
50%. Moreover, it has improved from 41.1% a year ago.
6.4  Increased VWAP, up 41% in 5 yearsIn the past five years Volume Weighted Average Price (VWAP) has 
increased by 40.8% to EUR15.49.
6.5  Increased share turnoverIn the past five years, average daily share turnover has increased 2.3% to EUR26 
million ($28.1 million). This suggests increased liquidity.
6.6  Satisfies one criterion of Benjamin Graham-"Total debt less than tangible book value"; total debt of EUR1.4 
billion (US$1.5 billion) is less than tangible book value of EUR5.3 billion (US$6 billion).-"Total debt equal or less 
than twice the net quick liquidation value"; total debt of EUR1.4 billion (US$1.5 billion) is 0.3 times the net 
liquidation value of EUR4.11 billion (US$4.7 billion).

- At EUR18.43 the price has risen above the upper Bollinger band resistance of EUR18.32, indicating a downside 
risk for it to fall back within the band.- The Relative Strength Index (RSI) of 75.1 has penetrated the overbought line 
of 70, suggesting the price gain of 5.4% in the last 14 days is unusually high.- The stock is overbought according to 
the Williams % R indicator of -1.5, suggesting the price is close to its 14-day high of EUR18.45.
SECTION 8  ONGOING BEARISH PARAMETERS8.1  Stock vs Index (Annual Percentage Change)
Over 5 years Ryanair Holdings is up a total 13.6% at an annualized rate of 3.2% compared to the Index being up 
29.7% at an annualized rate of 6.7%.
Ryanair Holdings has outperformed the ISEQ Overall Index in 2 of the past 5years: 2020, 2019.
8.2  Annualised Period-based Total Shareholder Returns [TSR %]: The Worst Period with TSR < 2.7%
8.3  Declining Volume, down 24% in 5 yearsIn the past five years, Average Daily Volume of Trading (ADVT) has 
decreased 24.1% to 1.8 million shares.
8.4  Satisfies 3 out of 9 criteria of Joseph Piotroski [pass mark 5]:- Positive operating cashflow.- Good quality of 
earnings [operating cashflow exceeds net income].- Improvement in asset turnover [growth in revenue of 193.5% 
exceeded growth in assets of 22.9%].
But does not meet the following 6 criteria of Joseph Piotroski:- Positive net income.- Return on Assets 
improvement.- Improvement in long-term debt to total assets.- Improvement in current ratio.- Total shares on issue 
unchanged (or reduction in total shares on issue).- Improvement in gross margin.

Ryanair Holdings PLC (O:RYAAY $125.18), Ryanair Holdings PLC is the International Depository Receipt (IDR)

0.6%.

Why do I have to queue for a boarding pass on Ryanair ?
Why do I have to queue for a boarding pass on Ryanair?
The Independent - Daily Edition
December 7, 2023 Thursday
First Edition
Copyright 2023 Independent Print Ltd All Rights Reserved
Section: SECTION 2; Pg. 26
Length: 420 words
Byline: SIMON CALDER
Body
Q I've read of an apparently new requirement for some Ryanair passengers to queue up at the airport for a 
boarding pass rather than using a code on their mobile phone. Could it be because Ryanair's new Boeing 737 Max 
aircraft have more seats than their 737-800 aircraft? In the event of an equipment change, it could mean the 
unlucky few on a full flight could be moved onto the next one - which is something they would do at the check-in 
desk?
TTD
A Ryanair's airport arrangements for passengers, like me, who prefer to avail of the basic fare on budget airlines 
without any added extras, abruptly changed at the weekend. The standard option to show a mobile boarding pass 
on their smart phone was not open to some of them. Instead, they were offered a choice between paying for an 
assigned seat - costing £8 or more - or queuing at an airport check-in desk for a paper boarding pass to their 
randomly assigned seat.
A spokesperson for the airline told me: "If passengers wish to avoid this seat fee, they can select a randomly 
allocated seat entirely free of charge." That's true, but it does not explain the current issue. So I have been studying 
the airline's customer-care feed on social media. One passenger was told: "Due to popularity of reserved seats, 
Ryanair is keeping seats available until the end for those customers wishing to purchase. Some passengers will be 
assigned the last remaining seats at the airport for free."
The idea that Ryanair has to hold seats back because people routinely decide at an airport to pay extra to reserve a 
space looks preposterous. All of us who are content with random allocation have declined repeated invitations to 
pay extra. But were I running late and/or the queue for boarding passes looked too long, I would reluctantly pay up - 
and it seems others are, too. The aim seems to be: to increase the number of passengers who pay for a specific 
seat by offering an unpalatable alternative: another airport hurdle and queue.
Why do I have to queue for a boarding pass on Ryanair ?
You smartly raise the "downgauging" issue: when an older 189-seat jet has to replace a newer 197-seat plane. This 
is a rare event, and when it happens there are almost always enough seats because of "no-shows"; Ryanair does 
not overbook. I have only heard of one confirmed incident. In common with other airlines such episodes are 
handled at the departure gate - with the carrier obliged to offer incentives to lure volunteers to offload, or pay cash 
compensation for involuntary denial of boarding.
Email your question to s@hols.tv or tweet @simoncalder
Load-Date: December 6, 2023
End of Document
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) Stock Rating Upgraded by StockNews.com
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) Stock Rating Upgraded by StockNews.com
Newstex Blogs 
Zolmax.com
December 7, 2023 Thursday
Copyright 2023 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 586 words
Body
December 7th, 2023 ( Zolmax.com  — Delivered by  Newstex )
Ryanair ( NASDAQ:RYAAY  - Get Free Report ) was upgraded by stock analysts at StockNews.com  from a "hold" 
rating to a "buy" rating in a research note issued to investors on Tuesday.
Separately, TheStreet upgraded shares of Ryanair from a "c" rating to a "b" rating in a report on Friday, December 
1st. Seven research analysts have rated the stock with a buy rating and one has assigned a strong buy rating to the 
stock. Based on data from MarketBeat, the stock has a consensus rating of "Buy" and a consensus target price of 
$59.00.
Read Our Latest Stock Analysis on Ryanair
Ryanair Stock Performance
Shares of Ryanair stock  opened at $124.12 on Tuesday. The stock's fifty day simple moving average is $102.73 
and its 200 day simple moving average is $103.12. The company has a current ratio of 1.19, a quick ratio of 1.19 
and a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.31. The company has a market capitalization of $28.27 billion, a PE ratio of 11.76, a 
PEG ratio of 0.81 and a beta of 1.53. Ryanair has a 12 month low of $73.50 and a 12 month high of $124.30.
Ryanair ( NASDAQ:RYAAY  - Get Free Report ) last announced its earnings results on Monday, November 6th. 
The transportation company reported $7.21 EPS for the quarter, topping the consensus estimate of $7.13 by $0.08. 
The firm had revenue of $5.36 billion for the quarter, compared to the consensus estimate of $5.14 billion. Ryanair 
had a net margin of 17.65% and a return on equity of 34.37%. On average, research analysts predict that Ryanair 
will post 8.87 EPS for the current year.
Institutional Inflows and Outflows
Institutional investors and hedge funds have recently made changes to their positions in the business. Simplicity 
Solutions LLC grew its stake in Ryanair by 1.3% during the second quarter. Simplicity Solutions LLC now owns 
7,692 shares of the transportation company's stock worth $851,000 after buying an additional 98 shares in the last 
quarter. Cetera Advisor Networks LLC lifted its stake in Ryanair by 4.6% during the second quarter. Cetera Advisor 
Networks LLC now owns 2,458 shares of the transportation company's stock worth $272,000 after purchasing an 
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) Stock Rating Upgraded by StockNews.com
additional 108 shares during the last quarter. Financial Gravity Asset Management Inc. acquired a new stake in 
shares of Ryanair in the 2nd quarter valued at $76,000. Bleakley Financial Group LLC raised its holdings in shares 
of Ryanair by 1.6% during the 2nd quarter. Bleakley Financial Group LLC now owns 7,699 shares of the 
transportation company's stock worth $852,000 after buying an additional 124 shares in the last quarter. Finally, 
Gallacher Capital Management LLC lifted its position in shares of Ryanair by 3.3% during the 3rd quarter. Gallacher 
Capital Management LLC now owns 4,043 shares of the transportation company's stock worth $393,000 after 
buying an additional 128 shares during the last quarter. Institutional investors and hedge funds own 43.66% of the 
company's stock.
Ryanair Company Profile
( Get Free Report )
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, Italy, Spain, and internationally. It is also involved in the provision of various ancillary services, 
such as non-flight scheduled and Internet-related services, as well as in-flight sale of beverages, food, duty-free, 
and merchandise; and markets car hire, travel insurance, and accommodation services through its website and 
mobile app.

A year ago the Turk Hava Yollari ADR price was $72.0. $1,000 would have bought 13.9 Turk Hava Yollari ADR on 
that day. Those 13.9 ADRs would be worth $1,241 at today's ADR price of $89.38. PV$1000= $1,241.
Activities
Turk Hava Yollari Anonim Ortakligi (THY), also known as Turkish Airlines, provides passenger and cargo air 
transportation services. The Company serves all domestic destinations as well as the Middle East, North America, 
Europe, Asia, North Africa and South Africa. It is the International Depository Receipt (IDR) market's 3rd largest 
Airlines company by market capitalisation.

You can fly to these warm and sunny destinations for as little as £34 return this December
You can fly to these warm and sunny destinations for as little as £34 return 
this December
walesonline.co.uk
December 7, 2023 Thursday 7:39 PM GMT
Copyright 2023 Reach PLC All Rights Reserved
Section: TRAVEL; Version:1
Length: 351 words
Byline: By, Robert Dalling
Highlight: There are real bargains to be had if you fancy escaping the rain and soaking up some sun before 
Christmas
Body
The winter season has well and truly arrived with the coats, woollen jumpers and thermals well and truly circulated 
to the front of our wardrobes. The familiar cold temperatures of December are upon us as we head into Christmas, 
with the sunshine feeling as far away than ever if you live in Wales. 
But if you're looking to save on the heating bills for a week, put the umbrellas away and soak up some sun for a bit 
longer, there are some some cheap and affordable deals that have become available to do just that. We've found 
return flights being offered by budget airlines Easyjet and Ryanair over the coming weeks for as little as £34. If 
Benidorm is your scene, you can fly there for the bargain price from Bristol for four nights. 
And it'll cost you only £7 more to head to Venice, with a return flight priced at £41, or even Faro in Portugal for a 
bargain £48 return. For the latest Swansea news, sign up to our newsletter here. Here are some of the best deals 
on offer at the moment. Join our WhatsApp news community here for the latest breaking news.
                     Alicante, Spain                    
Outbound Monday, December 11: 09:00 Bristol to Alicante 
Return Friday, December 15: 11:05 Alicante to Bristol 
Price: £34, Ryanair
                     Venice, Italy                   
You can fly to these warm and sunny destinations for as little as £34 return this December
Outbound Monday, December 11: 11:10 Bristol to Venice 
Return Friday, December 15 15:50 Venice to Bristol 
£41, Ryanair
                     Faro, Portugal                   
Outbound Monday, December 18: 17:05 Bristol to Faro 
Return Friday, December 22: 09:00 Faro to Bristol 
£48, Ryanair
                     Tenerife, Canary Islands                   
Outbound Monday, December 11: 13:40 Bristol to Tenerife 
Return Friday, December 15: 19:05 Tenerife to Bristol 
£58, Easyjet
                      Paris, France                   
Outbound Monday, December 11: 10:30 Bristol to Paris 
Return Friday, December 15: 22:15 Paris to Bristol 
£64, Easyjet
                      Malaga, Spain                   
Outbound Monday, December 11: 06:20 Bristol to Malaga 
Return Friday, December 15: 10:30 Malaga to Bristol 
£74, Easyjet

Teesside International Airport: Summer 2024 Flights Now on Sale as Popular Dalaman Flight Returns
Teesside International Airport: Summer 2024 Flights Now on Sale as Popular 
Dalaman Flight Returns
Contify Aviation News
December 7, 2023 Thursday 6:30 AM EST
Copyright 2023 Contify.com All Rights Reserved
Length: 654 words
Body
Flights for the summer of 2024 are now on sale from Teesside Airport, including the return of the popular flight to 
Dalaman, Turkey. TUI has launched a new weekly route to Dalaman, with flights every Tuesday from May to 
September. Passenger numbers at the airport have increased by 25% year-on-year. Ryanair is also offering flights 
from Teesside to various destinations. KLM provides three daily flights to Amsterdam Schiphol, and Balkan 
Holidays will begin its service to Bourgas, Bulgaria.
Key Highlights:
* Tees Valley Mayor Ben Houchen expressed the desire for next year to be even better with more flight options
* Teesside Airport offers a Family Plus bundle for summer holiday planning
* The airport recommends contacting a local travel agent to book a package holiday
Original Press Release:
Dec. 7 -- Teesside International Airportissued the following news release:
Holidaymakers can now get their 2024 summer holiday booked from Teesside, with flights now on sale - including 
the return of Dalaman, Turkey, after a 13-year absence.
Following the airport's busiest period since returning to public ownership in 2019 - with passenger numbers up 25% 
year-on-year - TUI have launched their new weekly route.
It will fly to and from Teesside every Tuesday from 28 May until 17 September - with flights departing at 9.20am. 
The flights open up the sandy beaches of Marmaris and Olu Deniz, as well as scenic bays along the south-western 
edge of Turkey.
This joins the airline's two flights a week to Majorca, running from 7 May to 22 October, which provides connections 
to Marella Cruises.
Teesside International Airport: Summer 2024 Flights Now on Sale as Popular Dalaman Flight Returns
This summer has seen the airport enjoy its busiest period since returning to public ownership in 2019 with 
passenger numbers up 25% year-on-year.
Next year aims to be even bigger and better, with low-cost carrier Ryanair also putting its flights from Teesside on 
sale. It is laying on 14 weekly flights for holidaymakers seeking summer sun to Alicante, Corfu, Faro and Majorca.
Planes will take off from Teesside to Majorca from 31 March to 24 October, with Faro running from 31 March to 23 
October - both operating twice a week. A once-a-week flight to Corfu will run from 1 June to 28 September, while 
the airline's twice-weekly year-round flights to Alicante will continue.
The airline has also introduced a Family Plus bundle to help people planning their summer holiday, as the cost of 
living continues to bite. This includes one small cabin bag, one 20kg family check-in bag, 10kg check-in bags for 
each party member and free seats for kids under 12.
These join the three-times daily KLM flight to Amsterdam Schiphol, offering hassle-free onward connectivity to more 
than 160 destinations, plus Balkan Holidays' service to Bourgas, Bulgaria, beginning 26 May and running to 8 
September.
Teesside is on course to record its busiest year since 2011 and has seen the strongest recovery of any UK airport 
since the Covid-19 pandemic.
Tees Valley Mayor Ben Houchen said: "The airport has enjoyed its best summer in almost 15 years thanks to the 
great selection of flights and destinations provided by TUI, Ryanair, KLM and Balkan Holidays.
"But we want next year to be even better, with the return of Dalaman and a great choice of destinations on sale now 
- and going quickly.
"It means families from Teesside and beyond can book their flights while knowing they'll be enjoying a smooth 
stress-free start to their well-earned holiday.
The flight announcement comes after Teesside Airport was named UK and Irish Airport of the Year
Teesside was named UK and Irish Airport of the Year at the TTG Travel Industry Awards in London after winning 
recognition for its growth in flights and delivering a great passenger experience.
Anyone looking to book a package holiday from Teesside should contact their local travel agent.
[Category: Transportation Infrastructure, Transportation/ Logistics, New Offerings, Divestiture]
Source: Teesside International Airport
Load-Date: December 8, 2023
End of Document

Investors look to see if Ryanair Holdings' recent rally will continue
SECTION 1 TODAY'S BULLISH SIGNALS1.1 PAST WEEK: STRONG MOMENTUM UPRYAAY adds 4.9% on 
robust volume 1.6 times average. Compared with the BNY Mellon Composite ADR Index which fell 0.1 points (or 
0.1%) in the week, the relative price increase was 5.8%. 
Ryanair Holdings (RYAAY) outperformed the The Bank of New York Mellon Composite ADR Index in 4 out of 5 
days. The price ranged between a high of $124.12 on Wednesday Dec 06 and a low of $118.22 on Thursday Nov 
30.[Volume Index (VI); 1 is average]
1.2 Other Bullish SignalsMCap/Total Assets:- Tobin's Q Ratio, defined as MCap divided by Total Assets, is 1.7. 
Compared with the rest of the market the ADR is undervalued.
SECTION 2 ONGOING BULLISH PARAMETERS2.1 Satisfies one criterion of Benjamin Graham-"Total debt less 
than tangible book value"; total debt of EUR1.4 billion (US$1.5 billion) is less than tangible book value of EUR5.3 
billion (US$6 billion).-"Total debt equal or less than twice the net quick liquidation value"; total debt of EUR1.4 billion 
(US$1.5 billion) is 0.3 times the net liquidation value of EUR4.11 billion (US$4.7 billion).
SECTION 3 TODAY'S BEARISH SIGNALS3.1 DowntrendBeta < 1 combined with price fall. The Beta of the ADR is 
0.4.
3.2 Overbought/Bearish Signals:- The Relative Strength Index (RSI) of 93.2 has penetrated the overbought line of 
70, suggesting the price gain of 8.3% in the last 14 days is unusually high. - The ADR is overbought according to 
the Williams % R indicator of -1.4, suggesting the price is close to its 14-day high of $124.30. - The Money Flow 
Index [MFI] is 80.4 suggesting an overbought 14-day trend, being above 80. The Money Ratio of 4.1 suggests 
positive money flow was 4.1 times negative money flow.
SECTION 4 ONGOING BEARISH PARAMETERS4.1 Satisfies 3 out of 9 criteria of Joseph Piotroski [pass mark 5]:- 
Positive operating cashflow.- Good quality of earnings [operating cashflow exceeds net income].- Improvement in 
asset turnover [growth in revenue of 193.5% exceeded growth in assets of 22.9%].
But does not meet the following 6 criteria of Joseph Piotroski:- Positive net income.- Return on Assets 
improvement.- Improvement in long-term debt to total assets.- Improvement in current ratio.- Total shares on issue 
unchanged (or reduction in total shares on issue).- Improvement in gross margin.

Cetera Advisor Networks LLC Acquires 108 Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY)
Cetera Advisor Networks LLC Acquires 108 Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc 
(NASDAQ:RYAAY)
American Banking and Market News
December 7, 2023 Thursday
Copyright 2023 American Banking and Market News All Rights Reserved
Length: 690 words
Body
Ryanair logo Cetera Advisor Networks LLC grew its holdings in shares of  Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY  
- Free Report ) by 4.6% during the second quarter, according to the company in its most recent filing with the 
Securities and Exchange Commission. The institutional investor  owned 2,458 shares of the transportation 
company's stock after buying an additional 108 shares during the period. Cetera Advisor Networks LLC's holdings 
in Ryanair were worth $272,000 as of its most recent SEC filing.  
A number of other hedge funds have also recently modified their holdings of the business. Financial Gravity Asset 
Management Inc. bought a new position in  Ryanair during the 2nd quarter valued at about $76,000.  Leuthold 
Group LLC bought a new position in  Ryanair during the 2nd quarter valued at about $346,000.  New York State 
Common Retirement Fund lifted its stake in  Ryanair by 18.8% during the 2nd quarter. New York State Common 
Retirement Fund now owns 315,477 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $34,892,000 after 
acquiring an additional 50,013 shares during the period.  abrdn plc lifted its stake in  Ryanair by 2.8% during the 
2nd quarter. abrdn plc now owns 12,298 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $1,360,000 after 
acquiring an additional 339 shares during the period.  Finally, Hartford Funds Management Co LLC lifted its stake in  
Ryanair by 12.8% during the 2nd quarter. Hartford Funds Management Co LLC now owns 4,147 shares of the 
transportation company's stock valued at $459,000 after acquiring an additional 469 shares during the period. 
Institutional investors own  43.66% of the company's stock.  Ryanair Trading Up 2.7 %
Ryanair stock  opened at $124.12 on Thursday. The firm has a 50 day moving average of $102.73 and a 200 day 
moving average of $103.12. The firm has a market capitalization of $28.27 billion, a price-to-earnings ratio of 11.76, 
a P/E/G ratio of 0.81 and a beta of 1.53. Ryanair Holdings plc has a 12-month low of $73.50 and a 12-month high of 
$124.30. The company has a current ratio of 1.19, a quick ratio of 1.19 and a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.31.  
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY  - Get Free Report ) last released its earnings results on Monday, November 6th. The 
transportation company reported $7.21 earnings per share (EPS) for the quarter, topping the consensus estimate of 
$7.13 by $0.08. The company had revenue of $5.36 billion during the quarter, compared to analyst estimates of 
$5.14 billion. Ryanair had a net margin of 17.65% and a return on equity of 34.37%.  As a group, research analysts 
predict that  Ryanair Holdings plc will post 8.87 earnings per share for the current year.  Wall Street Analysts 
Forecast Growth
Several research firms have issued reports on RYAAY. TheStreet upgraded shares of Ryanair from a "c" rating to a 
"b" rating in a research note on Friday, December 1st. StockNews.com  raised shares of Ryanair from a "hold" 
rating to a "buy" rating in a research report on Tuesday. Seven equities research analysts have rated the stock with 
Cetera Advisor Networks LLC Acquires 108 Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY)
a buy rating and one  has given a strong buy rating to the company. According to MarketBeat, Ryanair  has an 
average rating of "Buy" and an average target price of $59.00. 
View Our Latest Research Report on Ryanair Ryanair Profile (Free Report )
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, Italy, Spain, and internationally. It is also involved in the provision of various ancillary services, 
such as non-flight scheduled and Internet-related services, as well as in-flight sale of beverages, food, duty-free, 
and merchandise; and markets car hire, travel insurance, and accommodation services through its website and 
mobile app.Read More

Cetera Advisor Networks LLC Acquires 108 Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc ( NASDAQ :RYAAY)
Cetera Advisor Networks LLC Acquires 108 Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc 
(NASDAQ:RYAAY)
Newstex Blogs 
Zolmax.com
December 7, 2023 Thursday
Copyright 2023 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 636 words
Body
December 7th, 2023 ( Zolmax.com  — Delivered by  Newstex )
Cetera Advisor Networks LLC grew its holdings in shares of Ryanair Holdings plc ( NASDAQ:RYAAY  - Free Report 
) by 4.6% during the second quarter, according to the company in its most recent filing with the Securities and 
Exchange Commission. The institutional investor owned 2,458 shares of the transportation company's stock after 
buying an additional 108 shares during the period. Cetera Advisor Networks LLC's holdings in Ryanair were worth 
$272,000 as of its most recent SEC filing.
A number of other hedge funds have also recently modified their holdings of the business. Financial Gravity Asset 
Management Inc. bought a new position in Ryanair during the 2nd quarter valued at about $76,000. Leuthold Group 
LLC bought a new position in Ryanair during the 2nd quarter valued at about $346,000. New York State Common 
Retirement Fund lifted its stake in Ryanair by 18.8% during the 2nd quarter. New York State Common Retirement 
Fund now owns 315,477 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $34,892,000 after acquiring an 
additional 50,013 shares during the period. abrdn plc lifted its stake in Ryanair by 2.8% during the 2nd quarter. 
abrdn plc now owns 12,298 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $1,360,000 after acquiring an 
additional 339 shares during the period. Finally, Hartford Funds Management Co LLC lifted its stake in Ryanair by 
12.8% during the 2nd quarter. Hartford Funds Management Co LLC now owns 4,147 shares of the transportation 
company's stock valued at $459,000 after acquiring an additional 469 shares during the period. Institutional 
investors own 43.66% of the company's stock.
Ryanair Trading Up 2.7 %
Ryanair stock  opened at $124.12 on Thursday. The firm has a 50 day moving average of $102.73 and a 200 day 
moving average of $103.12. The firm has a market capitalization of $28.27 billion, a price-to-earnings ratio of 11.76, 
a P/E/G ratio of 0.81 and a beta of 1.53. Ryanair Holdings plc has a 12-month low of $73.50 and a 12-month high of 
$124.30. The company has a current ratio of 1.19, a quick ratio of 1.19 and a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.31.
Ryanair ( NASDAQ:RYAAY  - Get Free Report ) last released its earnings results on Monday, November 6th. The 
transportation company reported $7.21 earnings per share (EPS) for the quarter, topping the consensus estimate of 
$7.13 by $0.08. The company had revenue of $5.36 billion during the quarter, compared to analyst estimates of 
Cetera Advisor Networks LLC Acquires 108 Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc ( NASDAQ :RYAAY)
$5.14 billion. Ryanair had a net margin of 17.65% and a return on equity of 34.37%. As a group, research analysts 
predict that Ryanair Holdings plc will post 8.87 earnings per share for the current year.
Wall Street Analysts Forecast Growth
Several research firms have issued reports on RYAAY. TheStreet upgraded shares of Ryanair from a "c" rating to a 
"b" rating in a research note on Friday, December 1st. StockNews.com  raised shares of Ryanair from a "hold" 
rating to a "buy" rating in a research report on Tuesday. Seven equities research analysts have rated the stock with 
a buy rating and one has given a strong buy rating to the company. According to MarketBeat, Ryanair has an 
average rating of "Buy" and an average target price of $59.00.
View Our Latest Research Report on Ryanair
Ryanair Profile
( Free Report )
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, Italy, Spain, and internationally. It is also involved in the provision of various ancillary services, 
such as non-flight scheduled and Internet-related services, as well as in-flight sale of beverages, food, duty-free, 
and merchandise; and markets car hire, travel insurance, and accommodation services through its website and 
mobile app.
