48 Hours In: Palermo
48 Hours In: Palermo
The Independent (United Kingdom)
December 6, 2023 Wednesday 9:58 AM GMT
Copyright 2023 Independent Digital News and Media Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: ITALY,EUROPE,TRAVEL; Version:5
Length: 1620 words
Byline: Duncan Garwood
Highlight: Autumn's comfortable temperatures make the lively streets of Sicily's captivating capital a pleasure to 
explore, says Duncan Garwood.
Body
                       Click here for 48Hours                       In...Palermo map                   
                     Travel essentials                   
                     Why go now?                   
History, culture and operatic street life combine to make Palermo, Sicily's capital, a compelling, captivating city. 
Centuries of foreign rule have left an indelible mark on the city's fabric, which has a distinct East-meets-West feel 
with Norman palaces, Baroque churches, souk-like markets and Byzantine domes.
Autumn is a great time to explore its fascinating back streets as they return to full speed after the summer torpor 
and temperatures cool to pleasant levels. The cultural calendar also kicks off with Madama Butterfly opening at the 
Teatro Massimo (1) opera house on 18 Sept (00 39 091 605 3580; teatromassimo.it ).
                     Touch down                   
Ryanair (0871 246 0000; ryanair.com) flies to Palermo from Stansted and easyJet (0843 104 5000; easyjet.com) 
flies from Gatwick. Palermo's Falcone-Borsellino airport is at Punta Raisi, 30km west of the city. The cheapest way 
into town is on the Trinacria Express train to the central train station (2) (twice hourly between 5.45am and 
10.05pm; €5.80). Alternatively, the half-hourly Prestia e Comandè bus (www.prestiaecomande.it ) runs to the Teatro 
Politeama-Garibaldi (3) and central train station (2). Tickets for the 45-minute ride cost €6.10 and are available on 
the bus. The set taxi fare to the centre is €45.
                     Get your bearings                   
48 Hours In: Palermo
Palermo sits on Sicily's north-west coast, overlooked by the dun-coloured ridge of Monte Pellegrino. The historic 
centre, which extends north from the station (2) and contains most of the main sights, is made up of four quarters: 
La Kalsa, Albergheria, Capo and Vucciria. These are divided by the north-south Via Maqueda and the east-west 
Corso Vittorio Emanuele, which crosses it at a point known as the Quattro Canti (4), the "four corners". Running 
parallel to Via Maqueda, Via Roma is another important thoroughfare.
To the north, the 19th-century "new town" is the city's main shopping district. For free city maps, the main tourist 
office (5) is at Piazza Castelnuovo 34 (00 39 091 605 8351; www.provincia.palermo.it/turismo ; 8.30am-2pm and 
2.30-6pm weekdays only). There's also a tourist office at the airport (8.30am-7.30pm weekdays and 8.30am-2pm 
Saturdays).
                     Check-in                   
Richard Wagner supposedly completed his opera Parsifal at the Grand Hotel et Des Palmes (6) at Via Roma 398 
(00 39 091 60 28 111; amthotels.it/despalmes ), a stately 19th-century pile with a grandiose Liberty-style lobby and 
elegant carpeted rooms. Doubles with breakfast start at €145.
                                                                                                Book Now                                                                                      
For more modest digs, the friendly Hotel del Centro (7) at Via Roma 72 (00 39 091 617 0376; hoteldelcentro.it ) has 
bright, classically styled rooms and an excellent location between the train station (2) and Quattro Canti (4). 
Doubles start at €65, including breakfast.
                                                                                                Book Now                                                                                      
Near Teatro Massimo (1), A Casa di Amici (8), Via Volturno 6 (00 39 091 584 884; www.acasadiamici.com ), is an 
attractive hostel-cum-pensione with vibrantly coloured dorms (from €18) and high-ceilinged private rooms from €50, 
B&B.
                                                                                                Book Now                                                                                      
                     Day one                   
                     Take a hike                   
Start off at Palazzo Reale (9), aka Palazzo dei Normanni, at Piazza Indipendenza 1 (00 39 091 626 2833; 
federicosecondo.org ; open 8.15am-5.40pm and to 1pm Sunday; €8.50). Now seat of Sicily's regional government, 
this muscular Norman palace is home to the Cappella Palatina, a lustrous 12th-century chapel bedecked in gold 
mosaics. From the palace duck under the nearby Porta Nuova (10), and push on to the Cattedrale (11), Corso 
Vittorio Emanuele (cattedrale.palermo.it ; open 9am-to 5.30pm daily; free), whose hybrid Arab-Norman architecture 
incorporates crenellations and cupolas.
Continue on Corso Vittorio Emanuele to the Quattro Canti (4) intersection flanked by four Baroque façades. Turn 
right on to Via Maqueda and, on your left, you'll see the Fontana Pretoria (12), a lavish fountain of tiered basins and 
naked nymphs. Nip through to Piazza Bellini, home to two of Palermo's best-known churches – La Martorana (13), 
now sadly closed behind scaffolding, and the Chiesa Capitolare di San Cataldo (14) (9.30am-12.30pm and 3-6pm 
daily; €2.50).
                     Lunch on the run                   
Taste Palermo's local delicacies at the Touring Café (15) on Via Roma 252 (00 39 091 322 726; 6am to 11pm), 
which serves fabulous fist-sized arancini (fried rice balls; €1.50) and daily specials such as vegetable couscous 
(€5).
                     Window shopping                   
48 Hours In: Palermo
No trip to Palermo would be complete without trawling through a neighbourhood market. The Mercato del Capo 
(16), Via Sant'Agostino (open 7am-8pm daily except Sunday, to 1pm Wednesday) is one of the most characteristic, 
with groaning food stalls squeezed into the Dickensian alleyways of the Capo area.
For a more relaxed experience, there's Sapori e dei Saperi della Legalità (17) at Piazza Castelnuovo 13 (00 39 091 
757 4861). Browse the gourmet goodies, all of which have been produced on land confiscated from the mafia. 
Good buys include extra-virgin olive oil, wine and honey.
                     An aperitif                   
Join Palermo's refined café-goers for an early-evening drink at the Antico Caffè Spinnato (18), Via Principe di 
Belmonte 107-115 (00 39 091 749 5104; spinnato.it ). This polished café in the heart of the busy shopping district 
has outside tables where you can sit back and people-watch over chilled Corvo white (€4.20) or granita di gelsi 
(€4.50), an ice drink flavoured with black mulberries.
                     Dine with the locals                   
On a hidden piazza in the shabby Vucciria district, Ristorante Santandrea (19), Piazza Sant'Andrea 4 (00 39 091 
334 999; ristorantesantandrea.eu ; open dinner only Monday to Saturday) is a smart choice for creative seasonal 
cuisine that features tagliata di tonno con cipolla in agrodolce (tuna with sweet and sour onion). Reckon on from 
€35 per person for a full meal without wine.
More traditional in style is Ristorantino da Spano (20), Piazza Sant'Anna al Capo (00 39 348 562 8789; 
ristorantinospano.it ; closed Monday), a family-run trattoria in the tourist-free area behind the cathedral. Try the 
fettuccine alla tarantina (€6) with mussels and tomatoes.
                     Day two                   
                     Sunday morning: Go to church                   
One of Palermo's finest churches is the graceful Chiesa di San Francesco d'Assisi (21) (open 6.45am-noon and 4-
6.30pm daily) on pint-sized Piazza San Francesco d'Assisi. It sports a solemn Gothic with striking rose window and 
dramatic main portal. Inside, there's the sumptuous Cappella dell'Immacolata right of the altar. Sunday Mass is at 
7.30am, 10am, noon and 5.30pm.
                     Out to brunch                   
Just over the piazza, Antica Focacceria di San Francesco (22), Via Paternostro 58 (00 39 091 320 264; 
bit.ly/BrunchPal ), specialises in classic Sicilian snacks. Its signature dish is pani ca' meusa (€2.50), a roll filled with 
beef spleen served from a large steel cauldron. If that doesn't appeal, go for ricotta-filled cannoli (€2). It opens at 
midday, daily in summer, Wednesday to Monday at other times.
                     Cultural afternoon                   
Palermo's streets are almost deserted on Sunday afternoons so pay a visit to the Galleria d'Arte Moderna (23), Via 
Sant'Anna 21 (00 39 091 843 1605; galleriadartemodernapalermo.it ; open 9.30am to 6.30pm daily except Monday; 
€7 or €11 if there's an exhibition on), a lovely museum showcasing modern Sicilian art in a beautifully restored 15th-
century palazzo.
Another option is Teatro Massimo (1) (00 39 091 605 3262; teatromassimo.it ), Palermo's landmark opera house. 
Here you can take a guided tour (9am to 5pm daily except Monday; €8) or catch a matinee.
                     A walk in the park                   
Down by the seafront, Villa Giulia (24), Via Abramo Lincoln (open 8am to 8pm), is a historic 19th-century 
landscaped park with shady lanes and landscaped gardens.
48 Hours In: Palermo
Next door, there's the Botanical Garden (25), Via Abramo Lincoln 2b (00 39 091 238 91 236; ortobotanico.unipa.it ; 
open 9am to 7pm; €5) where fig trees and palms grow alongside cacti, coffee plants, papaya and bamboo.
                     The icing on the cake                   
South-west of Palermo, the Duomo di Monreale, Piazza Duomo, a sober Norman cathedral (open 8.30am to 
12.45pm and 2.30-5pm Monday to Saturday, 8-10am and 2.30-5pm Sunday; free) is one of Sicily's great 
masterpieces. It's decorated with sumptuous mosaics with gold designs on upper walls depicting biblical scenes. 
The adjacent cloisters (open 9am to 7pm Tues-Sat, until 1.30pm Sun and Mon; €6) are worth a look.
To get to Monreale take bus No 389 from Piazza Indipendenza (26). Buy tickets (€2.60 return) at the kiosk by the 
bus stop.
Click here to view Italian tours and Holidays, with Independent Holidays.
Load-Date: December 6, 2023
End of Document
I couldn't have had him at the start of the season but Pagaille is now my top pick ANTE-POST PRICEWISE
I couldn't have had him at the start of the season but Pagaille is now my top 
pick; ANTE-POST PRICEWISE
The Racing Post
December 6, 2023 Wednesday
Copyright 2023 Centurycomm Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: SPORT; Pg. 12,13
Length: 541 words
Body
NEARLY every horse entered in the Ladbrokes King George VI Chase at Kempton on Boxing Day has a question to 
answer and I wouldn't want to take a short price about anything at this stage.
A couple of weeks ago I wouldn't have been saying that because I thought last year's winner Bravemansgame 
made a perfectly satisfactory return in the Charlie Hall at Wetherby. However, he was downright disappointing at 
Haydock last time. He beat Royale Pagaille easily in the King George last year but was brushed aside by that rival 
in the Betfair Chase, so I really don't want to be backing him now at the same price he was when he won last year.
If Gerri Colombe and Allaho travel from Ireland, I'd expect Bravemansgame to be a bigger price than he is now, 
although I'm not entirely convinced by either of the Irish stars around Kempton.
Allaho did nothing to suggest he was anything like the force of old on his reappearance at Clonmel. It was a slowly 
run three-runner race and he just had to get round to win, which he did unimpressively. He's an amazing talent at 
his best but after his problems it's open to question whether he can get back to his previous level.
Gerri Colombe is a different kettle of fish because he seems destined for the top and did well to beat three Grade 1 
winners at Down Royal on his comeback. He's not slow by any means and I reckon he's going to be a tough nut to 
crack if he turns up, although it has to be said his form hasn't exactly worked out well and I doubt Kempton would 
be his ideal track.
He couldn't quite get past The Real Whacker at Cheltenham in March and, while the time of his Aintree win is solid, 
the form isn't and I think his reputation exceeds his achievements. That's not to say he can't or won't win the King 
George or the Cheltenham Gold Cup, just that he's priced up on what he might do.
Next there's Shishkin and it's anyone's guess what he's going to do these days. He has the talent to win, of course 
he does, but he didn't win the Ryanair in March when he should have, he gave up the ghost in the Champion Chase 
I couldn't have had him at the start of the season but Pagaille is now my top pick ANTE-POST PRICEWISE
the year before when a shortpriced favourite and, worst of all, he refused to race last time. He has a good record at 
Kempton and if his head's in the game he can win, but that has to be a huge doubt.
The Real Whacker has to bounce back from being pulled up in the Paddy Power and not many, if any, land the King 
George on the back of that sort of preparation, while
L'Homme Presse has been off since jumping badly right in the race last year.
Consequently, the only one to back at this stage has to be the Betfair Chase winner Royale Pagaille, who beat the 
King George joint-favourite easily there and was second in this race last year. That run came on the back of a poor 
preparation and Racing Post Ratings suggest his Haydock run was his best ever.
If that's the case it puts Royale Pagaille right in there with the best of these and he won't mind what the conditions 
are come Boxing Day. I wouldn't have dreamed of him winning the King George at the start of the season but, given 
the concerns about nearly all the others, I can't see him being out of the frame now.
ANTE-POST ADVICE Royale Pagaille Ladbrokes King George VI Chase (Kempton, December 26) 1pt each-way at 
14-1 with William Hill
Graphic
 
Royale Pagaille burst into the King George reckoning when lowering the colours of last year's winner 
Bravemansgame in the Betfair Chase at Haydock last month
JOHN GROSSICK (RACINGPOST.COM/PHOTOS)

Harrington sparkles as legends are honoured Deputy Ireland editor David Jennings reports from the HRI 
Awards night on Monday
Harrington sparkles as legends are honoured; Deputy Ireland editor David 
Jennings reports from the HRI Awards night on Monday
The Racing Post
December 6, 2023 Wednesday
Copyright 2023 Centurycomm Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: SPORT; Pg. 7
Length: 672 words
Body
ROBBIE POWER spoke of a fantastic horsewoman who was as tough as old boots, Barry Geraghty praised her 
positivity and ability to infuse confidence into those all around her, while Shane Foley hailed a fantastic woman who 
was fantastic to work for.
They were, of course, talking about the most successful female trainer in the history of the sport, who brought 
everyone to their feet as she made her way up to the stage at the Mansion House in Dublin to collect her 
contribution to the industry award.
As contributions go, they don't get much more generous than the donation made by Jessica Harrington. She has 
spent the last few decades smashing glass ceilings and, not only doing things that women had never done before, 
but most men too.
There was also talk of the "odd bollocking" from both past and present stable jockeys to which Harrington giggled: 
"Well, it didn't do them any harm, did it?"
This was a night of celebration in the Round Room of the Mansion House, where the Irish government used to sit 
and debate between 1919 and 1921. It's doubtful any of those debates were as intense as the one that Michael 
O'Leary and Davy Russell had over a cup of tea at Punchestown all those years ago and during a magnificent 
montage of the recently retired rider, there was certainty a hint of an admission from the Ryanair boss that he might 
have regretted getting rid of him back in 2014.
Russell became the latest recipient of the Irish racing hero award, adding his name to an illustrious roll of honour 
that includes the likes of Pat Smullen and Ruby Walsh.
Gordon Elliott hailed Russell one of the greatest of all time, before adding: "He brought a lot of owners into the 
place, but he also drove a lot out as well," which brought the loudest laugh of the whole night.
Harrington sparkles as legends are honoured Deputy Ireland editor David Jennings reports from the HRI 
Awards night on Monday
The Dungarvan trainer John Kiely is looking younger with every passing year and his first Cheltenham Festival 
winner at the age of 85 was recognised with the National Hunt achievement award.
JP McManus said of Kiely: "I can't think of anybody who deserves it more. He's very understated and an absolute 
pleasure to deal with."
It was A Dream To Share who opened Kiely's festival account in the Weatherbys Champion Bumper under 
teenager John Gleeson, who picked up the emerging talent award. That ride was described as "textbook" by Ruby 
Walsh, who presented him with the trophy. Rich praise from the greatest.
Amy Jo Hayes said she "couldn't talk" such was her shock as picking up ride of the year for her front-running 
masterclass on Redstone Well in a premier handicap at Leopardstown, but for somebody lost for words she 
somehow managed to have everyone in stitches. We need more Amy Jo Hayes in this world.
We nearly didn't have Wesley Joyce still in this world. There were more than a few moments when we thought we 
had lost him on that dark day at Galway during last year's summer festival when a horror fall from Red Heel left him 
fighting for his life. It was a battle he looked like losing for a long time.
"It's just great to be here," whispered Joyce, as he proudly held the Flat achievement award in his hand on the 
stage.
His main employer Johnny
Murtagh told us about a "loveable rogue" and by all accounts Joyce is the cheekiest of young chaps.
Paul Townend ended his awards hoodoo when he was a most deserving winner of the National Hunt award, while 
Barry O'Neill, a seven-in-a-row champion hailed by point aficionado Richard Pugh as someone he would love his 
kids to grow to be, won the point-topoint award.
The racecourse of the year was Ballinrobe. No argument here. Indeed, few could argue with any of the award 
winners. It has been some year for Irish racing.
HRI Awards winners Horse of the year Auguste Rodin Contribution to the industry Jessica Harrington Irish racing 
hero award Davy Russell Emerging talent John Gleeson National Hunt award Paul Townend National Hunt 
achievement John Kiely Point-to-point award Barry O'Neill Flat award Aidan O'Brien Flat achievement award 
Wesley Joyce Ride of the year Amy Jo Hayes Racecourse of the year Ballinrobe
Graphic
 
Jessica Harrington with her contribution to the industry award

World's biggest private jet dubbed 'Flying Mansion' with master suite and full bathroom
World's biggest private jet dubbed 'Flying Mansion' with master suite and 
full bathroom
Daily Star Online
December 6, 2023 Wednesday 9:31 PM GMT
Copyright 2023 Northern and Shell Media Publications All Rights Reserved
Length: 396 words
Byline: By, Lizzie McAllister
Highlight: This Boeing 747-8 is the world's biggest private jet and takes travelling in style to a whole new level – 
boasting gold-trimmed bedrooms and stunning bathrooms, it's a far cry from flying economy
Body
The world's biggest private jet has been dubbed the 'Flying Mansion' and has everything you need to start any 
luxury getaway in style.
If flying economy doesn't float your boat, this luxury Boeing 747-8 might be more up your street. It boasts multiple 
spacious living and dining rooms as well as multiple bedrooms, including a master suite.
This swanky boudoir has the utmost privacy as it sits right under the plane's nose and the cockpit, far from loud 
engines and the other bedrooms – making it a much better place to join the mile-high club than your favourite 
budget airline's toilet.
                                            For more of the latest news from the Daily Star, click here.                   
These closed-off living quarters feature a large bed in the middle of the room which is kitted out in high-quality 
materials for the ultimate night's sleep, reports The Sun.  It also has plenty of storage space, so don't worry about 
packing light.
The bedrooms also feature en-suite bathrooms covered in mirrors and decorated with wooden furnishings and gold 
trim. A golden staircase leads from the master bedroom up to the main living area, lined with colour-coordinated 
bookshelves, artwork on the walls and plush sofas to relax on a long-haul flight.
A separate living area also features three couches, perfect for unwinding over games or drinks after a long day of 
premium flying.
World's biggest private jet dubbed 'Flying Mansion' with master suite and full bathroom
While it boasts plenty of space, the plane doesn't scrimp on style. Materials like exotic wood can be found 
throughout and the entire vehicle is kitted out with touchscreen-controlled lights to make sure the mood is always 
set.
The Boeing 747-8 was first flown in November 2005. With a wingspan of 224ft, the enormous jet can hold up to 467 
passengers at a time – more than twice the capacity of a RyanAir plane.
Sound like your cup of tea Unfortunately – and unsurprisingly – the plane will set you back a fairly hefty sum. The 
jet is owned by real estate tycoon Joseph Lau, whose net worth is thought to be more than £10.3billion, according 
to simpleflying.com.

up for our newsletter by clicking                                                                      here                   
.                   
Load-Date: December 6, 2023
End of Document
Airport charges. CTI argues that the regulator should gain powers and ANA should lose them
Airport charges. CTI argues that the regulator should gain powers and ANA 
should lose them
CE Noticias Financieras English
December 6, 2023 Wednesday
Copyright 2023 Content Engine, LLC.
All Rights Reserved
Copyright 2023 CE Noticias Financieras All Rights Reserved
Length: 727 words
Body
The Independent Technical Commission (CTI) argues that the aviation regulator should have more powers to set 
airport charges. In practice, this means that ANA - Aeroportos de Portugal would lose power compared to the 
current status quo.
"One of the recommendations we are making is that the model for regulating charges should be more in the hands 
of the regulator than in the exclusive hands of the concessionaire," Raquel Carvalho, one of the CTI's seven 
members, said on Tuesday.
"This is a function of the regulator and introduces more transparency into this financing model," she added, during 
the event to present the CTI's conclusions for the location of Lisbon's new airport, which took place on Tuesday.
"The moment of renegotiation of a contract for airport expansion is perhaps the ideal moment for this issue to be 
regulated in a more up-to-date way in the concession contract, if it is maintained, or in any other [contract] that may 
be made, if that is the political option, which we don't know what it will be," added the professor at the Faculty of 
Law of the Portuguese Catholic University.
Currently, ANA - Aeroportos de Portugal presents its proposal and then the National Civil Aviation Authority (ANAC) 
decides whether to accept it or change the amount. At the moment, the regulator is evaluating the fees proposed by 
ANA for next year.
ANA intends to increase rates as follows in 2024: Lisbon (17%), Faro (12%), Porto (11%), Ponta Delgada (9%), 
Funchal (6%).
The proposal on the table has been widely criticized by the airline Ryanair, which announced in November that it 
will cancel one of its two planes in Madeira from January 2024 and reduce flights to Porto and Faro in the summer 
of next year.
The Independent Technical Commission (CTI) has concluded that Alcochete is the best location to host the new 
airport in the Lisbon region.
The group of independent experts believes that the Air Force's Alcochete Shooting Range is the most suitable 
location to replace Humberto Delgado airport.
CTI's choice as the "most advantageous solution for an intercontinental hub" was Humberto Delgado Airport + 
Alcochete Shooting Range.
However, when the Alcochete airport with two runways opens, Lisbon airport will close.
Airport charges. CTI argues that the regulator should gain powers and ANA should lose them
This option provides for two runways, with a capacity for 80 movements per hour and the possibility of expanding to 
four runways. 5,550 people exposed to noise. 40 kms from Lisbon, about 40 minutes. No railroad. Initially, it was 
planned to build a third crossing over the Tagus for a rail link. One of the advantages is that the land belongs to the 
state.
"The Alcochete Shooting Range is a public space and is closer to Lisbon. Vendas Novas involves expropriation," 
said CTI leader Maria do Rosário Partidário.
She recalled the process of building Lisbon's current airport in the 1940s. "There were two sites: Campo Grande 
and Portela. They thought Portela was the best solution, but it was too far from the city center. Distance is relative 
and changes over time."
Between December 6 and January 19, the public and institutional consultation period will take place on the 
Aeroparticipa.pt portal.
The Vendas Novas location was the second choice to build a new airport in the Lisbon region. The first is the 
Alcochete Shooting Range.
The "other viable solution" is for Humberto Delgado airport to remain open until Vendas Novas opens, with at least 
two runways.
The government announced on Tuesday that it will impose the "immediate execution" of works at Lisbon airport.
The announcement was made by António Costa: "the resolution of the council of ministers will impose on ANA the 
immediate execution of the works that are lacking".
These include the south pier, remodeling and expansion of Terminal One, among other obligations, said the Prime 
Minister in a speech during the presentation of the CTI's conclusions.
The aim is to improve flight sequencing and increase Lisbon airport's capacity, including "removing the Terminal 1 
apron from military use" so that the airport concession can be "fully used by civil aviation".
"The contract negotiating committee will be appointed, but we won't wait" for the decisions "for the works to be 
carried out", warned the Prime Minister.
"The Portuguese state will not leave for nowhere, nor will ANA," he said, predicting that the negotiation will be 
"lengthy" and that "nothing justifies further delay".
Load-Date: December 7, 2023
End of Document
Arrest made over 'fakes on a plane' scandal
Arrest made over 'fakes on a plane' scandal
 
Proactive Investors (UK)
December 6, 2023 Wednesday 03:33 PM EST
Copyright 2023 Proactive UK Ltd All Rights Reserved
Length: 316 words
Byline: William Farrington
Body
The Serious Fraud Office (SFO) has raided an address and arrested one individual as part of a criminal 
investigation into AOG Technics Ltd, the company accused of supplying unauthorised plane engine parts to major 
international carriers.
 AOG Technics was accused in September of a "deliberate, dishonest and sophisticated scheme" to supply 
unauthorised engine parts that ended up in Boeing aircraft.
Lawyers of jet engine maker CFM International told the High Court how AOG potentially sold thousands of engine 
components using forged paperwork, causing Virgin Australia (ASX:VAH), Southwest Airlines (NYSE:LUV) and 
United Airlines to ground some aircraft when the news came to light.
Ryanair Holdings PLC (LSE:RYA) was caught up in the scandal earlier this month after reporting the discovery of 
unauthorised aircraft components in two engines.
Barrister Matthew Reeve KC of Quadrant Chambers said there was "compelling documentary evidence that 
thousands of jet engine parts have been sold by (AOG) to airlines operating commercial aircraft fitted with the 
claimants' jet engines."
Little is known about AOG.
According to Companies House filings, the company has one director, Jose Alejandro Zamora Yrala, who is also 
listed as a director at Sunwave Solutions Ltd and Kensho Group, the former of which dissolved earlier this year.
Arrest made over 'fakes on a plane' scandal
AOG has taken down its website since the 'fakes on a plane' scandal came to light, while Zamora Yrala does not 
have an active LinkedIn profile.
Nick Ephgrave QPM, director of the Serious Fraud Office, said: "This investigation deals with very serious 
allegations of fraud involving the supply of aircraft parts, the consequences of which are potentially far reaching.
"The SFO is best placed to take this investigation forward vigorously and we are determined to establish the facts 
as swiftly as possible."
The SFO has not disclosed the name of the individual under arrest.
Load-Date: December 6, 2023
End of Document

Top Christmas gifts for travellers 2023
mirror.co.uk
December 6, 2023 Wednesday 8:39 AM GMT

UK arrest over fraudulent aircraft parts allegations
UK arrest over fraudulent aircraft parts allegations
Agence France Presse -- English
December 6, 2023 Wednesday 5:23 PM GMT
Copyright 2023 Agence France Presse All Rights Reserved
Length: 245 words
Dateline: London, Dec 6 2023
Body
Britain's Serious Fraud Office (SFO) on Wednesday raided an address and arrested one person as part of a probe 
into an aircraft parts supplier that serviced several major airlines.
Investigators are looking into UK-based AOG Technics Ltd, which has supplied parts for the world's best-selling 
passenger aircraft engine (CFM56) and most-used cargo aircraft engine (CF6) since 2015. 
The parts, which investigators believe may have been non-certified, were mostly sold to overseas companies that 
install airline parts, and to UK airlines, maintenance providers and parts suppliers, the SFO said in a statement.
Aviation authorities in the UK, Europe and the United States have issued alerts to businesses who may have 
bought or installed AOG's parts, resulting in some planes being grounded.   
"This investigation deals with very serious allegations of fraud involving the supply of aircraft parts, the 
consequences of which are potentially far reaching," said Nick Ephgrave, director of the SFO.
"The SFO is best placed to take this investigation forward vigorously and we are determined to establish the facts 
as swiftly as possible," he added.
CFM56 engines are used on the previous generation of the Airbus A320 and Boeing 737 aircraft.
Airlines affected include Ryanair, American Airlines, Delta Air Lines, United Airlines, Southwest Airlines and Virgin 
Australia Airlines.

Man arrested by fraud squad investigating fake aircraft parts scandal
Man arrested by fraud squad investigating fake aircraft parts scandal
telegraph.co.uk
December 6, 2023 Wednesday 7:56 PM GMT
Copyright 2023 Telegraph Media Group Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: BUSINESS; Version:1
Length: 422 words
Byline: By Matt Oliver
Highlight: Ryanair is among the companies sold engine components with false safety documents
Body
Fraud squad investigators investigating a company accused of supplying fake aeroplane parts  to airlines around 
the world have arrested a man. 
The man was being questioned on Wednesday after his home was searched by the Serious Fraud Office (SFO) 
and the National Crime Agency (NCA).
London-based AOG Technics has supplied parts to airlines  around the world, but has been accused of selling 
products using fake safety documents.
In some cases it has caused aircraft to be grounded, sending carriers and manufacturers scrambling to discover 
whether they are affected.
Ryanair is among those that have discovered fake parts and blamed the British company, while US carriers Delta 
Air Lines, American Airlines and Southwest Airlines have also discovered suspect components in their planes.
AOG Technics is also facing legal action by American manufacturer CFM International, after the company’s CFM56 
– the world’s best-selling jet engine – was said to have been affected.
The SFO said AOG had been supplying parts for the CFM56 and the CF6, the most-used cargo aircraft engine, 
since 2015.
CFM56 engines are used in Airbus SE A320 and Boeing 737 jets, among others, and some 22,000 are still in 
service globally.
Aviation regulators in the UK, US and Europe have issued alerts to businesses who may have bought AOG’s 
products, amid safety concerns.
Man arrested by fraud squad investigating fake aircraft parts scandal
The SFO is working alongside the UK Civil Aviation Authority  on the investigation.
Nick Ephgrave, the SFO’s director, said: “This investigation deals with very serious allegations of fraud involving the 
supply of aircraft parts, the consequences of which are potentially far reaching.
“The SFO is best placed to take this investigation forward vigorously and we are determined to establish the facts 
as swiftly as possible.”
As the scandal unfolded, Michael O’Leary, the boss of Ryanair , has called for greater scrutiny of third-party jet 
engine suppliers.
AOG could not be reached for comment on Wednesday.
Industry sources told Reuters that the parts in question were not considered critical, but nevertheless their presence 
makes it impossible to verify airworthiness.
Lawyers for CFM and its co-owners General Electric Safran have claimed that AOG used a “deliberate, dishonest 
and sophisticated scheme to deceive the market with falsified documents on an industrial scale”.
In filings to London’s High Court, they claimed to have documentary evidence that thousands of jet engine parts 
had been sold by the British company to airlines operating commercial aircraft fitted with CFM jet engines.
Load-Date: December 6, 2023
End of Document
Serious Fraud Office arrests company boss as it launches probe into jet engine scam
Serious Fraud Office arrests company boss as it launches probe into jet 
engine scam
MailOnline
December 6, 2023 Wednesday 7:51 PM GMT
Copyright 2023 Associated Newspapers Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: BUSINESS; Version:1
Length: 433 words
Byline: Jessica Clark
Body
The boss of a firm at the centre of a fake plane parts scandal has been arrested as part of a major criminal fraud 
probe.
Police arrested Jose Alejandro Zamora Yrala, director of aircraft parts supplier AOG Technics, at his London home 
yesterday morning.
The Serious Fraud Office (SFO) and National Crime Agency (NCA) launched an investigation into the business 
after bogus components were found in planes.
The company has been in business since 2015 and supplied parts for CF56, the world's best-selling passenger 
aircraft engine. 
But the firm is accused of providing fake authentication certificates, raising concerns over safety.
SFO director Nick Ephgrave said: 'This investigation deals with very serious allegations of fraud involving the supply 
of aircraft parts, the consequences of which are potentially far-reaching.'
He said the SFO would be 'vigorous' with its investigation and 'establish the facts as swiftly as possible'.
Ephgrave told Bloomberg: 'We are now going through front doors, making arrests and seizing properties.'
AOG Technics could not be contacted for comment.
Last week Ryanair became the latest airline to confirm dodgy parts had been found in two of its planes. 
Serious Fraud Office arrests company boss as it launches probe into jet engine scam
The discovery was made during maintenance checks carried out in Texas and Brazil in the past few months. The 
parts, which were found in two of Ryanair's Boeing planes, have been removed, the company said.
US carriers Delta Air Lines, American Airlines and Southwest Airlines have become caught up in the scandal which 
has resulted in planes being grounded. 
The SFO investigation is the first criminal action since regulators were alerted to fake parts found in Boeing and 
Airbus planes earlier this year. 
Aviation watchdogs traced the supplies back to AOG Technics, an obscure London-based firm. Regulators in the 
UK, US and Europe accused the company of supplying engine parts with faked certification documents.
The UK's Civil Aviation Authority announced in August that it was 'investigating the supply of a large number of 
suspect unapproved parts' that could be traced back to AOG Technics.
It issued a safety notice warning airlines that some of the parts were used in engines fitted in UK planes. Operators 
and owners were told to investigate their records for parts bought directly or indirectly from the firm.
The European Union Aviation Safety Agency also said in August that it was examining reports of parts with 
suspected falsified documents.
The US Federal Aviation Administration warned airlines about the scandal and Bloomberg has reported that the US 
Justice Department is in the early stages of a probe.
Load-Date: December 6, 2023
End of Document
Arrest over alleged fake plane parts scam
Arrest over alleged fake plane parts scam
Belfast Telegraph Online
December 6, 2023 Wednesday 3:15 PM GMT
Copyright 2023 Independent News & Media (Northern Ireland) All Rights Reserved
Length: 231 words
Byline: By Neil Lancefield, PA Transport Correspondent
Body
Fraud investigators have launched an investigation into a company suspected of supplying fake aircraft parts used 
by airlines across the world.
The Serious Fraud Office (SFO) said its investigators carried out a dawn raid at a site in London used by AOG 
Technics and arrested one person who remains in custody.
The UK’s Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) and its counterparts in the EU and the US issued alerts earlier this year 
warning aviation businesses about unapproved parts sold by the company.
AOG Technics mostly sold to overseas companies that install airline parts but some UK airlines were also affected, 
the SFO said.
It added that “some planes have been grounded in the UK and the US”.
In October, Tui confirmed that a component supplied by AOG Technics on one of its aircraft was “identified and 
quickly removed”.
Other affected airlines include Ryanair, American Airlines, Delta Air Lines, United Airlines, Southwest Airlines, TAP 
and Virgin Australia Airlines.
SFO director Nick Ephgrave said: “This investigation deals with very serious allegations of fraud involving the 
supply of aircraft parts, the consequences of which are potentially far-reaching.
“The SFO is best placed to take this investigation forward vigorously and we are determined to establish the facts 
as swiftly as possible.”
The SFO said it is working closely with the CAA and other regulators as part of the inquiry.
Arrest over alleged fake plane parts scam

Press Association Mediapoint

Fraud investigators have launched an investigation into a company suspected of supplying fake aircraft parts used 
by airlines across the world.
The Serious Fraud Office (SFO) said its investigators carried out a dawn raid at a site in London used by AOG 
Technics and arrested one person who remains in custody.
The UK's Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) and its counterparts in the EU and the US issued alerts earlier this year

December 6, 2023 Wednesday 5:53 PM BST
Copyright 2023 The Press Association Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: HOME NEWS
Length: 247 words
Byline: Neil Lancefield, PA Transport Correspondent
Body
Fraud investigators have launched an investigation into a company suspected of supplying fake aircraft parts used 
by airlines across the world.
The Serious Fraud Office (SFO) said its investigators carried out a dawn raid at a site in London used by AOG 
Technics and arrested one person who remains in custody.
The UK's Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) and its counterparts in the EU and the US issued alerts earlier this year 
warning aviation businesses about unapproved parts sold by the company.
AOG Technics mostly sold to overseas companies that install airline parts but some UK airlines were also affected, 
the SFO said.
It added that ``some planes have been grounded in the UK and the US''.
A spokesman for travel firm Tui confirmed an engine component supplied by AOG Technics on an aircraft the 
group's airlines were sent for leasing was ``identified and quickly removed'' before the plane entered service.
Other affected airlines include Ryanair, American Airlines, Delta Air Lines, United Airlines, Southwest Airlines, TAP 
and Virgin Australia Airlines.
SFO director Nick Ephgrave said: ``This investigation deals with very serious allegations of fraud involving the 
supply of aircraft parts, the consequences of which are potentially far-reaching.
``The SFO is best placed to take this investigation forward vigorously and we are determined to establish the facts 
as swiftly as possible.''
ARREST OVER ALLEGED FAKE PLANE PARTS SCAM
The SFO said it is working closely with the CAA and other regulators as part of the inquiry.

Southeast Asia Banks On Aviation Boom
Southeast Asia Banks On Aviation Boom
Newstex Blogs 
International Business Times News
December 6, 2023 Wednesday 4:00 AM EST
Copyright 2023 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 757 words
Byline: AFP News
Body
December 6th, 2023 ( International Business Times News  — Delivered by  Newstex )
Major airport expansion projects are taking off across Thailand, Cambodia and Vietnam, and a new airline is set to 
launch next year -- all banking on an expected boom in air travel in Southeast Asia, fuelled by Chinese and Indian 
tourists.
But there are doubts about whether it will materialise in an uncertain economic environment and as worries about 
the impact of travel on climate change.
Thailand's Really Cool Airlines is expected to start flying between Bangkok and Japan around mid-2024, but CEO 
Patee Sarasin -- a veteran of the region's cutthroat budget sector -- says it has been a battle to launch a new carrier 
just after a pandemic.
"It's a lot of money. It has been quite gruelling to raise the funds," he told AFP.
"There are some points (where you say) 'why am I doing this?' It crossed my mind many, many times."
Patee ran budget carrier Nok Air for more than a decade, but while he is coy about the finer details of the new 
venture, he claims it may yet "change the aviation paradigm".
Flying took a hammering globally during the pandemic as international travel all but shut down, but the industry is 
bullish about its bounceback, evidenced by a flurry of big-ticket orders at this month's Dubai Air Show and bumper 
profit jumps for the likes of Air France-KLM and Ryanair.
Southeast Asia is becoming a hot property, with private and public players competing for an expanding market.
The region currently accounts for 10 percent of global traffic -- more than 500 million passengers in 2019.
And Boeing expects this figure to grow around 9.5 percent a year over the next two decades, well above the global 
average of 6.1 percent.
Southeast Asia Banks On Aviation Boom
Across the region from Bangkok to Hanoi, governments are splashing billions of dollars to update and expand 
airport infrastructure.
A new terminal opened at Suvarnabhumi, Bangkok's main international airport, in September, and a third runway is 
being built.
There are plans for a third terminal at the city's other airport, Don Mueang, as well as a doubling of capacity at 
Chiang Mai in the north, and expansion in the major island tourism hub Phuket.
Cambodia has grand plans to make Phnom Penh's new $1.5 billion airport, expected in 2025, a regional hub to 
compete with Bangkok and Singapore, with about 50 million passengers by 2050.
Further evidence of the kingdom's ambitions came earlier this month with the opening of the new Chinese-funded 
$1.1 billion airport at Siem Reap, the gateway to the Angkor Wat temple complex, Cambodia's biggest tourist draw.
Built as part of Beijing's sprawling "Belt and Road" infrastructure scheme, the Siem Reap airport is designed to 
handle 12 million passengers a year by 2040 -- double the total number of foreign tourists who visited the country in 
2019.
Philip Kao, president of a Siem Reap tourism association, hailed the new airport as a "game changer" because its 
longer runway means it can handle bigger planes flying long-haul.
But while some are hoping for a tourism bounceback, others are grappling with the environmental impact of the 
construction boom.
Outside Ho Chi Minh City, work on what will be Vietnam's biggest airport, the $15 billion Long Thanh terminal, has 
blanketed nearby neighbourhoods in thick red dust.
Tourist numbers are not yet hitting pre-pandemic highs, and Mayur Patel, Asia Director for aviation data 
consultancy OAG said they are unlikely to do so before late 2024 or early 2025.
"It's fragmented from an economic perspective, but there is a coordinated effort to bring tourism back. Complexities 
will ease out in the years to come," he told AFP.
Thailand, where tourism accounts for around a fifth of gross domestic product, has stepped up measures in recent 
weeks to boost numbers by granting visas on arrival to visitors from China and India -- two huge reservoirs of 
customers.
Analysts expect growth to be powered by the growing Chinese and Indian middle classes -- as well as a younger 
generation more keen to travel than their parents.
But OAG warns the region's tourism has sometimes been over-reliant on China, and for now Chinese visitor 
numbers still way below pre-pandemic levels as the Asian superpower grapples with a challenging economic 
slowdown.
In Thailand's deep south, Betong International Airport stands as a monument to misguided expansion.
Opened in 2022 in a remote spot near the Malaysian border, the airport struggled for passengers, and now stands 
idle as airlines halted operations within a few months.
Link to the original story.
Notes
Southeast Asia Banks On Aviation Boom

Southeast Asia banks on aviation boom
Southeast Asia banks on aviation boom
Newstex Blogs 
Digital Journal
December 6, 2023 Wednesday 3:59 AM EST
Copyright 2023 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 772 words
Byline: AFP
Body
December 6th, 2023 ( Digital Journal  — Delivered by  Newstex )
Major airport expansion projects are taking off across Thailand, Cambodia and Vietnam, and a new airline is set to 
launch next year - all banking on an expected boom in air travel in Southeast Asia, fuelled by Chinese and Indian 
tourists.
But there are doubts about whether it will materialise in an uncertain economic environment and as worries about 
the impact of travel on climate change.
Thailand's Really Cool Airlines is expected to start flying between Bangkok and Japan around mid-2024, but CEO 
Patee Sarasin - a veteran of the region's cutthroat budget sector - says it has been a battle to launch a new carrier 
just after a pandemic.
"It's a lot of money. It has been quite gruelling to raise the funds," he told AFP.
"There are some points (where you say) 'why am I doing this?' It crossed my mind many, many times."
Patee ran budget carrier Nok Air for more than a decade, but while he is coy about the finer details of the new 
venture, he claims it may yet "change the aviation paradigm".
Flying took a hammering globally during the pandemic as international travel all but shut down, but the industry is 
bullish about its bounceback, evidenced by a flurry of big-ticket orders at this month's Dubai Air Show and bumper 
profit jumps for the likes of Air France-KLM and Ryanair.
– Airport boom –
Southeast Asia is becoming a hot property, with private and public players competing for an expanding market.
The region currently accounts for 10 percent of global traffic - more than 500 million passengers in 2019.
And Boeing expects this figure to grow around 9.5 percent a year over the next two decades, well above the global 
average of 6.1 percent.
Southeast Asia banks on aviation boom
Across the region from Bangkok to Hanoi, governments are splashing billions of dollars to update and expand 
airport infrastructure.
A new terminal opened at Suvarnabhumi, Bangkok's main international airport, in September, and a third runway is 
being built.
There are plans for a third terminal at the city's other airport, Don Mueang, as well as a doubling of capacity at 
Chiang Mai in the north, and expansion in the major island tourism hub Phuket.
Cambodia has grand plans to make Phnom Penh's new $1.5 billion airport, expected in 2025, a regional hub to 
compete with Bangkok and Singapore, with about 50 million passengers by 2050.
Further evidence of the kingdom's ambitions came earlier this month with the opening of the new Chinese-funded 
$1.1 billion airport at Siem Reap, the gateway to the Angkor Wat temple complex, Cambodia's biggest tourist draw.
Built as part of Beijing's sprawling "Belt and Road" infrastructure scheme, the Siem Reap airport is designed to 
handle 12 million passengers a year by 2040 - double the total number of foreign tourists who visited the country in 
2019.
Philip Kao, president of a Siem Reap tourism association, hailed the new airport as a "game changer" because its 
longer runway means it can handle bigger planes flying long-haul.
But while some are hoping for a tourism bounceback,others are grappling with the environmental impact of the 
construction boom.
Outside Ho Chi Minh City, work on what will be Vietnam's biggest airport, the $15 billion Long Thanh terminal, has 
blanketed nearby neighbourhoods in thick red dust.
– Turbulence ahead? –
Tourist numbers are not yet hitting pre-pandemic highs, and Mayur Patel, Asia Director for aviation data 
consultancy OAG said they are unlikely to do so before late 2024 or early 2025.
"It's fragmented from an economic perspective, but there is a coordinated effort to bring tourism back. Complexities 
will ease out in the years to come," he told AFP.
Thailand, where tourism accounts for around a fifth of gross domestic product, has stepped up measures in recent 
weeks to boost numbers by granting visas on arrival to visitors from China and India - two huge reservoirs of 
customers.
Analysts expect growth to be powered by the growing Chinese and Indian middle classes - as well as a younger 
generation more keen to travel than their parents.
But OAG warns the region's tourism has sometimes been over-reliant on China, and for now Chinese visitor 
numbers still way below pre-pandemic levels as the Asian superpower grapples with a challenging economic 
slowdown.
In Thailand's deep south, Betong International Airport stands as a monument to misguided expansion.
Opened in 2022 in a remote spot near the Malaysian border, the airport struggled for passengers, and now stands 
idle as airlines halted operations within a few months.

Southeast Asia banks on aviation boom
Southeast Asia banks on aviation boom
Agence France Presse -- English
December 6, 2023 Wednesday 4:33 AM GMT
Copyright 2023 Agence France Presse All Rights Reserved
Length: 775 words
Dateline: Bangkok, Dec 6 2023
Body
Major airport expansion projects are taking off across Thailand, Cambodia and Vietnam, and a new airline is set to 
launch next year -- all banking on an expected boom in air travel in Southeast Asia, fuelled by Chinese and Indian 
tourists.
But there are doubts about whether it will materialise in an uncertain economic environment and as worries about 
the impact of travel on climate change deepen. 
Thailand's Really Cool Airlines is expected to start flying between Bangkok and Japan around mid-2024, but CEO 
Patee Sarasin -- a veteran of the region's cutthroat budget sector -- says it has been a battle to launch a new carrier 
just after a pandemic.
"It's a lot of money. It has been quite gruelling to raise the funds," he told AFP.
"There are some points (where you say) 'why am I doing this?' It crossed my mind many, many times."
Patee ran budget carrier Nok Air for more than a decade, but while he is coy about the finer details of the new 
venture, he claims it may yet "change the aviation paradigm".
He added: "Southeast Asia is going to be probably one of the centres of the universe in the future, with the 
slowdown in Europe, and in the US."
Flying took a hammering globally during the pandemic as international travel all but shut down, but the industry is 
bullish about its bounceback, evidenced by a flurry of big-ticket orders at this month's Dubai Air Show and bumper 
profit jumps for the likes of Air France-KLM and Ryanair.
- Airport boom - 
Southeast Asia is becoming a hot property, with private and public players competing for an expanding market.
Southeast Asia banks on aviation boom
The region currently accounts for 10 percent of global traffic -- more than 500 million passengers in 2019. 
And Boeing expects this figure to grow around 9.5 percent a year over the next two decades, well above the global 
average of 6.1 percent.
Across the region from Bangkok to Hanoi, governments are splashing billions of dollars to update and expand 
airport infrastructure.
A new terminal opened at Suvarnabhumi, Bangkok's main international airport, in September, and a third runway is 
being built.
There are plans for a third terminal at the city's other airport, Don Mueang, as well as a doubling of capacity at 
Chiang Mai in the north, and expansion in the major island tourism hub Phuket.
Cambodia has grand plans to make Phnom Penh's new $1.5 billion airport, expected in 2025, a regional hub to 
compete with Bangkok and Singapore, with about 50 million passengers by 2050.
Further evidence of the kingdom's ambitions came earlier this month with the opening of the new Chinese-funded 
$1.1 billion airport at Siem Reap, the gateway to the Angkor Wat temple complex, Cambodia's biggest tourist draw.
Built as part of Beijing's sprawling "Belt and Road" infrastructure scheme, the Siem Reap airport is designed to 
handle 12 million passengers a year by 2040 -- double the total number of foreign tourists who visited the country in 
2019.
Philip Kao, president of a Siem Reap tourism association, hailed the new airport as a "game changer" because its 
longer runway means it can handle bigger planes flying long-haul.
But while some are hoping for a tourism bounceback, others are grappling with the environmental impact of the 
construction boom.
Outside Ho Chi Minh City, work on what will be Vietnam's biggest airport, the $15 billion Long Thanh terminal, has 
blanketed nearby neighbourhoods in thick red dust.
- Turbulence ahead? - 
Tourist numbers are not yet hitting pre-pandemic highs, and Mayur Patel, Asia Director for aviation data 
consultancy OAG said they are unlikely to do so before late 2024 or early 2025.
"It's fragmented from an economic perspective, but there is a coordinated effort to bring tourism back. Complexities 
will ease out in the years to come," he told AFP.
Thailand, where tourism accounts for around a fifth of gross domestic product, has stepped up measures in recent 
weeks to boost numbers by granting visas on arrival to visitors from China and India -- two huge reservoirs of 
customers.
Analysts expect growth to be powered by the growing Chinese and Indian middle classes -- as well as a younger 
generation more keen to travel than their parents.
But OAG warns the region's tourism has sometimes been over-reliant on China, and for now Chinese visitor 
numbers are still way below pre-pandemic levels as the Asian superpower grapples with a challenging economic 
slowdown.
In Thailand's deep south, Betong International Airport stands as a monument to misguided expansion.
Opened in 2022 in a remote spot near the Malaysian border, the airport struggled for passengers, and now stands 
idle as airlines halted operations within a few months. 
Southeast Asia banks on aviation boom
ah-ss-tak/pdw/dan
BOEING

Southeast Asia banks on aviation boom
Southeast Asia banks on aviation boom
 
Philippines Daily Inquirer
December 6, 2023 Wednesday
Copyright 2023 Philippines Daily Inquirer All Rights Reserved
Length: 767 words
Body
 Major airport expansion projects are taking off across Thailand, Cambodia and Vietnam, and a new airline is set to 
launch next year - all banking on an expected boom in air travel in Southeast Asia, fueled by Chinese and Indian 
tourists.
But there are doubts about whether it will materialize in an uncertain economic environment and as worries about 
the impact of travel on climate change deepen.
Thailand's Really Cool Airlines is expected to start flying between Bangkok and Japan around mid-2024, but CEO 
Patee Sarasin - a veteran of the region's cutthroat budget sector - says it has been a battle to launch a new carrier 
just after a pandemic.
'It's a lot of money. It has been quite grueling to raise the funds,' he told .
'There are some points (where you say) 'why am I doing this?' It crossed my mind many, many times.'
Patee ran budget carrier Nok Air for more than a decade, but while he is coy about the finer details of the new 
venture, he claims it may yet 'change the aviation paradigm'.
He added: 'Southeast Asia is going to be probably one of the centers of the universe in the future, with the 
slowdown in Europe, and in the US.'
Flying took a hammering globally during the pandemic as international travel all but shut down, but the industry is 
bullish about its bounceback, evidenced by a flurry of big-ticket orders at this month's Dubai Air Show and bumper 
profit jumps for the likes of Air France-KLM and Ryanair.

Southeast Asia is becoming a hot property, with private and public players competing for an expanding market.
The region currently accounts for 10 percent of global traffic - more than 500 million passengers in 2019.
Southeast Asia banks on aviation boom
And Boeing expects this figure to grow around 9.5 percent a year over the next two decades, well above the global 
average of 6.1 percent.
Across the region from Bangkok to Hanoi, governments are splashing billions of dollars to update and expand 
airport infrastructure.
A new terminal opened at Suvarnabhumi, Bangkok's main international airport, in September, and a third runway is 
being built.
There are plans for a third terminal at the city's other airport, Don Mueang, as well as a doubling of capacity at 
Chiang Mai in the north, and expansion in the major island tourism hub Phuket.
Cambodia has grand plans to make Phnom Penh's new $1.5 billion airport, expected in 2025, a regional hub to 
compete with Bangkok and Singapore, with about 50 million passengers by 2050.
Further evidence of the kingdom's ambitions came earlier this month with the opening of the new Chinese-funded 
$1.1 billion airport at Siem Reap, the gateway to the Angkor Wat temple complex, Cambodia's biggest tourist draw.

longer runway means it can handle bigger planes flying long-haul.
But while some are hoping for a tourism bounceback, others are grappling with the environmental impact of the 
construction boom.
Outside Ho Chi Minh City, work on what will be Vietnam's biggest airport, the $15 billion Long Thanh terminal, has 
blanketed nearby neighborhoods in thick red dust.

consultancy OAG said they are unlikely to do so before late 2024 or early 2025.

will ease out in the years to come,' he told .
Thailand, where tourism accounts for around a fifth of gross domestic product, has stepped up measures in recent 
weeks to boost numbers by granting visas on arrival to visitors from China and India - two huge reservoirs of 
customers.
Analysts expect growth to be powered by the growing Chinese and Indian middle classes - as well as a younger 
generation more keen to travel than their parents.
But OAG warns the region's tourism has sometimes been over-reliant on China, and for now Chinese visitor 
numbers are still way below pre-pandemic levels as the Asian superpower grapples with a challenging economic 
slowdown.

Opened in 2022 in a remote spot near the Malaysian border, the airport struggled for passengers, and now stands 
idle as airlines halted operations within a few months.

Arrest over alleged fake plane parts scam
Arrest over alleged fake plane parts scam
standard.co.uk
December 6, 2023 Wednesday 3:13 PM GMT
Copyright 2023 Evening Standard Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: BUSINESS NEWS,BUSINESS; Version:2
Length: 259 words
Byline: Neil Lancefield
Highlight: The Serious Fraud Office (SFO) said its investigators carried out a dawn raid at a site in London used by 
AOG Technics.
Body
Fraud investigators have launched an investigation into a company suspected of supplying fake aircraft parts used 
by airlines across the world.
The Serious Fraud Office  (SFO) said its investigators carried out a dawn raid at a site in London  used by AOG 
Technics and arrested one person who remains in custody.
The UK’s Civil Aviation Authority  (CAA) and its counterparts in the EU and the US issued alerts earlier this year 
warning aviation businesses about unapproved parts sold by the company.
This investigation deals with very serious allegations
Nick Ephgrave, SFO
AOG Technics mostly sold to overseas companies that install airline parts but some UK airlines were also affected, 
the SFO said.
It added that “some planes have been grounded in the UK and the US”.
A spokesman for travel firm Tui confirmed an engine component supplied by AOG Technics on an aircraft the 
group’s airlines were sent for leasing was “identified and quickly removed” before the plane entered service.
Other affected airlines include Ryanair, American Airlines, Delta Air Lines, United Airlines, Southwest Airlines , TAP 
and Virgin Australia Airlines.
Arrest over alleged fake plane parts scam
SFO director Nick Ephgrave said: “This investigation deals with very serious allegations of fraud involving the 
supply of aircraft parts, the consequences of which are potentially far-reaching.
“The SFO is best placed to take this investigation forward vigorously and we are determined to establish the facts 
as swiftly as possible.”
The SFO said it is working closely with the CAA  and other regulators as part of the inquiry.
Load-Date: December 6, 2023
End of Document

AIB Group (A5G: EUR4.34) in 4th consecutive rise
AIB Group PLC's (I: A5G EUR4.34) stock price extended its gains on Tuesday, rising an additional 1.0c (0.2%) to 
close at EUR4.34. AIB Group PLC is Ireland's largest Bank by market cap. The stock lifted 1.2% on Friday and 
0.7% on Monday. This brought its 4-day rise to 4.6%, compared with the ISEQ Overall Index which rose 187.3 
points (2.3%) in the four days for a relative price increase of 2.3%. Cumulative volume in the 4 days was 1.1 times 
the average 4-day volume of 4.3 million shares. There were 2,250,000 shares worth EUR9.8 million ($10.6 million) 
traded today.
+  AIB Group (A5G: EUR4.34) Market Cap $13 billion, Bank sector, PV$1000 (5 yr): $1,206

stocks. Bank of Ireland is Ireland's 2nd largest Bank by market cap. Past 12 months DPS: 21.0c; Last price: 
EUR8.65; Dividend yield: 2.4%;

relative price increase was 0.1%. Dalata Hotel Group PLC- ESM is Ireland's largest Hotels/Restaurants/Casinos 
company by market cap. There were 474,090 shares worth EUR2 million ($2.2 million) traded today. The volume 
was 0.9 times the average daily trading volume of 515,812 shares.

Kenmare Resources (KMR: EUR4.82) increases on rising relative strength

high of EUR4.82 and its seven-day low of EUR4.68 today. There were 1,920 shares worth EUR9,254 ($10,016)

Arrest over alleged fake plane parts scam
Arrest over alleged fake plane parts scam
The Independent (United Kingdom)
December 6, 2023 Wednesday 3:13 PM GMT
Copyright 2023 Independent Digital News and Media Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: BUSINESS; Version:2
Length: 259 words
Byline: Neil Lancefield
Highlight: The Serious Fraud Office (SFO) said its investigators carried out a dawn raid at a site in London used by 
AOG Technics.
Body
Fraud investigators have launched an investigation into a company suspected of supplying fake aircraft parts used 
by airlines across the world.
The Serious Fraud Office  (SFO) said its investigators carried out a dawn raid at a site in London  used by AOG 
Technics and arrested one person who remains in custody.
The UK’s Civil Aviation Authority  (CAA) and its counterparts in the EU and the US issued alerts earlier this year 
warning aviation businesses about unapproved parts sold by the company.
This investigation deals with very serious allegations
Nick Ephgrave, SFO
AOG Technics mostly sold to overseas companies that install airline parts but some UK airlines were also affected, 
the SFO said.
It added that “some planes have been grounded in the UK and the US”.
A spokesman for travel firm Tui  confirmed an engine component supplied by AOG Technics on an aircraft the 
group’s airlines were sent for leasing was “identified and quickly removed” before the plane entered service.
Other affected airlines include Ryanair, American Airlines, Delta Air Lines, United Airlines, Southwest Airlines, TAP 
and Virgin Australia Airlines.
SFO director Nick Ephgrave said: “This investigation deals with very serious allegations of fraud involving the 
supply of aircraft parts, the consequences of which are potentially far-reaching.
Arrest over alleged fake plane parts scam
“The SFO is best placed to take this investigation forward vigorously and we are determined to establish the facts 
as swiftly as possible.”
The SFO said it is working closely with the CAA  and other regulators as part of the inquiry.
Load-Date: December 6, 2023
End of Document
Man arrested after London firm accused of supplying fake engine parts to airlines
Man arrested after London firm accused of supplying fake engine parts to 
airlines
standard.co.uk
December 6, 2023 Wednesday 5:08 PM GMT
Copyright 2023 Evening Standard Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: UK,NEWS; Version:1
Length: 267 words
Byline: Daniel Keane
Highlight: Firm sold to overseas companies that install airline parts but some UK airlines were also impacted
Body
A man has been arrested after a London  firm was accused of supplying fake aircraft parts used by airlines across 
the world. 
The Serious Fraud Office (SFO) said its investigators carried out a dawn raid at a site in London used by AOG 
Technics and arrested one person who remains in custody.
The firm mostly sold to overseas companies that install airline parts but some UK airlines were also impacted, the 
SFO said in a statement. 
It added that “some planes have been grounded in the UK and the US”.
AOG Technics has been accused of supplying falsely documented parts for use in the world's most-sold passenger 
jet engine, the CFM56.
CFM56 engines power the previous generation of Boeing  737s and about half the previous generation of Airbus 
A320s.
Earlier this year, the UK's Civil Aviation Authority  (CAA) and its counterparts in the EU and the US issued alerts 
warning businesses about unapproved parts sold by AOG Technics. 
Affected airlines include Tui, Ryanair , American Airlines , Delta Air Lines, United Airlines, Southwest Airlines, TAP 
and Virgin Australia Airlines.
Man arrested after London firm accused of supplying fake engine parts to airlines
SFO director Nick Ephgrave said: “This investigation deals with very serious allegations of fraud involving the 
supply of aircraft parts, the consequences of which are potentially far-reaching.
“The SFO is best placed to take this investigation forward vigorously and we are determined to establish the facts 
as swiftly as possible.”
The agency said it is working closely with the CAA and other regulators as part of the inquiry.
The suspected forgery came to light after reports made by a Portuguese maintenance company in June.
Load-Date: December 6, 2023
