Explainer: Is there a new fee for Ryanair customers? What we know about boarding pass confusion
Explainer: Is there a new fee for Ryanair customers? What we know about 
boarding pass confusion
Belfast Telegraph Online
December 5, 2023 Tuesday 11:20 AM GMT
Copyright 2023 Independent News & Media (Northern Ireland) All Rights Reserved
Length: 1236 words
Byline: Simon Calder
Body
Confusion reigns about a possible change of practice by Europe’s biggest budget airline, Ryanair, requiring some 
passengers either to queue for a paper boarding pass at the airport or pay for seat selection. Travellers have 
accused the carrier of imposing a money-making policy ahead of the Christmas rush.
An airline spokesperson said: “There is no new procedure in force.”
But some travellers have said that they were informed the standard option to show a mobile boarding pass on their 
smart phone was not open to them.
The issue is still far from clear. But these are the key questions and answers about Ryanair check-in and boarding 
policies as we understand them so far.
                     What’s the background to Ryanair’s check-in requirements?                   
In 2008, Ryanair became the first airline anywhere in the world to ask passengers to check in online before 
reaching the airport. The aim was to cut costs: drastically reducing the number of travellers who had to see a check-
in agent at a desk, and commensurately allowing Ryanair to pay less for space at the departure airport.
The option of checking in at the airport has remained available – but at a high cost. The fee started at £10, but 
within a year increased to £40. It is now £55 for each passenger on a booking.
Initially the boarding pass had to be printed out to avoid the charge. This was annoying and difficult for people on 
holiday abroad.
Soon, though, Ryanair aligned with other airlines that allow boarding passes to be carried on mobile phones and 
shown while going through the airport and at the departure gate.
Explainer: Is there a new fee for Ryanair customers? What we know about boarding pass confusion
                     Can I use mobile boarding passes everywhere?                   
No. Ryanair says: “We accept mobile boarding passes on flights from the majority of airports on our network. 
However unfortunately some airports cannot accept mobile boarding passes yet.”
These airports including Kefalonia in Greece, the Albanian capital, Tirana, and all airports in Morocco, Turkey, 
Israel and Lebanon.
Ryanair says: “Customers travelling from these airports must check in online and print out a paper boarding pass 
for their flight.”
                     Wasn’t there a controversy about airport check-in earlier this year?                   
Yes. In August, Ryanair was heavily criticised after charging two elderly passengers £110 at London Stansted 
airport, after the couple inadvertently checked in for their inbound rather than outbound flight to France.
At the time, a spokesperson for the airline said: “In accordance with Ryanair’s T&Cs, which these passengers 
agreed to at the time of booking, they failed to check-in online before arriving at Stansted airport (11 Aug) despite 
receiving an email reminder (10 Aug) to check in online. These passengers were correctly charged the airport 
check-in fee.”
                     How do travellers avoid charges for extras on Ryanair?                   
Simply by declining all invitations to pay for extra services, and complying with the rules on cabin baggage (carrying 
no more than one small item measuring no more than 40 x 20 x 25cm).
Consider the £15 one-way journey (correct at time of research) from Edinburgh to Shannon on 11 December. 
Options offered include:
                                            a 10kg checked bag for an extra £18                       priority boarding and an additional, 
larger piece of hand luggage for an extra £22                       fast-track security for £7                       selecting a seat 
in advance, a minimum of £8                                        
If all these extras were chosen, the fare would increase by £55 – to nearly five times the original price. Passengers, 
though, are able to opt out of all the extras.
                     What has happened now?                   
Some passengers who decline the option to book a specific seat in advance, and instead accept random seat 
allocation, say they have been told they cannot use an online boarding pass.
They say they were invited to choose between paying for a specific seat, at which point they could use their smart 
phone, or queue up for a paper boarding pass at a Ryanair desk.
One passenger, Andrew Brown, told The Independent: “Ryanair says that you can check in but if you want to avoid 
queuing for a free-of-charge printed boarding card at check in you should pay for a dedicated seat. Then you can 
have your boarding card on your phone as before.”
He speculated: “They’re trying to discourage people from selecting a free random seat. It was brought in without 
notice and there’s nothing on their website about the policy change.
“It puts an end to my practice of taking just hand baggage with no allocated seat and no extras, so just the fare.”
Another passenger, Neil Gregory, told the BBC : “The app said if I opted for a free random seat I’d have to go to 
check-in to get a paper boarding pass, which I’ve never seen before. If you wanted a digital boarding pass, it said 
you had to pay for a reserved seat.”
Explainer: Is there a new fee for Ryanair customers? What we know about boarding pass confusion
The BBC said a traveller was told by staff at the airport check-in desk that the new policy was only for the last 20 
passengers checking in for each flight.
On a “random seat assignment” booking for a flight from London Stansted to Italy for 5 December, The Independent 
experienced no difficulty checking in online as normal and getting a digital boarding pass on a smart phone.
                     What does Ryanair say?                   
The Belfast Telegraph has been trying to establish exactly what the airline’s policy is.
A spokesperson for the airline said: “There is no charge for a Ryanair digital boarding pass – ever. All Ryanair 
passengers can pay for a reserved seat if they so wish or if passengers wish to avoid this seat fee, they can select 
a randomly allocated seat entirely free of charge.”
The Belfast Telegraph then asked specifically, can passengers who don't choose a seat – and who therefore avoid 
the seat fee - also get their digital boarding pass for free on their phone?
So far there has been no response to this question.
                     What could be going on?                   
Some background: Ryanair has been conducting a campaign to try to persuade passengers not to buy tickets for its 
flights through online travel agents (OTAs). One aspect of this involves requiring some passengers who do book 
through an OTA to go through a series of verification checks before being allowed to check in.
Travellers are told: “Your booking is blocked because it looks like it was booked through an online travel agent who 
has no commercial relationship with us to sell our flights.
“Online travel agents often do not provide us with your correct email address and payment details, so we need to 
verify your identity. We also need to carry out this process in order to ensure we can comply with safety and 
security requirements.”
This very process comes at a cost to Ryanair – as would requiring some passengers to go to a desk at the airport
One theory is that the airline has a new policy of asking some passengers who opt not to select a seat to queue up 
for a paper boarding pass, in a bid to increase the proportion choosing and paying for a specific seat.
Passenger Andrew Brown said: “I’m a regular and think Ryanair is great. But this is a stealth charge.”
The Independent has seen nothing to substantiate the assertions.
The airline spokesperson said: “There is no charge for a Ryanair digital boarding pass – ever.”
Load-Date: December 5, 2023
End of Document
Do you now have to pay to check-in for your Ryanair flight?
Do you now have to pay to check-in for your Ryanair flight?
The Independent (United Kingdom)
December 5, 2023 Tuesday 10:01 AM GMT
Copyright 2023 Independent Digital News and Media Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS & ADVICE,TRAVEL; Version:1
Length: 1200 words
Byline: Simon Calder
Highlight: Airline rejects accusations of imposing money-making scheme ahead of Christmas rush
Body
Confusion reigns about a possible change of practice by Europe’s biggest budget airline, Ryanair , requiring some 
passengers either to queue for a paper boarding pass at the airport or pay for seat selection. Travellers have 
accused the carrier of imposing a money-making policy ahead of the Christmas rush.
An airline spokesperson said: “There is no new procedure in force.”
But some travellers have told The Independent that they were informed the standard option to show a mobile 
boarding pass on their smart phone was not open to them.
The issue is still far from clear. But these are the key questions and answers about Ryanair check-in and boarding 
policies as we understand them so far.
                     What’s the background to Ryanair’s check-in requirements?                   
In 2008, Ryanair became the first airline anywhere in the world to ask passengers to check in online before 
reaching the airport. The aim was to cut costs: drastically reducing the number of travellers who had to see a check-
in agent at a desk, and commensurately allowing Ryanair to pay less for space at the departure airport.
The option of checking in at the airport has remained available – but at a high cost. The fee started at £10, but 
within a year increased to £40.  It is now £55 for each passenger on a booking.
Initially the boarding pass had to be printed out to avoid the charge. This was annoying and difficult for people on 
holiday abroad.
Soon, though, Ryanair aligned with other airlines that allow boarding passes to be carried on mobile phones and 
shown while going through the airport and at the departure gate.
Do you now have to pay to check-in for your Ryanair flight?
                     Can I use mobile boarding passes everywhere?                   
No. Ryanair says: “We accept mobile boarding passes on flights from the majority of airports on our network. 
However unfortunately some airports cannot accept mobile boarding passes yet.”
These airports including Kefalonia in Greece, the Albanian capital, Tirana, and all airports in Morocco, Turkey, 
Israel and Lebanon.
Ryanair says: “Customers travelling from these airports must check in online and print out a paper boarding pass 
for their flight.”
                     Wasn’t there a controversy about airport check-in earlier this year?                   
Yes. In August, Ryanair was heavily criticised after charging two elderly passengers £110 at London Stansted 
airport , after the couple inadvertently checked in for their inbound rather than outbound flight to France.
At the time, a spokesperson for the airline said: “In accordance with Ryanair’s T&Cs, which these passengers 
agreed to at the time of booking, they failed to check-in online before arriving at Stansted airport (11 Aug) despite 
receiving an email reminder (10 Aug) to check in online. These passengers were correctly charged the airport 
check-in fee.”
                     How do travellers avoid charges for extras on Ryanair?                   
Simply by declining all invitations to pay for extra services, and complying with the rules on cabin baggage (carrying 
no more than one small item measuring no more than 40 x 20 x 25cm).
Consider the £15 one-way journey (correct at time of research) from Edinburgh to Shannon on 11 December. 
Options offered include:
If all these extras were chosen, the fare would increase by £55 – to nearly five times the original price. Passengers, 
though, are able to opt out of all the extras.
                     What has happened now?                   
Some passengers who decline the option to book a specific seat in advance, and instead accept random seat 
allocation, say they have been told they cannot use an online boarding pass.
They say they were invited to choose between paying for a specific seat, at which point they could use their smart 
phone, or queue up for a paper boarding pass at a Ryanair desk.
One passenger, Andrew Brown, told The Independent: “Ryanair says that you can check in but if you want to avoid 
queuing for a free-of-charge printed boarding card at check in you should pay for a dedicated seat. Then you can 
have your boarding card on your phone as before.”
He speculated: “They’re trying to discourage people from selecting a free random seat. It was brought in without 
notice and there’s nothing on their website about the policy change.
“It puts an end to my practice of taking just hand baggage with no allocated seat and no extras, so just the fare.”
Another passenger, Neil Gregory, told the BBC : “The app said if I opted for a free random seat I’d have to go to 
check-in to get a paper boarding pass, which I’ve never seen before. If you wanted a digital boarding pass, it said 
you had to pay for a reserved seat.”
The BBC said a traveller was told by staff at the airport check-in desk that the new policy was only for the last 20 
passengers checking in for each flight.
Do you now have to pay to check-in for your Ryanair flight?
On a “random seat assignment” booking for a flight from London Stansted to Italy for 5 December, The Independent 
experienced no difficulty checking in online as normal and getting a digital boarding pass on a smart phone.
                     What does Ryanair say?                   
                     The Independent has been trying to establish exactly what the airline’s policy is.
A spokesperson for the airline said: “All Ryanair passengers can pay for a reserved seat if they so wish or if 
passengers wish to avoid this seat fee, they can select a randomly allocated seat entirely free of charge.”
All of this is true, but it does not explain the current issue.
                     The Independent has asked specifically: “I am a regular Ryanair passenger. I always accept random 
seat allocation. With the exception of certain airports (eg in Morocco) can I always check in using only a boarding 
pass on my mobile?”
So far there has been no response to this question. 
                     What could be going on?                   
Some background: Ryanair has been conducting a campaign to try to persuade passengers not to buy tickets for its 
flights through online travel agents (OTAs). One aspect of this involves requiring some passengers who do book 
through an OTA to go through a series of verification checks before being allowed to check in.
Travellers are told: “Your booking is blocked because it looks like it was booked through an online travel agent who 
has no commercial relationship with us to sell our flights.
“Online travel agents often do not provide us with your correct email address and payment details, so we need to 
verify your identity. We also need to carry out this process in order to ensure we can comply with safety and 
security requirements.”
This very process comes at a cost to Ryanair – as would requiring some passengers to go to a desk at the airport 
One theory is that the airline has a new policy of asking some passengers who opt not to select a seat to queue up 
for a paper boarding pass, in a bid to increase the proportion choosing and paying for a specific seat.
Passenger Andrew Brown said: “I’m a regular and think Ryanair is great. But this is a stealth charge.”
                     The Independent has seen nothing to substantiate the assertions.
The airline spokesperson said: “There is no charge for a Ryanair digital boarding pass – ever.”

Ryanair denies new boarding pass charge
Ryanair denies new boarding pass charge
Belfast Telegraph
December 5, 2023 Tuesday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2023 Belfast Telegraph Newspapers Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 14
Length: 203 words
Byline: Eimear McGovern
Body
RYANAIR has denied claims it is charging a new fee for e-boarding passes.
The BBC said some people on social media claimed they'd been charged up to £21 - or alternatively had to queue 
for a paper pass at the airport.
Ryanair said: "There is no charge for a Ryanair digital boarding pass - ever.
"All Ryanair passengers can pay for a reserved seat if they so wish, or if passengers wish to avoid this seat fee, 
they can select a randomly allocated seat entirely free of charge."
One passenger contacted the airline on X, saying: "When and why did you start this carry on? I now have to 
QUEUE to collect my boarding pass at the airport?"
Another said: "So what's this forcing people to buy seats after purchasing a flight or queue for a boarding pass all 
about? I thought the option to take a random seat was to avoid extra queues? Another cash gathering exercise?"
The claims suggest Ryanair is asking some passengers to book a seat for between £7 and £21 before they can 
download their boarding pass.
If they do not book a seat, they have to queue for a pass at the airport.
Over the years budget airlines have introduced charges for addons such as putting luggage in the hold, booking 
seats or choosing a seat with extra legroom.
Ryanair denies new boarding pass charge

Ryanair issues travel warning for ‘disruption’
Ryanair issues travel warning for ‘disruption’
Express Online
December 5, 2023 Tuesday 8:21 AM GMT
Copyright 2023 Northern and Shell Media Publications All Rights Reserved
Length: 277 words
Byline: Esther Marshall
Body
Ryanair has issued a travel warning for "disruption" 
Ryanair has issued a travel warning for “potential disruption” on flights to and from the UK due to cold weather.
A spokesperson said: “Potential disruptions to and from the United Kingdom due to freezing weather conditions.
“Affected passengers will be notified and any passengers travelling to and from the UK on Tuesday December 5 
should check their Ryanair app for the latest updates on their flight.
“We regret any inconvenience caused to passengers by these weather conditions which are outside of Ryanair’s 
control and affects all airlines operating to and from the UK on December 5.”
Passengers are advised to check the Ryanair app before travelling to the airport as cold weather could impact 
flights.
Cold weather hit the UK with areas such as Cumbria hit with snow 
The Met Office warns that there will be a “few wintry showers in the north and the northeast” with “some freezing 
fog forming by dawn”.
It said: “Remaining rather cloudy in the south and southeast, but clearer elsewhere. Light winds for all and turning 
cold with a frost and some freezing fog forming by dawn.”
On Wednesday the frost and fog is expected to clear with bright spells to follow. The weather is expected to be 
milder from Thursday to Saturday.
easyJet has also issued a warning for British travellers as they could face difficulties travelling to the airport due to 
strikes.
Ryanair issues travel warning for ‘disruption’
Train strikes are expected to impact lines across the UK this week up until December 8. Tourists could face knock-
on delays over the weekend.
British tourists should plan their journey before setting off at the airport to make sure their route isn't impacted.
Load-Date: December 5, 2023
End of Document
On The Beach ‘to pursue’ Ryanair after refunds win
On The Beach ‘to pursue’ Ryanair after refunds win
standard.co.uk
December 5, 2023 Tuesday 10:56 AM GMT
Copyright 2023 Evening Standard Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: BUSINESS; Version:1
Length: 253 words
Byline: Daniel O'Boyle
Highlight: On The Beach was awarded £2 million in October after it said it had to refund customers’ flights as 
Ryanair did not do so
Body
Online travel agent On The Beach says it will continue to “pursue Ryanair  for further sums”, after winning a £2 
million court case over refunds  for flights  cancelled by the low-cost airline.
On The Beach was awarded £2 million in October after it said it had to refund customers ’ flights as Ryanair did not 
do so.
“This common-sense outcome should not have taken a protracted and expensive legal process to resolve,” it said.
The travel agent said it had been forced to pay more refunds since the case began, and it was now trying to chase 
claims for these.
Ryanair itself took legal action against On The Beach in 2010 over an intellectual property dispute, but the case has 
still not progressed to court. On the Beach says “final resolution of the dispute might take some time”.
Ryanair did not respond to a request for comment.
The travel agent also revealed its profits increased sixfold to £12.9 million in the year to 30 September. The shares 
gained 17.6p, or 15%, to 135p.
CEO Shaun Morton said: “"I am pleased with the Group's incredibly strong performance this year.
This year we have seen the majority of consumers protect -not sacrifice -their holiday , a trend that our research 
shows will continue.
On The Beach ‘to pursue’ Ryanair after refunds win
“ We are already seeing this with strong momentum into the new financial year with TTV up 26% for the first nine 
weeks of FY24 and Winter FY23 bookings up 34%.
"We approach our key booking period in Q2 with significant momentum and this gives us confidence that Summer 
'24 will be significantly ahead of Summer '23."
Load-Date: December 5, 2023
End of Document
Ryanair : Pay to pick seat or queue up
Ryanair: Pay to pick seat or queue up
The Times (London)
December 5, 2023 Tuesday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2023 Times Newspapers Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 10
Length: 240 words
Byline: Ben Clatworthy
Body
Ryanair has been accused of making a "scandalous" change to its check-in policy in a move that will affect millions 
of passengers.
Only passengers who pay for a reserved seat are now allowed to download a mobile boarding pass or print one at 
home.
Those who refuse to pay for a seat - allowing it to be allocated at random - now have to queue at the airport check-
in desks to be issued with a pass. Charges for a reserved seat range from £4.50-£15.50 per flight.
Passengers have complained of being made to stand in "30-metre" queues to be issued with a boarding pass 
before they can go on to clear security.
One passenger wrote on Twitter/X: "I just can't believe your new policy of not allowing passengers to create a 
boarding pass (mobile or printout) unless they buy a seat, forcing them to join a check-in queue (30m or longer) to 
do so for no other reason for you to make a few quid. Scandalous."
Some passengers said that the new policy meant passengers now have to pay for a mobile boarding pass, 
although the airline denied this.
Ryanair said: "There is no charge for a Ryanair digital boarding pass - ever. All Ryanair passengers can pay for a 
reserved seat if they so wish or if passengers wish to avoid this seat fee, they can select a randomly allocated seat 
entirely free of charge."
Ministers have vowed to crack down on so-called "drip pricing", advertising one price upfront and revealing other 
charges later in the buying process.
Ryanair : Pay to pick seat or queue up
Load-Date: December 5, 2023
End of Document

CTK's Business News in Brief
CTK's Business News in Brief
CTK Business News Wire
December 5, 2023 Tuesday 8:42 PM (Central European Time)
Copyright 2023 Czech News Agency (CTK) All Rights Reserved
Length: 614 words
Body
CTK's Business News in Brief
Ryanair to fly regularly from Pardubice to Girona
-----------------------------------------------------------
Pardubice, East Bohemia - Irish carrier Ryanair will operate a regular biweekly service from Pardubice to Girona in 
Catalonia, Spain, from April 2024, the Pardubice airport has said in a press release.
"I believe that the new connection to this attractive destination will be successful from both directions and will 
increase tourism in the Pardubice Region," said Ivan Cech, head of the East Bohemian Airport company, which 
operates the Pardubice airport. Ryanair already flies from Pardubice to Alicante in Spain. This year, the line is 
estimated to carry over 22,000 passengers. In 2017-2019, Ryanair also operated a service from Pardubice to 
London, which it cancelled.
Ostrava airport to add regular flights to Malaga from spring
-----------------------------------------
Mosnov, North Moravia - The international Leos Janacek Ostrava Airport will offer a new regular service to Malaga, 
Spain, from spring, to be operated by Ryanair every Monday and Thursday, airport operator Letiste Ostrava told 
CTK in a press release today.
The airport is expecting a significant expansion of operations in 2024, said airport head Jaromir Radkovsky. In 
addition to the new service to Malaga, Ryanair will also increase the number of flights to London-Stansted from two 
per week to three per week starting from the end of March.
Panasonic starts building heat pump production facility in Plzen
----------------------------------
Plzen, West Bohemia - Japanese corporation Panasonic has started building a new, significantly larger heat pump 
production facility in Plzen at a cost of Kc7.6bn, Panasonic Heating & Ventilation Air-Conditioning Czech CEO 
Hiroshi Komatsubara said at today's launch of the construction.
CTK's Business News in Brief
Plzen will become the European headquarters for production, research and development. The new plant is due to 
open in May 2025 and will produce up to one million heat pumps a year by 2030, with the products to be exported 
to the whole of Europe, Komatsubara said. Panasonic has been operating in Plzen since 1996, when it started 
producing televisions there as the first Japanese investor in the Czech Republic. Panasonic started producing 
pumps in Plzen in 2018, but the production ran in parallel with the production of televisions. Last year, the 
production of televisions ended and now the company is focusing exclusively on heat pumps, Komatsubara said.
Kralupy refinery to have heat recovery unit worth over Kc500m
-----------------------------
Kralupy nad Vltavou, Central Bohemia - The Orlen Unipetrol group will build a heat recovery unit to recover flue gas 
heat at its production plant in Kralupy nad Vltavou at a cost exceeding Kc500m, the group's spokesman Pavel Kaidl 
said in a press release today.
The unit is expected to be completed in mid-2025, according to the press release. The group expects that the unit 
will reduce the refinery's emissions by as much as 15 kilotons per year. The Orlen Unipetrol group is the largest 
refining and petrochemical company in the Czech Republic.
Ceske drahy to raise wages by 2.3 pct from January
-------------------------------
Prague - Czech national rail operator Ceske drahy has signed a collective agreement with the trade unions for next 
year, agreeing on a 2.3 percent increase in wages and the retention of existing benefits such as working hours, 
holidays and various forms of contributions, Ceske drahy said in a press release today.
Ceske drahy employees should also receive an extraordinary bonus of Kc12,000, according to the press release. In 
2022, the carrier employed 21,875 people.
tam,hel/er
Load-Date: December 5, 2023
End of Document
Three new routes a boost for city airport
Three new routes a boost for city airport
Eastern Daily Press
December 5, 2023
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2023 NLA Media Access Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 7
Length: 313 words
Byline: EDWARD DEWULF-PETERS
Body
Ryanair will fly three new routes out of Norwich Airport to desirable Mediterranean destinations from next spring, it 
has been revealed.
The budget airline will run flights to Malta, Alicante and Faro on Mondays and Fridays from April 1, as well as a host 
of return journeys.
Aviation analyst Sean Moulton shared the news with his 16,600 followers on X, along with detailed flight times and 
numbers.
Tickets are not yet on sale but have been loaded onto Ryanair's online system ahead of the new year, screenshots 
show, which Mr Moulton said he expects to be available for purchase "soon".
Norwich Airport currently operates flights to 18 destinations in nine countries, with connections to 150 more 
locations via Amsterdam.
Journeys to Malta and Spanish port city Alicante have been previously available with KLM and the now-defunct 
Flybe, but services were cancelled shortly before the Covid pandemic.
Portuguese destination Faro, however, is a new location for the city airport, which will be provided by a 6.40pm to 
9.40pm outbound or 3.15pm to 6.15pm inbound flight.
Norwich Airport has been contacted for comment and is understood to be close to confirming its first association 
with Ryanair, which flies regularly from Stansted.
Three new routes a boost for city airport
Vicky Samwell-Buckenham, manager at Norwich-based agency Oyster Travel, said the routes would only be good 
news for the region.
"People will be over the moon to hear they can fly to these destinations from Norwich Airport again," she said.
"Our customers always love to fly from Norwich and will be happy to continue to support the airport going forward.
She added: "It will be a happy return for those who remember being able to fly to Malta or Malaga with Flybe in the 
past."
Tui is currently Norwich Airport's biggest operator by destination with nine routes in total, but has regularly attracted 
criticism in recent years for delays and cancellations.
Graphic
 
Three new Ryanair routes have been announced for Norwich Airport
Load-Date: December 5, 2023
End of Document
New Mediterranean destinations set to launch from Norwich Airport
New Mediterranean destinations set to launch from Norwich Airport
Evening News (Norwich)
December 5, 2023
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2023 NLA Media Access Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 4
Length: 313 words
Byline: EDWARD DEWULF-PETERS
Body
Ryanair will fly three new routes out of Norwich Airport to desirable Mediterranean destinations from next spring, it 
has been revealed. The budget airline will run flights to Malta, Alicante and Faro on Mondays and Fridays from April 
1, as well as a host of return journeys.
Aviation analyst Sean Moulton shared the news with his 16,600 followers on X, along with detailed flight times and 
numbers.
Tickets are not yet on sale but have been loaded onto Ryanair's online system ahead of the new year, screenshots 
show, which Mr Moulton said he expects to be available for purchase "soon".
Norwich Airport currently operates flights to 18 destinations in nine countries, with connections to 150 more 
locations via Amsterdam.
Journeys to Malta and Spanish port city Alicante have been previously available with KLM and the now-defunct 
Flybe, but services were cancelled shortly before the Covid pandemic.
Portuguese destination Faro, however, is a new location for the city airport, which will be provided by a 6.40pm to 
9.40pm outbound or 3.15pm to 6.15pm inbound flight.
Norwich Airport has been contacted for comment and is understood to be close to confirming its first association 
with Ryanair, which flies regularly from Stansted.
Vicky Samwell- Buckenham, manager at
Norwich-based agency Oyster Travel, said the routes would only be good news for the region.
New Mediterranean destinations set to launch from Norwich Airport
"People will be over the moon to hear they can fly to these destinations from Norwich Airport again," she said.
"Our customers always love to fly from Norwich and will be happy to continue to support the airport going forward.
She added: "It will be a happy return for those who remember being able to fly to Malta or Malaga with Flybe in the 
past."
Tui is currently Norwich Airport's biggest operator by destination with nine routes in total, but has regularly attracted 
criticism in recent years for delays and cancellations.

Ryanair will fly to THREE new Mediterranean destinations from Norwich Airport
Ryanair will fly to THREE new Mediterranean destinations from Norwich 
Airport
Evening News (Norwich)
December 5, 2023 Tuesday
Copyright 2023 NewsQuest Media Group Limited All Rights Reserved
Length: 375 words
Byline: Edward Dewulf-Peters
Body
Ryanair will fly three new routes out of Norwich Airport to desirable Mediterranean destinations from next spring, it 
has been revealed.
The budget airline will run flights to Malta, Alicante and Faro on Mondays and Fridays from April 1, as well as a host 
of return journeys.
Aviation analyst Sean Moulton shared the news with his 16,600 followers on X, along with detailed flight times and 
numbers.
Tickets are not yet on sale but have been loaded onto Ryanair's online system ahead of the new year, screenshots 
show, which Mr Moulton said he expects to be available for purchase "soon".
READ MORE: New chairman announced as Norwich Theatre heads 'into next chapter'
Norwich Airport currently operates flights to 18 destinations in nine countries, with connections to 150 more 
locations via Amsterdam.
Journeys to Malta and Spanish port city Alicante have been previously available with KLM and the now-defunct 
Flybe, but services were cancelled shortly before the Covid pandemic.
Portuguese destination Faro, however, is a new location for the city airport, which will be provided by a 6.40pm to 
9.40pm outbound or 3.15pm to 6.15pm inbound flight.
Norwich Airport has been contacted for comment and is understood to be close to confirming its first association 
with Ryanair, which flies regularly from Stansted.
Ryanair will fly to THREE new Mediterranean destinations from Norwich Airport
READ MORE: First look at 'exciting' new salon in one of city's most historic hotels
Vicky Samwell-Buckenham, manager at Norwich-based agency Oyster Travel, said the routes would only be good 
news for the region.
"People will be over the moon to hear they can fly to these destinations from Norwich Airport again," she said.
"Our customers always love to fly from Norwich and will be happy to continue to support the airport going forward.
READ MORE: TUI passengers delayed at Norwich Airport for 10 HOURS with 'no announcements'
She added: "It will be a happy return for those who remember being able to fly to Malta or Malaga with Flybe in the 
past."
Tui is currently Norwich Airport's biggest operator by destination with nine routes in total, but has regularly attracted 
criticism in recent years for delays and cancellations.
The operator announced in September that it would be running a second weekly flight to Tenerife, between October 
and April.
Load-Date: December 5, 2023
End of Document
‘Scandalous’ Ryanair change will affect millions of passengers
‘Scandalous’ Ryanair change will affect millions of passengers
thetimes.co.uk
December 5, 2023 Tuesday 12:00 AM GMT
Copyright 2023 News International Ltd All Rights Reserved
Length: 497 words
Byline: Ben Clatworthy, Transport Correspondent
Highlight: Only travellers who pay for a reserved seat can download a mobile boarding pass or print one at home, 
it is claimed
Body
Ryanair has been accused of making a “scandalous” change to its check-in policy, in a move that will affect millions 
of passengers.
The Irish airline quietly implemented the change, which only allows passengers who pay for a reserved seat to 
download a mobile boarding pass or print one at home.
Those who refuse to pay for a seat — allowing it to be allocated at random — now have to queue at the airport 
check-in desks to be issued with a pass. Charges for a reserved seat range from £4.50-£15.50 per flight. 
The move has enraged passengers who complained of being made to stand in “30-metre” queues to be issued with 
a boarding pass. Only then can they clear security.
One passenger wrote on X/Twitter: “I just can’t believe your new policy of not allowing passengers to create a 
boarding pass (mobile or printout) unless they buy a seat, forcing them to join a check-in queue (30m or longer) to 
do so for no other reason for you to make a few quid. Scandalous.”
The move makes it even harder to board a flight having only paid the headline fare. Previously passengers willing to 
travel with only a small under-seat cabin bag and be randomly allocated a seat at check-in could fly for the 
advertised fare.
Anyone wanting to carry a bigger bag on board, book a seat or check-in luggage would have to pay extra.
Passengers who have been issued a boarding pass but lost it, or do not have a phone, are already charged £20 by 
Ryanair
 to have it printed at the airport. If a passenger fails to check-in at home, they must pay £55 at the airport.
‘Scandalous’ Ryanair change will affect millions of passengers
‘BA charged us an extra £158 to sit together in business class’
Some passengers said that the new policy meant passengers now have to pay for a mobile boarding pass, 
although the airline strongly denied this.
However, a spokeswoman stopped replying to The Times when asked about the policy of not issuing mobile passes 
to passengers without a reserved seat.
The statement said: “There is no charge for a Ryanair digital boarding pass — ever. All Ryanair passengers can 
pay for a reserved seat if they so wish or if passengers wish to avoid this seat fee, they can select a randomly 
allocated seat entirely free of charge.”
Ministers have vowed to crack down on so-called “drip pricing”. It announced a new consumers’ bill at the King’s 
Speech, granting “new powers to enable growing consumer harms to be tackled”.
Drip pricing is the practice whereby businesses only advertise part of a product’s price upfront and reveal other 
charges later in the buying process.
It would ban airlines from charging extra for luggage, seat selection, travel insurance or food and drink vouchers at 
the point of purchase. The practice is most common in the aviation, retail, entertainment and communication 
sectors.
It has become particularly prevalent in the airline industry. The government’s impact assessment of the practice 
found that the median charge for luggage, the most regularly selected product, is £65 — a 54 per cent increase on 
the headline ticket price.
Load-Date: December 5, 2023
End of Document

SECTION 3  STOCKS HITTING CONSECUTIVE HIGHS
Ryanair Holdings (RY4B: EUR18.04) hits year-high 7th time in one month
Ryanair Holdings PLC's (I: RY4B EUR18.04) stock price hit a 52-week high of EUR18.22 during the day. In the past 
month the stock has hit a new 52-week high seven times, pointing to a significant uptrend.
Ryanair Holdings' stock price increased 4.0c (0.2%) from its previous trading session to close at EUR18.04.
Compared with the ISEQ Overall Index which fell 34.8 points (0.4%) in the day, the relative price increase was 
0.6%.
Ryanair Holdings PLC is Ireland's largest Airline company by market cap.
SECTION 4  TODAY'S BULLISH SIGNALS4.1  PAST WEEK: MODERATE MOMENTUM UPRY4B adds 5.3% on 
average volume 0.995 times average. Compared with the ISEQ Overall Index which rose 250.9 points (or 3.1%) in 
the week, the relative price increase was 2.2%.
Ryanair Holdings (RY4B) outperformed the ISEQ Overall Index in 4 out of 5 days. The price ranged between a high 
of EUR18.04 on Monday Dec 04 and a low of EUR17.45 on Tuesday Nov 28.
4.2  Uptrend
The stock traded at a thirty one-month high of EUR18.22 today.Price/Moving Average Price of 1.08 and positive 
MACD:- The Price/MAP 200 for Ryanair Holdings is 1.08. Being higher than 1 is a bullish indicator. It is higher than 
the Price/MAP 200 for the ISEQ Overall Index of 0.99, a second bullish indicator. The 200-day MAP has increased 
to EUR16.78, a third bullish indicator.- The Moving Average Convergence Divergence (MACD) indicator of 12-day 
Exponential Moving Average (EMA) of 17.46 minus the 26-day EMA of 16.92 is positive, suggesting a bullish signal. 
Both the 12-day EMA as well as the 26-day EMA are rising, another bullish signal.- The price to 50-day EMAP ratio 
is 1.1, a bullish indicator. The 50-day EMAP has increased to EUR16.47. An increase is another bullish indicator.
Past Month:- Rises to Falls: In the past month the number of rises outnumbered falls 13:5 or 2.6:1.
In the last three months the stock has hit a new 52-week high seven times, pointing to a significant uptrend. The 
Best 3 weeks in the past quarterIn the past quarter the week beginning Monday November 06 saw the highest

MARKET Tuesday December 05, 2023 06:12 GMT
weekly rise of 10.1% for a relative price increase of 13.1%. The rise was propped up by volume of 1.9 times 
average.

Capitalisation at 11.4%.
SECTION 5  ONGOING BULLISH PARAMETERS5.1  The Best Periods [3 Mo, 1 Yr] with Price Change % > 11.51-
Year price change of 37.7% for Ryanair Holdings outperformed the change of 15.6% in the ISEQ Overall Index for a 
relative price change of 22.1%.
5.2  Annualised Period-based Total Shareholder Returns [TSR %]: The Best Periods with TSR > 9%
5.3  Low Debt to Equity (%) and ReducingThe debt to equity ratio of 24.6% is under a safe benchmark figure of 
50%. Moreover, it has improved from 41.1% a year ago.
5.4  Increased VWAP, up 41% in 5 yearsIn the past five years Volume Weighted Average Price (VWAP) has 
increased by 40.6% to EUR15.45.
5.5  Increased share turnoverIn the past five years, average daily share turnover has increased 2.0% to EUR26 
million ($28.3 million). This suggests increased liquidity.
5.6  Satisfies one criterion of Benjamin Graham-"Total debt less than tangible book value"; total debt of EUR1.4 
billion (US$1.5 billion) is less than tangible book value of EUR5.3 billion (US$6 billion).-"Total debt equal or less 
than twice the net quick liquidation value"; total debt of EUR1.4 billion (US$1.5 billion) is 0.3 times the net 
liquidation value of EUR4.11 billion (US$4.7 billion).
SECTION 6  TODAY'S BEARISH SIGNALS6.1  Overbought/Bearish Signals:
- The Relative Strength Index (RSI) of 70.2 has penetrated the overbought line of 70, suggesting the price gain of 
3.6% in the last 14 days is unusually high.- The stock is overbought according to the Williams % R indicator of -
15.7, suggesting the price is close to its 14-day high of EUR18.22.- The Stochastic indicator of 91.9 has broken 
through the overbought line of 80; this indicates the price is close to its 14-day high and is likely to revert to a 
downtrend.
SECTION 7  ONGOING BEARISH PARAMETERS7.1  Stock vs Index (Annual Percentage Change)
Over 5 years Ryanair Holdings is up a total 13.6% at an annualized rate of 3.2% compared to the Index being up 
29.7% at an annualized rate of 6.7%.
Ryanair Holdings has outperformed the ISEQ Overall Index in 2 of the past 5years: 2020, 2019.
7.2  Annualised Period-based Total Shareholder Returns [TSR %]: The Worst Period with TSR < 4.6%
7.3  Declining Volume, down 24% in 5 yearsIn the past five years, Average Daily Volume of Trading (ADVT) has 
decreased 24.2% to 1.8 million shares.
7.4  Satisfies 3 out of 9 criteria of Joseph Piotroski [pass mark 5]:- Positive operating cashflow.- Good quality of 
earnings [operating cashflow exceeds net income].- Improvement in asset turnover [growth in revenue of 193.5% 
exceeded growth in assets of 22.9%].
But does not meet the following 6 criteria of Joseph Piotroski:- Positive net income.- Return on Assets 
improvement.- Improvement in long-term debt to total assets.- Improvement in current ratio.- Total shares on issue 
unchanged (or reduction in total shares on issue).- Improvement in gross margin.

Holdings Shares on that day. Those 72.7 Shares would be worth EUR1,312 at today's Share price of EUR18.04. At 
today's exchange rate of USD1=0.92 EUR this is equivalent to USD1,427. PV$1000= $1,427.

Ryanair axed 960 flights due to Gaza conflict
Ryanair axed 960 flights due to Gaza conflict
Western Daily Press
December 5, 2023 Tuesday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2023 Reach PLC All Rights Reserved
Section: BUSINESS; Pg. 15
Length: 264 words
Body
LOW-COST airline Ryanair has said more than 960 flights were cancelled last month due to the war between Israel 
and Hamas.
It comes after the Irish carrier cancelled over 870 flights in October as a result of the conflict in Gaza.
Airlines have suspended flights to Tel Aviv and neighbouring Jordan after Hamas militants launched an attack on 
Israel on October 7 and due to the subsequent escalation of the war.
Rival EASYJET said last week that conflict and the threat to stability across the Middle East has also affected 
demand for flights in destiminority nations such as Egypt, while it saw bookings impacted across the board in 
October and November due to the war.
EasyJet warned that it does not expect to narrow losses in the first quarter of its new financial year as flights and 
wider demand are affected, but it said booking appetite had started to recover in recent weeks.
Ryanair's latest passenger statistics showed it operated over 66,400 flights in November, with a 4% increase in 
people flown, at 11.7 million, despite the cancellations.
London-listed Hungarian airline Wizz Air said yesterday that it has decided to suspend operations in Israel until 
early next month.
The budget airline said it "continues to monitor the situation on the ground closely, and stands ready to redeploy 
capacity should conditions stabilise".
It carried 29.3% more passengers in November, at 4.8 million.
Wizz Air said it had also restarted inbound flights to Chisinau, Moldova, in Eastern Europe having suspended flights 
to the country in March due to tensions linked to Russia's war with Ukraine.
Ryanair axed 960 flights due to Gaza conflict
Graphic
 
>>Ryanair is one of many airlines to have axed flights because of conflict Dan Kitwood/Getty Images

End of Document

days. The price ranged between a high of $121.46 on Monday Dec 04 and a low of $117.55 on Tuesday Nov 
28.[Volume Index (VI); 1 is average]
1.2 Other Bullish SignalsMCap/Total Assets:- Tobin's Q Ratio, defined as MCap divided by Total Assets, is 1.7. 
Compared with the rest of the market the ADR is undervalued.
SECTION 2 ONGOING BULLISH PARAMETERS2.1 Satisfies one criterion of Benjamin Graham-"Total debt less 
than tangible book value"; total debt of EUR1.4 billion (US$1.5 billion) is less than tangible book value of EUR5.3 
billion (US$6 billion).-"Total debt equal or less than twice the net quick liquidation value"; total debt of EUR1.4 billion 
(US$1.5 billion) is 0.3 times the net liquidation value of EUR4.11 billion (US$4.7 billion).

0.4.
3.2 Overbought/Bearish Signals:- The Relative Strength Index (RSI) of 99.0 has penetrated the overbought line of 
70, suggesting the price gain of 9.6% in the last 14 days is unusually high. - The ADR is overbought according to 
the Williams % R indicator of -2.4, suggesting the price is close to its 14-day high of $121.78.
SECTION 4 ONGOING BEARISH PARAMETERS4.1 Satisfies 3 out of 9 criteria of Joseph Piotroski [pass mark 5]:- 
Positive operating cashflow.- Good quality of earnings [operating cashflow exceeds net income].- Improvement in 
asset turnover [growth in revenue of 193.5% exceeded growth in assets of 22.9%].
But does not meet the following 6 criteria of Joseph Piotroski:- Positive net income.- Return on Assets 
improvement.- Improvement in long-term debt to total assets.- Improvement in current ratio.- Total shares on issue 
unchanged (or reduction in total shares on issue).- Improvement in gross margin.

Ryanair flight from UK to Morocco makes emergency landing in Portugal after pilot falls ill
Ryanair flight from UK to Morocco makes emergency landing in Portugal 
after pilot falls ill
MailOnline
December 5, 2023 Tuesday 2:14 PM GMT
Copyright 2023 Associated Newspapers Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Version:3
Length: 288 words
Byline: Natalia Penza
Body
•
Pilot told passengers before landing he wasn't feeling well, according to a report
A Ryanair plane had to make an emergency landing in Portugal after the pilot fell ill.
The aircraft was heading from the UK to Morocco but ended up landing at Faro Airport on the Portuguese Algarve 
this morning, according to local reports.
The pilot had told passengers before landing that he wasn't feeling well and the diversion triggered a 'red alert' at 
the airport, according to Portuguese daily Correio da Manha.
A spokesperson from Ryanair said: 'There was no "emergency landing".
'This flight from Stansted to Morocco (5 Dec) diverted to Faro when one of the pilots became ill. 
'The aircraft landed normally, and passengers were transferred to an alternative aircraft operated by another crew 
before continuing to Morocco.'
In April a packed easyJet plane heading to Agadir in Morocco from London Gatwick had to divert to Faro.
Local reports at the time said the flight diversion was the result of the pilot suffering an 'indisposition', and led to an 
identical red alert being activated before the Airbus A320 was landed safely.
EasyJet said in a comment at the time: 'easyJet can confirm that flight EZY6469 from London Gatwick to Agadir on 
21 April diverted to Faro due to the First Officer requiring medical assistance.
'The Captain performed a routine landing in accordance with standard operating procedures and the aircraft was 
met by medical services on arrival in Faro.
Ryanair flight from UK to Morocco makes emergency landing in Portugal after pilot falls ill
'A replacement crew was arranged and passengers have since continued their journey to Agadir. We apologise for 
any inconvenience experienced due to the diversion and resulting delay.
'The safety and well-being of its passengers and crew is easyJet's highest priority.'
Load-Date: December 5, 2023
End of Document

Flights axed due to Gaza war
Flights axed due to Gaza war
The Press and Journal
December 5, 2023 Tuesday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2023 Aberdeen Journals Ltd All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 20
Length: 273 words
Byline: HOLLY WILLIAMS
Body
Low-cost airline Ryanair has said more than 960 flights were cancelled last month due to the war between Israel 
and Hamas.
It comes after the Irish carrier cancelled over 870 flights in October as a result of the conflict in Gaza.
Airlines have suspended flights to Tel Aviv and neighbouring Jordan after Hamas militants launched an attack on 
Israel on October 7 and due to the subsequent escalation of the war.
Rival easyJet said last week that conflict and the threat to stability across the Middle East has also affected demand 
for flights in destinations such as Egypt, while it saw bookings impacted across the board in October and November 
due to the war.
EasyJet warned it does not expect to narrow losses in the first quarter of its new financial year as flights and wider 
demand are affected, but it said booking appetite had started to recover in recent weeks.
Ryanair's latest passenger statistics showed it operated over 66,400 flights in November, with a 4% increase in 
people flown, at 11.7 million, despite the cancellations.
London-listed Hungarian airline Wizz Air said yesterday it has decided to suspend operations in Israel until early 
January next year.
The budget airline said it "continues to monitor the situation closely, and stands ready to redeploy capacity should 
conditions stabilise".
Wizz Air said it had also restarted inbound flights to Chisinau, Moldova, in Eastern
Flights axed due to Gaza war
Europe having suspended flights to the country in March due to tensions linked to Russia's war with Ukraine.
It said the move follows a "comprehensive evaluation of safety factors", adding that the group "intends to gradually 
reintroduce operations".

American Banking and Market News

Copyright 2023 American Banking and Market News All Rights Reserved

Body
Ryanair logo Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY  - Get Free Report ) was upgraded by research analysts at 
StockNews.com  from a "hold" rating to a "buy" rating in a report issued on Tuesday. 
•
Is Ryanair Overbought? Earnings Say Not Likely  
Separately, TheStreet raised shares of Ryanair from a "c" rating to a "b" rating in a report on Friday. Seven equities 
research analysts have rated the stock with a buy rating and one  has given a strong buy rating to the company. 
Based on data from MarketBeat.com, Ryanair  has an average rating of "Buy" and a consensus price target of 
$59.00. 
View Our Latest Stock Report on Ryanair Ryanair Stock Down 0.5 %
•
Can Ryanair Stock Fly Above Resistance Levels, What Earnings Show 
RYAAY stock  traded down $0.63 during midday trading on Tuesday, reaching $120.83. 847,155 shares of the 
company's stock traded hands, compared to its average volume of 444,413. The company has a market cap of 
$27.52 billion, a price-to-earnings ratio of 11.45, a P/E/G ratio of 0.81 and a beta of 1.53. The firm's fifty day moving 
average price is $102.20 and its 200-day moving average price is $102.98. The company has a quick ratio of 1.19, 
a current ratio of 1.19 and a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.31. Ryanair has a 52 week low of $73.50 and a 52 week high 
of $121.78.  
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY  - Get Free Report ) last posted its earnings results on Monday, November 6th. The 
transportation company reported $7.21 earnings per share (EPS) for the quarter, topping the consensus estimate of 
$7.13 by $0.08. Ryanair had a net margin of 17.65% and a return on equity of 34.37%. The firm had revenue of 
$5.36 billion during the quarter, compared to analyst estimates of $5.14 billion.  As a group, sell-side analysts 
forecast that  Ryanair will post 8.87 earnings per share for the current fiscal year. Institutional Investors Weigh In 
On Ryanair

quarter. 43.66% of the stock is owned by hedge funds and other institutional investors. Ryanair Company Profile 
(Get Free Report ) 
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, Italy, Spain, and internationally. It is also involved in the provision of various ancillary services, 
such as non-flight scheduled and Internet-related services, as well as in-flight sale of beverages, food, duty-free, 
and merchandise; and markets car hire, travel insurance, and accommodation services through its website and 
mobile app.Featured Stories

Ryanair reveals 960 flights axed due to conflict in Gaza; Airlines have 
suspended flights to Tel Aviv and neighbouring Jordan amid tensions
Express and Star
December 5, 2023 Tuesday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2023 MNA All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 36
Length: 309 words
Byline: HOLLY WILLIAMS
Body
Low-cost airline Ryanair has said more than 960 flights were cancelled last month due to the war between Israel 
and Hamas. It comes after the Irish carrier cancelled over 870 flights in October as a result of the conflict in Gaza. 
Airlines have suspended flights to Tel Aviv and neighbouring Jordan after Hamas militants launched an attack on 
Israel on October 7 and due to the subsequent escalation of the war. 
Rival EASYJET said last week that conflict and the threat to stability across the Middle East has also affected 
demand for flights in destinations such as Egypt, while it saw bookings impacted across the board in October and 
November due to the war. EasyJet warned that it does not expect to narrow losses in the first quarter of its new 
financial year as flights and wider demand are affected, but it said booking appetite had started to recover in recent 
weeks. Ryanair's latest passenger statisShares tics showed it operated over 66,400 flights in November, with a 4% 
increase in people flown, at 11.7 million, despite the cancellations. London-listed Hungarian airline Wizz Air said 
yesterday that it has decided to suspend operations in Israel until early January next year. The budget airline said it 
"continues to monitor the situation on the ground closely, and stands ready to redeploy capacity should conditions 
stabilise". It carried 29.3% more passengers in November, at 4.8 million. Wizz Air said it had also restarted inbound 
flights to Chisinau, Moldova, in Eastern Europe having suspended flights to the country in March due to tensions 
linked to Russia's war with Ukraine. It said the move follows a "comprehensive evaluation of safety factors", adding 
that the group "intends to gradually re-introduce operations, including reopening its base in Chisinau, while ensuring 
safe and secure operations for its crew and passengers".

Ryanair Addresses Fake Engine Parts in Routine Checks
Ryanair Addresses Fake Engine Parts in Routine Checks
Airguide Business & AirguideBusiness.com
December 05, 2023
Copyright 2023 Pyramid Media Group Inc. All Rights Reserved
Section: Air and Travel Business News - Airlines; ISSN: 1939-666X
Length: 279 words
Body
Ryanair has revealed the discovery and replacement of unauthorized engine parts in two of its aircraft during 
routine inspections. The parts, suspected to be supplied by UK-based AOG Technics, were identified several 
months ago during checks in Brazil and the United States. Ryanair's CEO, Michael O'Leary, stated that the issue 
involved certain CFM56 engines manufactured by CFM International, impacting several Boeing B737NG and Airbus 
A320ceo family aircraft.
AOG Technics has faced scrutiny for selling parts with falsified Authorized Release Certificates (ARCs), as revealed 
by the European Aviation Safety Agency in August. While the problem has affected multiple airlines globally, 
O'Leary emphasized that Ryanair had been "largely unaffected" by the issue, having never engaged with AOG 
Technics.
The two affected engines are currently in workshops, with the relevant parts forwarded to investigators examining 
AOG Technics. O'Leary called for stricter controls over third-party suppliers in light of this incident. Other airlines, 
including Southwest Airlines, TUI Airways, TAP Portugal, and Virgin Australia, have also temporarily grounded 
aircraft to address the problem. Ryanair operates over 500 Boeing B737NG aircraft.

across the globe with our Advertising Multimedia Network, Advertising eMail: advert@AirGuideOnline.com and

Load-Date: December 26, 2023
End of Document

by the European Aviation Safety Agency in August. While the problem has affected multiple airlines globally,

Technics.
The two affected engines are currently in workshops, with the relevant parts forwarded to investigators examining

including Southwest Airlines, TUI Airways, TAP Portugal, and Virgin Australia, have also temporarily grounded

Ryanair Addresses Fake Engine Parts in Routine Checks
Ryanair Addresses Fake Engine Parts in Routine Checks
Airguide Business & AirguideBusiness.com
December 05, 2023
Copyright 2023 Pyramid Media Group Inc. All Rights Reserved
Section: Air and Travel Business News - Airlines; ISSN: 1939-666X
Length: 279 words
Body
Ryanair has revealed the discovery and replacement of unauthorized engine parts in two of its aircraft during 
routine inspections. The parts, suspected to be supplied by UK-based AOG Technics, were identified several 
months ago during checks in Brazil and the United States. Ryanair's CEO, Michael O'Leary, stated that the issue 
involved certain CFM56 engines manufactured by CFM International, impacting several Boeing B737NG and Airbus 
A320ceo family aircraft.
AOG Technics has faced scrutiny for selling parts with falsified Authorized Release Certificates (ARCs), as revealed 
by the European Aviation Safety Agency in August. While the problem has affected multiple airlines globally, 
O'Leary emphasized that Ryanair had been "largely unaffected" by the issue, having never engaged with AOG 
Technics.
The two affected engines are currently in workshops, with the relevant parts forwarded to investigators examining 
AOG Technics. O'Leary called for stricter controls over third-party suppliers in light of this incident. Other airlines, 
including Southwest Airlines, TUI Airways, TAP Portugal, and Virgin Australia, have also temporarily grounded 
aircraft to address the problem. Ryanair operates over 500 Boeing B737NG aircraft.
AirGuide and Pyramid Media connects you to an affluent, influential group of business and leisure travelers from 
across the globe with our Advertising Multimedia Network, Advertising eMail: advert@AirGuideOnline.com and 
Elevate your Customer Experience with our Tech and Content Solutions. For market intelligence and analysis see 
AirGuide

News, 
and 
for 
global 
travel 
see 
AirGuide 
Destination 
News. 
Editorial 
eMail: 
edit@AirGuideOnline.com
Load-Date: January 4, 2024
End of Document

Ryanair says it cancelled 960 flights in November due to Gaza conflict
Ryanair says it cancelled 960 flights in November due to Gaza conflict
The Irish Times
December 5, 2023 Tuesday
Copyright 2023 The Irish Times All Rights Reserved
Section: FINANCE; Pg. 16
Length: 309 words
Body
Ryanair has said more than 960 flights were cancelled last month due to the war between Israel and Hamas. 
It comes after the carrier cancelled more than 870 flights in October as a result of the conflict in Gaza.
Airlines have suspended flights to Tel Aviv and neighbouring Jordan after Hamas militants launched an attack on 
Israel on October 7th and due to the subsequent escalation of the war.
Rival EasyJet said last week that conflict and the threat to stability across the Middle East has also affected 
demand for flights in destinations such as Egypt, while it saw bookings impacted across the board in October and 
November due to the war.
 EasyJet warned that it does not expect to narrow losses in the first quarter of its new financial year as flights and 
wider demand are affected, but it said booking appetite had started to recover in recent weeks.
Ryanair s latest passenger statistics showed it operated more than  66,400 flights in November, with a 4 per cent 
increase in people flown, at 11.7 million, despite the cancellations.
London-listed Hungarian airline Wizz Air said yesterday that it has decided to suspend operations in Israel until 
early January next year. 
The budget airline said it  continues to monitor the situation on the ground closely, and stands ready to redeploy 
capacity should conditions stabilise .
It carried 29.3 per cent more passengers in November, at 4.8 million.
Wizz Air said it had also restarted inbound flights to Chisinau, Moldova, in eastern Europe having suspended flights 
to the country in March due to tensions linked to Russia s war with Ukraine. 
It said the move follows a  comprehensive evaluation of safety factors , adding that the group  intends to gradually 
reintroduce operations, including reopening its base in Chisinau, while ensuring safe and secure operations for its 
crew and passengers .   PA
Ryanair says it cancelled 960 flights in November due to Gaza conflict
Load-Date: December 4, 2023
End of Document
Stock Spotlight: easyJet soars to profitability as dividend return opens stock to income seekers
Stock Spotlight: easyJet soars to profitability as dividend return opens stock 
to income seekers
Investment Week
December 5, 2023 Tuesday
Copyright 2023 Incisive Media Limited All Rights Reserved
Length: 637 words
Byline: elliot.needham@incisivemedia.com, (Elliot Gulliver-Needham)
Body
Richard Hunter, head of markets at interactive investor, said easyJet had "finally put the ravages wrought by the 
pandemic to bed", thanks to a combination of "aggressive measures" by the group and the tailwind of people 
returning to travel.
Chris Beauchamp, chief market analyst at IG Group, said the stock had "shone" following its swing back into 
profitability for the year, which it revealed in its full-year results last week (28 November).
Stock Spotlight: Starbucks brews success in Q4 despite union discord
The company reported an adjusted pre-tax profit of £455m, compared to an expected £441.6m, well ahead of the 
previous year's loss of £178m.
A large amount of the growth has come from the sales of its package holidays, which are expected to expand by 
over 35% next year.
"The group has seen a true profitable benefit from ancillary revenues, which continue to boost revenues, and which 
include the likes of customer payments for personally allocated seats, baggage and food," added Hunter.
Revenues increased by 42% to £8.2bn during the period, which Hunter attributed to the company's pricing strength, 
an increase in capacity and load factors, and further strong growth in the easyJet holidays arm.
"At the same time, the group continues to target more profitable primary airports, as opposed to some of its 
competitors who choose to fly to cheaper, but less convenient, destinations," he noted.
US revises strong Q3 GDP numbers upwards to 5.2%
Stock Spotlight: easyJet soars to profitability as dividend return opens stock to income seekers
The airline's load factor - the metric used in the airline industry which measures the percentage of available seating 
capacity that has been filled with passengers - rose to 89% in 2023, up from 86% in 2022. The number of 
passengers also increased, jumping 19% to 82.8 million.
However, Michael Hewson, chief market analyst at CMC Markets UK, noted this was "well below the levels Ryanair 
has been able to achieve, where load factors are at 93%".
He added that despite the strong performance of the firm, easyJet had struggled to bring its stock price back to 
levels it was trading at earlier this year.
easyJet's stock price is up 40.7% year-to-date but still sits 12% below the 2023 peak set in May, according to data 
from Morningstar Direct.
The share price is still down 63.4% from its pre-Covid February 2020 levels and Hewson said it had failed to keep 
up with competitor Ryanair's stock, which was up 63% year-to-date and has now surpassed its pre-pandemic 
levels.
Russ Mould, investment director at AJ Bell, said the return of the firm's dividend represented a "tick in the box for its 
long-awaited recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic".
He noted that while the travel sector has seen strong demand in the past few years, intense cost pressures have 
been problematic for operators.
"Many airlines got heavily into debt during the pandemic, and they have had to prioritise paying down borrowings 
before dishing out dividends to shareholders," he explained.
Stock Spotlight: Toyota EV pivot may not be enough to catch Tesla
The net cash position of the firm has now pushed it to feel comfortable restarting dividends for the first time since 
2020, he added.
Hunter agreed: "The very fact that easyJet is in a position to make this move is a far cry from the recent past and 
shows confidence in prospects, which have taken some time to recover."
He added that while a projected yield of 1.1% was "for the moment little more than a gesture", the group plans to 
grow the dividend significantly over the next few years.
Beauchamp added that the reappearance of a dividend would also allow income investors to return to the stock, 
"providing hope of more inflows to boost the share price".
However, Mould warned the key challenge for the firm was to "sustain this positive momentum", which may prove 
difficult in the face of high interest rates and an ongoing cost-of-living crisis.
Load-Date: December 6, 2023
End of Document
Park and ride trial to be extended following bumper weekend
Park and ride trial to be extended following bumper weekend
Evening News (Norwich)
December 5, 2023 Tuesday
Copyright 2023 NewsQuest Media Group Limited All Rights Reserved
Length: 338 words
Byline: Edward Dewulf-Peters
Body
A city park and ride site that was given a second chance following a three-year closure has had its trial extended by 
more than three months.
The news comes after the Postwick Park and Ride reopened in September after being used as a Covid testing 
centre, but it was only planned to be open for four months.
But council bosses have confirmed the trial period will now be extended until April following an uptick in use and to 
allow more communities to take advantage of the service.
Councillor Graham Plant, cabinet member for highways, infrastructure and transport, said: "The Postwick Park and 
Ride has been open for more than three months now and figures are going in the right direction.
"Last Saturday saw the most passengers in one day since its reopening.
READ MORE: Ryanair will fly to THREE new Mediterranean destinations from Norwich Airport
"However, numbers are still low at around 37pc of pre-pandemic levels so we still need many more people using 
this service regularly to make it viable for the future."
The site was initially closed to become a Covid testing centre but was reopened as a trial ahead of last Christmas, 
with councillors subsequently emphasising the importance of keeping the site open.
The council warned the public to "use it or lose it" when talking about the 552-car-capacity site which the county 
council say costs 250,000 a year to run.
READ MORE: No charge for teen yet in derelict building arson spree investigation
Park and ride trial to be extended following bumper weekend
Mr Plant added: "We know how important this service is - particularly to those living in villages to the east - so we 
have decided to extend the trial until Easter next year to give it the best chance of getting passenger numbers back 
up."
The council also hopes to drive up numbers with quality-of-life changes to its "Travel Norfolk Journey Planner".
This includes showing the number of spaces available at all park and ride sites and a new function that is going live 
at the end of this week for park and ride journeys to appear as individual options when searched through the 
system.
Load-Date: December 5, 2023
End of Document
‘Spectacular’ destination is one of the cheapest city breaks in Europe
‘Spectacular’ destination is one of the cheapest city breaks in Europe
Express Online
December 5, 2023 Tuesday 10:27 AM GMT
Copyright 2023 Northern and Shell Media Publications All Rights Reserved
Length: 406 words
Byline: Esther Marshall
Body
Tirana is one of Europe's most affordable city breaks 
 This article contains affiliate links, we will receive a commission on any sales we generate from it. Learn more
Planning a city break? With prices soaring around the globe, it’s becoming more challenging to find an affordable 
mini-break.
However, there are still a few destinations where it’s possible to travel without breaking the bank.
Tirana, the capital of beautiful Albania, is one of the most affordable options for a city break and a fantastic choice 
for Britons looking to explore on a budget.
Albania is fast becoming a popular tourist destination but Brits that head there soon will find the country is still 
something of a hidden gem.
So what is there to do in Tirana?
Tirana is an affordable choice for Brits looking for a city break 
Surrounded by mountains, one of the best ways to admire Tirana is from the top of Dajti mountain, easily reached 
on the city’s cable car. At the top, tourists will find fantastic views of the city and a range of family-friendly activities.
A tourist wrote on Tripadvisor: “We were very lucky that the day we chose to go to the Dajti Mountain by the 
Ekspres Cable Car, it was wall to wall sunshine and the panoramic views were spectacular.”
In the city, tourists can visit one of Tirana’s museums, with Bunk’Art 1 and 2 top of most travellers’ lists.
Aubergine is a central ingredient of Albanian cuisine 
‘Spectacular’ destination is one of the cheapest city breaks in Europe
Housed in the city’s former bunkers, each museum delves into aspects of Albanian life under Enver Hoxha’s 
dictatorship. To find out more about the fearsome techniques the dictator’s secret service used to track citizens, 
head to the House of Leaves museum in the centre of the city.
Tirana also has a thriving nightlife scene and tourists will find fantastic cocktail bars in the Blokku district. Expect to 
pay no more than £6 or £7 for a cocktail.
When it comes to restaurants, the city has tons of options. Look out for lamb or aubergine dishes or pick up a 
famous burek pastry from a local bakery.
Brits visiting during spring or summer could also take a day trip to Durres, a nearby beach resort or head north to 
explore the countryside.
It takes just over three hours to reach Tirana from London with budget flights on airlines including Wizz Air and 
Ryanair.
Accommodation is much cheaper than in other European capitals with hotels on offer for around £20 per person per 
night. Search for hotels and self-catered options on Booking.com.
Load-Date: December 5, 2023
End of Document
Developers give update on Debenhams plans after 'slight delays'
Developers give update on Debenhams plans after 'slight delays'
Evening News (Norwich)
December 5, 2023 Tuesday
Copyright 2023 NewsQuest Media Group Limited All Rights Reserved
Length: 330 words
Byline: Edward Dewulf-Peters
Body
Developers behind a major housing proposal for the city's former Debenhams department store have given an 
update on why full plans are yet to emerge.
In the summer, developers Stanford Real Estate and planning consultants Lanpro revealed their vision for the 
prominent city centre building, in Orford Place.
Dubbed "Orford House", the development would see almost an entirely new structure built with shops on the first 
two floors and 400 student flats on the other floors.
In a schedule laid out by Lanpro, a public consultation was to be held in June that would be followed by a full 
planning submission in August.
But four months later, a formal application is yet to be lodged with Norwich City Council.
READ MORE: Korean police could 'expand' investigation into City loan striker's sex scandal
Ben Burgess, Lanpro regional director, said: "Work is still progressing towards submission of a full application for 
Orford House but as is often the case with projects of this size some slight delays have been encountered.
"I would expect the application to be submitted in the near future."
The building opened in 1956 after the previous Curls Brothers store on the site was destroyed in a 1942 Second 
World War air raid.
The building had been home to Debenhams until it closed in May 2021 as the company closed 30 stores around the 
country.
READ MORE: Ryanair will fly to THREE new Mediterranean destinations from Norwich Airport
Developers give update on Debenhams plans after 'slight delays'
As part of potential demolition plans, the existing building could be knocked down to all but the basement and 
ground floor.
The various sections of the building would vary in height, but at its tallest, it would be three storeys higher than the 
current, six-floor, building.
As well as its online application, Lanpro held a consultation event in association with Benchmark Architects at The 
Forum on Friday, June 23 to inform the final application.
However, a city council spokesman confirmed its planning department had not yet received plans from the 
developers.
Load-Date: December 5, 2023
End of Document
We think of immigrants in economic terms, but what about emotionally?
We think of immigrants in economic terms, but what about emotionally?
The Irish Times
December 5, 2023 Tuesday
Copyright 2023 The Irish Times All Rights Reserved
Section: FEATURES; Pg. 10
Length: 650 words
Body
Many decades ago my parents got a message from the post office to say that a woman in Australia had telephoned 
because she was concerned about a relative of ours who had arrived from Ireland and rented a room in her 
boarding house. He was in such a state of despair that she feared for his life.
I don t know how my parents dealt with this   like almost everyone else, they didn t have a telephone   but the man 
eventually went on to make a life for himself in Australia.
Thinking about him the other day it struck me that this scenario must be repeated in Ireland today for some of the 
immigrants who arrive here.
We often think of immigrants, refugees, even asylum seekers, in purely economic terms, but what s happening for 
them emotionally? How many experience the sort of despair that prompted that woman in Australia to ring an Irish 
post office?
Not all emigrants, as we know, cope successfully with their emotional pain. I have heard Irish people   and I don t 
mean tourists   shouting their angry, drunken way through Leicester Square in London and Downtown, Boston. I 
smiled ruefully and passed on.
We like to hear of successful emigration stories while the ones who were lost to alcoholism, homelessness or both 
have passed into the shadows.
Today s immigrants and even some refugees can, at least, visit home via Ryanair. But many   refugees and asylum 
seekers   may not ever go back to a home that will never be safe.
A 2017 report from the College of Psychiatrists of Ireland outlines what must be a crushing degree of pain for many 
of these people:  Asylum seekers have higher levels of psychopathology than the general population. They suffer 
higher rates of anxiety and depressive disorders than other sections of society. They have up to 10 times the level 
of post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) compared to the indigenous population.
 Most refugees and asylum seekers have not survived a single clear-cut traumatic event, but a collection of 
negative experiences of war and oppression. A torture experience will not necessarily be clearly separated from the 
other experiences and for some torture was not their worst experience. 
We think of immigrants in economic terms, but what about emotionally?
A person who works with refugees told me of the reversal that some families experience. For instance, you are 
supposed to be the head of your family but you don t speak English well or at all. So, increasingly, it s your school-
going children who interpret the world for you and interpret you to the world.
UK search suggests that having to leave your family behind and the challenge of establishing yourself in your new 
country are sources of depression and anxiety.
Other pressures are more subtle and hardly ever seen by us, the  host  population, especially for immigrants who 
came here to work. Requests for money, along with the expectation that you will send it, can come from the home 
country as many an Irish emigrant experienced in the past. The assumption is made that you have money to spare.
Much of the income of the Irish economy came from emigrants. How many Irish people never or rarely came home 
from England because they were expected to throw money around when they got here and they couldn t admit they 
didn t have it?
On top of this, we have the increasing belligerence of the right wing, with their hatred of immigrants. If I was an 
immigrant and if I had read the reported messages that passed between the promoters of the recent violence in 
Dublin, I would be, at the very least, wary when going around and at worst fearful (especially if I was black or 
brown).
Perhaps I am painting too gloomy a picture. I have left out the bright spots and the success stories. But it is good, I 
think, to have a rounded and empathetic understanding of people who are here and will always be here.
And who, in many respects, are no different to how we used to be.
Padraig O Morain is accredited  by the Irish Association for  Counselling and Psychotherapy
Load-Date: December 4, 2023
End of Document
