7.3 Profiles of Top ManagementMichael OLearyCEOMichael O'Leary has served as a director of Ryanair since 
1988 and a director of Ryanair Holdings since July 1996. He was appointed chief executive officer of Ryanair in 
1994.
Monthly: Ryanair Holdings (RY4B: EUR17.58) rises 22% on high volatility in November 2023
David BondermanNon-Executive ChairmanDavid Bonderman has served as a director since August 1996 and has 
served as the chairman of the Board of Directors since December 1996. In 1992, Mr. Bonderman co-founded TPG 
(formerly known as Texas Pacific Group), a private equity investment firm. He currently serves as an officer and 
director of the general partner and manager of TPG. Mr. Bonderman is also an officer, director and shareholder of 
1996 Air G.P. Inc., which owns shares of Ryanair. He also serves on the boards of directors of the following public 
companies: CoStar Group, Inc. and General Motors Company and is a U.S. citizen.
Shareholder Value:Creation of shareholder value in Ryanair Holdings:Month of appointment: December 1996In the 
last 10 years the average annualized return to shareholders was 11.9%. The present value of Euro1,000 (PV1000) 
invested 10 years ago is now EUR3,086, a gain of EUR1,973 and dividend reinvested of EUR113. 
Neil SorahanCFONeil Sorahan was appointed Chief Financial Officer of Ryanair in October 2014, having previously 
served as its Finance Director from June 2006. Prior to that, he was Ryanair's Group Treasurer from January 2003. 
Before joining Ryanair, Neil held various finance and treasury roles at CRH plc, the international building materials 
group (June 1992 to December 2002).
Shareholder Value:Creation of shareholder value in Ryanair Holdings:Year of appointment: 2014In the last 5 years 
the average annualized return to shareholders was 8.7%. The present value of Euro1,000 (PV1000) invested 5 
years ago is now EUR1,520, a gain of EUR520. 
Michael HickeyChief Operating OfficerMichael Hickey has served as Chief Operations Officer since February 2014. 
Michael has held a wide range of senior positions within the Engineering Department since 1988 and was Director 
of Engineering between January 2000 and February 2014. Prior to joining Ryanair in 1988, Michael worked as an 
aircraft engineer with Fields Aircraft Services and McAlpine Aviation, working primarily on executive aircraft.
Shareholder Value:Creation of shareholder value in Ryanair Holdings:Year of appointment: 2014In the last 5 years 
the average annualized return to shareholders was 8.7%. The present value of Euro1,000 (PV1000) invested 5 
years ago is now EUR1,520, a gain of EUR520. 
Juliusz KomorekCompany SecretaryJuliusz Komorek was appointed Company Secretary and Chief Legal and 
Regulatory Officer in May 2009, having served as Deputy Director of Legal and Regulatory Affairs since 2007. Prior 
to joining the Company in 2004, Juliusz had gained relevant experience in the European Commission's Directorate 
General for Competition and in the Polish Embassy to the EU in Brussels, as well as in the private sector in Poland 
and the Netherlands. Juliusz is a lawyer, holding degrees from the universities of Warsaw and Amsterdam.
7.4 Profiles of Board of DirectorsMichael CawleyDirectorMichael Cawley was appointed as a non-executive director 
of Ryanair in August 2014. Michael had served as Deputy Chief Executive Officer and Chief Operating Officer of 
Ryanair from 2003 to March 2014 and before that as Ryanair's Chief Financial Officer and Commercial Director 
from 1997. Michael also holds directorships in Paddy Power PLC and in Kingspan Group PLC. Prior to joining 
Ryanair, Michael was Group Finance Director of Gowan Group Limited, one of Ireland's largest private companies 
and the main distributor for Peugeot and Citroen automobiles in Ireland. Michael holds a Bachelor of Commerce 
degree and is a fellow of the Institute of Chartered Accountants in Ireland. He is an Irish citizen.
Shareholder Value:Creation of shareholder value in Ryanair Holdings:Month of appointment: August 2014In the last 
5 years the average annualized return to shareholders was 8.7%. The present value of Euro1,000 (PV1000) 
invested 5 years ago is now EUR1,520, a gain of EUR520. 
Michael O''LearyDirectorMichael O'Leary has served as a director of Ryanair since 1988 and a director of Ryanair 
Holdings since July 1996. He was appointed chief executive officer of Ryanair in 1994.
Shareholder Value:Creation of shareholder value in Ryanair Holdings:Year of appointment: 1988In the last 10 years 
the average annualized return to shareholders was 11.9%. The present value of Euro1,000 (PV1000) invested 10 
years ago is now EUR3,086, a gain of EUR1,973 and dividend reinvested of EUR113. 
Monthly: Ryanair Holdings (RY4B: EUR17.58) rises 22% on high volatility in November 2023
Mike O''BrienNon-Executive DirectorMike O'Brien was appointed as a non-executive director of Ryanair in May 
2016.Capt O'Brien has a long and distinguished career in the aviation industry having just retired as Head of Flight 
Operations with the Maltese Civil Aviation Authority whom he joined in 2001, having previously served for 10 years 
as the Head of Operations Standards with the Irish Aviation Authority. Capt O'Brien also served 4 years as the 
Chief Pilot and Flight Ops Manager of Ryanair from 1987 to 1991.
R. A. (Dick) MillikenNon-Executive DirectorAge: 62Dick Milliken has served as a director of Ryanair since July 
2013.
Howard MillarNon-Executive DirectorHoward Millar was appointed as a non-executive director of Ryanair in August 
2015. Howard had served as Deputy Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer from 2003 to December 
2014 and before that as Ryanair's Director of Finance from 1993. Howard is Chairman of BDO Ireland and a 
member of Irelandia Aviation's advisory board. Howard is a graduate of Trinity College, Dublin and is a fellow of 
Chartered Accountants Ireland. He is an Irish citizen.
James OsborneNon-Executive DirectorJames Osborne has served as a director of Ryanair Holdings since August 
1996, and has been a director of Ryanair since April 1995. Mr. Osborne is a former managing partner of A & L 
Goodbody Solicitors. He is also a former Chairman of Independent News and Media plc and a director of James 
Hardie Industries NV. He also serves as a director of a number of Irish private companies and is an Irish citizen.
Kyran McLaughlinNon-Executive DirectorKyran McLaughlin has served as a director since January 2001, and is 
also Deputy Chairman and Head of Capital Markets at Davy Stockbrokers. Mr. McLaughlin also advised Ryanair 
during its initial flotation on the Dublin and NASDAQ stock markets in 1997. Mr. McLaughlin serves on the Board of 
Directors of Elan Corporation plc, and he also serves as a director of a number of other Irish private companies and 
is an Irish citizen.
Louise PhelanNon-Executive DirectorLouise Phelan has served as a director of Ryanair since December 2012. Ms. 
Phelan is currently serving as VP for PayPal Global Operations Europe Middle East and Africa leading 1,800 
people in Dublin, Dundalk and Berlin. Louise has been part of PayPal since 2006 and prior to this she was a 
member of the Senior Management team for GE Money, a division of General Electric (GE), which specialises in 
small ticket lending for a client base comprising both consumers and commercial customers. Louise is also a 
member of the Board of the American Chamber of Commerce and a member of the Dublin Chamber of Commerce, 
CCMA Ireland, the Women's Executive Network (WXN) and the International Women's Forum and is an Irish 
citizen.
Julie O''NeillNon-Executive DirectorJulie O'Neill is a non-executive director at Ryanair, Europe's favourite airline. 
She served as Secretary General of the Department of Transport, Ireland from 2002 to 2009. During that time she 
delivered a successful IPO for the part-privatisation of Aer Lingus and oversaw the setting up of the Dublin Airport 
Authority to provide the basis for the subsequent independence of Shannon Airport. In a career that spanned 37 
years in the Irish public service, she worked in strategic policy development and implementation in eight 
Government Departments.
Declan McKeonNon-Executive DirectorDeclan McKeon has served as a director since May 2010. Mr. McKeon is a 
former audit partner of PricewaterhouseCoopers and continues to act as a consultant to PricewaterhouseCoopers. 
He is currently a director, chairman of the audit committee, and a member of the compensation committee of Icon 
plc and is an Irish citizen.
Charles McCreevyNon-Executive DirectorCharles McCreevy has served as a director since May 2010. Mr. 
McCreevy has previously served as EU Commissioner for Internal Markets and Services (2004-2010) and has held 
positions in several Irish Government Ministerial Offices, including Minister for Finance (1997-2004), Minister for 
Tourism & Trade (1993-1994) and Minister for Social Welfare (1992-1993) and is an Irish citizen.

GLOSSARYADVT: Average Daily Volume of shares TradedAnnual Return: Dividends Paid In a 12-Month 
Period/Price at the Beginning of the Period + Capital Gain or Loss over 1 Year/Price 1 Year Ago (%)Cash/MCap: 
Cash plus Liquids/Market Capitalisation (times)Current Ratio: Current Assets/Current Liabilities (times)Debt/Equity: 
Net Debt/Net Assets %EBIT Margin : Earnings Before Interest and Tax/Revenue (%)Moving Average Price (n 
periods): Sum of Prices for each Period/Number of PeriodsPV1000: Present value of 1000 invested 1 year/'n' years 
agoPrice Close/Moving Avg Price: Latest Price/Moving Average PricePrice/NTA: Closing Share Price/Net Tangible 
Assets Per Share (times)Price/Sales: Share Price/Sales Per Share (times)Relative Price Change [RPC]: Relative 
price change is price change of stock with respect to Benchmark IndexReturn on Assets: Net Profit/Total Assets 
(%)Return on Equity (Shareholders' Funds): Net Profit/Net Assets (%)TSR: Total Shareholder Returns is expressed 
Monthly: Ryanair Holdings (RY4B: EUR17.58) rises 22% on high volatility in November 2023
as an annualized rate of return for shareholders after allowing for capital appreciation and dividendVolume Index 
(VI): Number of shares traded in the period/Average number of shares traded for the periodVolume Weighted 
Average Price (VWAP): The Volume Weighted Average Price (VWAP) is the summation of turnover divided by total 
volume in the same period.

Ryanair Holdings - 6 Reasons Traders Remain Bullish (and 1 Reason Why Bearish)
Ryanair Holdings- 6 Reasons Traders Remain Bullish (and 1 Reason Why 
Bearish)
News Bites - Western Europe: Ireland
December 4, 2023 Monday
Copyright 2023 Jupiter International (Australia) Pty Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: STOCK
Length: 419 words
Body
IRISH STOCK REPORT
Ryanair Holdings (I:RY4B), Ireland's largest Airline company by market cap, has soared 47.4% Year To Date. 
There is uncertainty in the market and it is difficult to predict how economic conditions will be in 2024 and beyond 
as well as what the impact of those conditions may be on Ryanair Holdings. However, there are several key 
reasons why some investors remain bullish on the short-term prospects for Ryanair Holdings.
Below are some of those key reasons:
- Ryanair Holdings' share price has lifted 2.4% from its previous trading session to close at EUR18.0.- The volume 
was 1.4 times the average daily trading volume of 1.8 million shares.- The stock has a 1-month relative price 
strength of 94 indicating it is outperformed 94% of the market. A price rise combined with a high relative strength is 
a bullish signal. - The Moving Average Convergence Divergence (MACD) indicator of 12-day Exponential Moving 
Average (EMA) of 17.4 minus the 26-day EMA of 16.8 is positive, suggesting a bullish signal. The price to 50-day 
EMAP ratio is 1.1, a bullish indicator. - Both the 12-day EMA as well as the 26-day EMA are rising, another bullish 
signal.- The stock is up in last 3 days 3.2%, 3.9% for last 5 days and 22.9% for past month.
However, there is at least one reason investors may remain bearish in the short-term:
- The stock is trading below both its MAPs and the 50-day MAP of 16.4 is lower than the 200-day MAP of 16.8, a 
bearish indicator.

A year ago the exchange rate was USD 1 = 0.97 EUR. USD1000 would have bought EUR969. A year ago the 
Ryanair Holdings Share price was EUR13.04. EUR969 would have bought 74.3 Ryanair Holdings Shares on that 
day. Those 74.3 Shares would be worth EUR1,338 at today's Share price of EUR18.0. At today's exchange rate of 
USD1=0.92 EUR this is equivalent to USD1,459. PV$1000= $1,459.
Activities
Ryanair Holdings plc (Ryanair) is engaged in the provision of a scheduled airline service across a European route 
network. It is Ireland's largest Airline company by market capitalisation.

IRISH END-OF-DAY STOCK REPORT
www.buysellsignals.com
Ryanair Holdings PLC's (I: RY4B EUR18.04) stock price hit a 52-week high of EUR18.22 during the day. In the past 
month the stock has hit a new 52-week high seven times, pointing to a significant uptrend. 
Ryanair Holdings' stock price increased 4.0c (0.2%) from its previous trading session to close at EUR18.04. 
Compared with the ISEQ Overall Index which fell 34.8 points (0.4%) in the day, the relative price increase was 
0.6%. 
Ryanair Holdings PLC is Ireland's largest Airline company by market cap. 
There were 2,780,000 shares worth EUR50.2 million ($54.6 million) traded today. Monday's price rise was propped 
up by robust volume of 1.6 times the average daily volume of 1.8 million shares.

1.3 Uptrend
The stock traded at a thirty one-month high of EUR18.22 today. Price/Moving Average Price of 1.08 and positive 
MACD:- The Price/MAP 200 for Ryanair Holdings is 1.08. Being higher than 1 is a bullish indicator. It is higher than 
the Price/MAP 200 for the ISEQ Overall Index of 0.99, a second bullish indicator. The 200-day MAP has increased 
to EUR16.78, a third bullish indicator.- The Moving Average Convergence Divergence (MACD) indicator of 12-day 
Exponential Moving Average (EMA) of 17.46 minus the 26-day EMA of 16.92 is positive, suggesting a bullish signal. 
Both the 12-day EMA as well as the 26-day EMA are rising, another bullish signal.- The price to 50-day EMAP ratio 
is 1.1, a bullish indicator. The 50-day EMAP has increased to EUR16.47. An increase is another bullish indicator.
Past Month:- Rises to Falls: In the past month the number of rises outnumbered falls 13:5 or 2.6:1. 
Past Quarter:
In the last three months the stock has hit a new 52-week high seven times, pointing to a significant uptrend. The 
Best 3 weeks in the past quarterIn the past quarter the week beginning Monday November 06 saw the highest 
weekly rise of 10.1% for a relative price increase of 13.1%. The rise was propped up by volume of 1.9 times 
average.

EUR7.3 billion (55%) from EUR13.2 billion to EUR20.5 billion. Based on a dynamic start date of 5 years ago, there

Ryanair denies introducing 'scandalous' boarding pass fee after passenger complaints
Ryanair denies introducing 'scandalous' boarding pass fee after passenger 
complaints
standard.co.uk
December 4, 2023 Monday 4:36 PM GMT
Copyright 2023 Evening Standard Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: UK,NEWS; Version:1
Length: 447 words
Byline: Daniel Keane
Highlight: Passengers claimed they were forced to pay extra to obtain a digital pass
Body
Ryanair  has denied claims from passengers that it has introduced a “scandalous” extra fee to obtain a digital 
boarding pass.  
Travellers using the budget airline  said they had been charged up to £21 to book a seat on their flight, in order to 
access their e-boarding pass.
Those who refused to pay the fee claimed that they were forced to queue for a paper pass at the airport. 
But a spokesperson for Ryanair denied that the airline had introduced the charge, despite furious complaints from 
passengers on social media. 
One passenger travelling from London to Belfast on Monday tweeted: “When and why did you start this carry on? I 
now have to QUEUE to collect my boarding pass at the airport.”
Another passenger said: “I just can't believe your new policy of not allowing passengers to create a boarding pass 
(mobile or print-out) unless they buy a seat, forcing them to join a check-in queue (30m or longer) to do so for no 
other reason for you to make a few quid. Scandalous.”
And another passenger posted a screenshot of their app after checking in, with a message reading: "Get your 
boarding pass now and avoid queueing at the airport by adding a seat".
They wrote alongside the image: "Charging for a mobile boarding pass? You are ridiculous."
Ryanair denies introducing 'scandalous' boarding pass fee after passenger complaints
Ryanair passengers are usually provided with their digital boarding pass for free via their app. There is a separate 
fee for travellers wishing to book a specific seat on the flight. 
A spokesperson for Ryanair said in a statement: “There is no charge for a Ryanair digital boarding pass – ever. 
"All Ryanair passengers can pay for a reserved seat if they so wish or if passengers wish to avoid this seat fee, they 
can select a randomly allocated seat entirely free of charge.”
Ryanair is known for its low fares  but has also been criticised for its numerous add-on charges. 
This includes a fee for putting luggage in the hold, booking a seat and requesting a seat with extra legroom. 
Ryanair's CEO Michael O'Leary  has defended the airline's hidden fees, saying they are essential in order to keep 
fares low. 
Consumer rights expert Martyn James told the BBC that the new fee was likely a malfunction on Ryanair’s 
computer or booking systems. 
“If this new charge is true, then it's something of a false economy for Ryanair, as they'll need an awful lot more staff 
on the check-in desks to print off all of those boarding passes," he said.
“However, this latest news story highlights a glaringly unfair scenario that's been allowed to continue for far too 
long. Passengers should not have to pay for reserving a 'standard' seat at all. Speedy boarding, more legroom, 
premium -fine. But you should not have to pay to sit next to a loved one."
Load-Date: December 4, 2023
End of Document
Ryanair hits back at 'false' claims that it's introducing a new fee for passengers
Ryanair hits back at 'false' claims that it's introducing a new fee for 
passengers
Daily Star Online
December 4, 2023 Monday 4:17 PM GMT
Copyright 2023 Northern and Shell Media Publications All Rights Reserved
Length: 412 words
Byline: By, Sophie Foster
Highlight: Budget airline Ryanair came under fire from customers claiming they are being charged between £8 and 
£21 for a seat to get their boarding pass – but spokesperson says there is 'no charge for boarding pass – ever'
Body
Holidaymakers have spoken out in fury after claiming budget airline Ryanair had introduced a new charge. A small 
number of passengers claimed they were being forced to pay for a seat in order to download an e-boarding pass, or 
face queuing up at the airport. 
However, the airline has hit back at the 'false' reports. A spokesperson told the Daily Star: "These reports are false. 
There is no charge for a Ryanair digital boarding pass – ever. All Ryanair passengers can pay for a reserved seat if 
they so wish or if passengers wish to avoid this seat fee, they can select a randomly allocated seat entirely free of 
charge.:"
The airline is notorious for charging for heaps of add-ons from checked luggage to cabin bags, drinks and snacks 
on board, seat selection, priority boarding and more. Airlines have previously stated that digital passes allow them 
to hire fewer check-in agents which saves them money and keeps costs down. This is part of what lets them sell 
flights at such low prices.
                                            Check out our travel section for more holidays, travel news, hacks, flight secrets and 
more..                                        
Ryanair has already come under fire for charging Brits £55 per person to print off their boarding passes if they don’t 
check in online. This fee is applied to prevent large queues at the airport for check-in. Earlier this year, a woman 
took to Twitter, now known as X, in fury after her elderly parents were charged the added fee. She said her parents 
"in their 70s and 80s" made a mistake when downloading their boarding passes to their mobiles.
Ryanair hits back at 'false' claims that it's introducing a new fee for passengers
To be able to board the flight they then had to shell out £110 for "two pieces of paper". The rule means that the 
latest change to Ryanair policy, which will cause more queues at check-in is confusing for some.
A Ryanair spokesperson told Daily Star at the time: "In accordance with Ryanair’s T&C’s, which these passengers 
agreed to at the time of booking, they failed to check-in online before arriving at Stansted airport 11 Aug despite 
receiving an email reminder 10 Aug to check-in online. These passengers were correctly charged the airport check-
in fee £55 per pax.
"All passengers travelling with Ryanair agree to check-in online before arriving at their departure airport and all 
passengers are sent an email/SMS, reminding them to do so 24hrs before departure. We regret that these 
passengers ignored their email reminder and failed to check-in online."
Load-Date: December 4, 2023
End of Document

IRISH END-OF-WEEK STOCK REPORT
www.buysellsignals.com
Ryanair Holdings (I:RY4B EUR18.0), Ireland's largest Airline company by market cap, has lifted 67.0c (or 3.9%) in 
the past week to close at EUR18.0. Compared with the ISEQ Overall Index which rose 200.1 points (or 2.4%) in the 
week, this represented a relative price increase of 1.4%. 
The price ranged between a high of EUR18.0 on Friday Dec 01 and a low of EUR17.13 on Monday Nov 27. In the 
past week the market cap has risen by EUR762.9 million ($832.1 million) to EUR20.5 billion. 
Total volume in the week equalled the average trading of 8.8 million shares. 
Bearish Turning Point
Relative Strength Index (RSI)The Relative Strength Index (RSI) of 73.4 has penetrated the overbought line of 70, 
suggesting the price gain of 5.4% in the last 14 days is unusually high. The RSI was previously 68.6.
A year ago the exchange rate was USD 1 = 0.97 EUR. USD1000 would have bought EUR969. A year ago the 
Ryanair Holdings Share price was EUR13.04. EUR969 would have bought 74.3 Ryanair Holdings Shares on that 
day. Those 74.3 Shares would be worth EUR1,338 at today's Share price of EUR18.0. At today's exchange rate of 
USD1=0.92 EUR this is equivalent to USD1,459. PV$1000= $1,459.

GLOSSARYADVT: Average Daily Volume of shares TradedAnnual Return: Dividends Paid In a 12-Month 
Period/Price at the Beginning of the Period + Capital Gain or Loss over 1 Year/Price 1 Year Ago (%)Cash/MCap: 
Cash plus Liquids/Market Capitalisation (times)Current Ratio: Current Assets/Current Liabilities (times)Debt/Equity: 
Net Debt/Net Assets %EBIT Margin : Earnings Before Interest and Tax/Revenue (%)Moving Average Price (n 
periods): Sum of Prices for each Period/Number of PeriodsPV1000: Present value of 1000 invested 1 year/'n' years 
agoPrice Close/Moving Avg Price: Latest Price/Moving Average PricePrice/NTA: Closing Share Price/Net Tangible 
Assets Per Share (times)Price/Sales: Share Price/Sales Per Share (times)Relative Price Change [RPC]: Relative 
price change is price change of stock with respect to Benchmark IndexRelative Strength (6 Months): Price close 
today/Price close 6 months ago, then ranked by percentile within the entire market.Return on Assets: Net 
Profit/Total Assets (%)Return on Equity (Shareholders' Funds): Net Profit/Net Assets (%)TSR: Total Shareholder 
Returns is expressed as an annualized rate of return for shareholders after allowing for capital appreciation and 
dividendVolume Index (VI): Number of shares traded in the period/Average number of shares traded for the 
periodVolume Weighted Average Price (VWAP): The Volume Weighted Average Price (VWAP) is the summation of 
turnover divided by total volume in the same period.

Ryanair passengers slam 'disgraceful' and 'ridiculous' new add-on charge
Ryanair passengers slam 'disgraceful' and 'ridiculous' new add-on charge
Oxford Mail
December 4, 2023 Monday
Copyright 2023 NewsQuest Media Group Limited All Rights Reserved
Length: 408 words
Byline: Carlo Simone
Body
Ryanair has been criticised for a "ridiculous" and "disgraceful" add-on charge where some customers are reportedly 
having to pay a fee to access their digital boarding pass.
The budget airline already charges for add-ons such as checked baggage and booking a seat in advance.
Now it appears that some are being stuck with having to pay a fee to access their digital boarding pass, otherwise 
they will have to queue to collect a printed one from the airport.
Passengers have shared screenshots on X (formerly Twitter), with the airline-s app instructing them to select a 
random seat in advance at a cost of between 8 and 21 if they wish to download their digital boarding pass.
@Ryanair I just can-t believe your new policy of not allowing passengers to create a boarding pass (mobile or print-
out) unless they buy a seat, forcing them to join a check-in queue (30m or longer) to do so for no other reason for 
you to make a few quid. Scandalous. pic.twitter.com/48SMNrbMSV
- Ell- To Pay (@Ell2Pay) December 2, 2023
Airport staff told The Mail on Sunday the change, which has been rolled out in recent days, had caused outrage 
with affected customers.
How did Ryanair passengers react to digital boarding pass charge?
One Ryanair customer posted online: "I just can-t believe your new policy of not allowing passengers to create a 
boarding pass (mobile or print-out) unless they buy a seat, forcing them to join a check-in queue (30m or longer) to 
do so for no other reason for you to make a few quid. Scandalous."
Another person shared: "@askryanair I know that you're cheap but forcing me to pay for a seat or having to go to 
the airport early to collect a boarding pass in person is RIDICULOUS".
Ryanair passengers slam 'disgraceful' and 'ridiculous' new add-on charge
@askryanair I know that you're cheap but forcing me to pay for a seat or having to go to the airport early to collect a 
boarding pass in person is RIDICULOUS pic.twitter.com/536ANqBlw9
- Denis (@the_kneeees) December 2, 2023
Frustration was evident among many people, with another posting: "@Ryanair why have I now got to buy a seat to 
access a digital boarding pass that was free for years you're disgraceful and do nothing but congest airports and 
damage your reputation inexorably".
Speaking to The Mail on Sunday Ryanair spokesman said: "Passengers have the choice of choosing a seat for a 
small fee or be randomly allocated a seat free of charge."
The latest fee does not appear to affect all travellers, with some saying they got a digital boarding pass for free.

Ryanair hits back at 'false' reports it's charging passengers to get e-boarding passes
Ryanair hits back at 'false' reports it's charging passengers to get e-
boarding passes
mirror.co.uk
December 4, 2023 Monday 4:12 PM GMT
Copyright 2023 Reach PLC All Rights Reserved
Section: CHEAP FLIGHTS; Version:1
Length: 467 words
Byline: By, Milo Boyd
Highlight: Ryanair passengers claimed that they were being charged up to £21 for a seat in order to get an e-
boarding pass but the budget airline has hit back at the 'false' reports
Body
                     Ryanair has denied reports it has started charging customers a new fee for e-boarding passes. 
A small number of passengers with the budget airline claimed they had to fork out up to £21 for a seat booking if 
they wanted an e-boarding pass, or face having to queue at the airport to get their ticket. However, the airline has 
slammed the claims as 'false'. 
A spokesperson for Ryanair told the Mirror: "These reports are false. There is no charge for a Ryanair digital 
boarding pass - ever. All Ryanair passengers can pay for a reserved seat if they so wish or if passengers wish to 
avoid this seat fee, they can select a randomly allocated seat entirely free of charge." 
If you are due to fly with Ryanair, it is worth noting that you'll need to check-in online two hours or more before your 
flight -or you'll face a fee to check-in at the airport. CEO Michael O'Leary has said multiple times that the £65 fee is 
levied to stop people checking-in in person at the airport, as doing so requires additional staff. 
                     Have you been hit by the new fee Email webtravel@reachplc.com                   
Most airlines require passengers to check-in online and then allow them to download a pass. Customers can 
usually pick up a printed copy from the airport free of charge, whether from an airline staff member or from a self-
service machine.
Ryanair hits back at 'false' reports it's charging passengers to get e-boarding passes
The airline has gained a reputation in recent years for levying charges on their customers. Unzela Khan recently 
ended up having to pay £220 to check-in at Luton Airport, based on each of her party being charged £55 each. She 
told MyLondon that her family had booked a holiday to Naples, Italy, and paid around £200 for the flights.
The family arrived at Luton Airport on November 3 and thought all was well until they got to the front of the check-in 
desk queue. "We reached the check-in desk, weighed our bags and discussed checking in the baby car seat and 
pushchair. Then, the Ryanair employee said: 'That'll be £55.' Confused, we asked why and were told it was 
because we hadn't checked in online."
Despite the family's protests, they were told it would cost £220 for the four of them, although the baby could fly for 
no extra cost. If they couldn't afford to stump up, they weren't allowed to fly. "Anyway, we begrudgingly had to pay 
the £220 which is a whole adult ticket to Italy while listening to another family next to us going through the same 
shock and horror," Unzela said.
Ryanair's website states that "You can check in for your flight at the airport, but you will have to pay an airport 
check-in fee per passenger to cover the extra cost of the airport check-in service." If you fail to check-in online two 
hours or more before your plane departs, then you will be charged the fee, even if you can do so at the airport.
Load-Date: December 4, 2023
End of Document
Ryanair passengers slam 'disgraceful' and 'ridiculous' new add-on charge
Ryanair passengers slam 'disgraceful' and 'ridiculous' new add-on charge
Worcester News
December 4, 2023 Monday
Copyright 2023 NewsQuest Media Group Limited All Rights Reserved
Length: 408 words
Byline: Carlo Simone
Body
Ryanair has been criticised for a "ridiculous" and "disgraceful" add-on charge where some customers are reportedly 
having to pay a fee to access their digital boarding pass.
The budget airline already charges for add-ons such as checked baggage and booking a seat in advance.
Now it appears that some are being stuck with having to pay a fee to access their digital boarding pass, otherwise 
they will have to queue to collect a printed one from the airport.
Passengers have shared screenshots on X (formerly Twitter), with the airline-s app instructing them to select a 
random seat in advance at a cost of between 8 and 21 if they wish to download their digital boarding pass.
@Ryanair I just can-t believe your new policy of not allowing passengers to create a boarding pass (mobile or print-
out) unless they buy a seat, forcing them to join a check-in queue (30m or longer) to do so for no other reason for 
you to make a few quid. Scandalous. pic.twitter.com/48SMNrbMSV
- Ell- To Pay (@Ell2Pay) December 2, 2023
Airport staff told The Mail on Sunday the change, which has been rolled out in recent days, had caused outrage 
with affected customers.
How did Ryanair passengers react to digital boarding pass charge?
One Ryanair customer posted online: "I just can-t believe your new policy of not allowing passengers to create a 
boarding pass (mobile or print-out) unless they buy a seat, forcing them to join a check-in queue (30m or longer) to 
do so for no other reason for you to make a few quid. Scandalous."
Another person shared: "@askryanair I know that you're cheap but forcing me to pay for a seat or having to go to 
the airport early to collect a boarding pass in person is RIDICULOUS".
Ryanair passengers slam 'disgraceful' and 'ridiculous' new add-on charge
@askryanair I know that you're cheap but forcing me to pay for a seat or having to go to the airport early to collect a 
boarding pass in person is RIDICULOUS pic.twitter.com/536ANqBlw9
- Denis (@the_kneeees) December 2, 2023
Frustration was evident among many people, with another posting: "@Ryanair why have I now got to buy a seat to 
access a digital boarding pass that was free for years you're disgraceful and do nothing but congest airports and 
damage your reputation inexorably".
Speaking to The Mail on Sunday Ryanair spokesman said: "Passengers have the choice of choosing a seat for a 
small fee or be randomly allocated a seat free of charge."
The latest fee does not appear to affect all travellers, with some saying they got a digital boarding pass for free.
Load-Date: December 4, 2023
End of Document

they will have to queue to collect a printed one from the airport.

random seat in advance at a cost of between 8 and 21 if they wish to download their digital boarding pass.
@Ryanair I just can-t believe your new policy of not allowing passengers to create a boarding pass (mobile or print-
out) unless they buy a seat, forcing them to join a check-in queue (30m or longer) to do so for no other reason for 
you to make a few quid. Scandalous. pic.twitter.com/48SMNrbMSV
- Ell- To Pay (@Ell2Pay) December 2, 2023
Airport staff told The Mail on Sunday the change, which has been rolled out in recent days, had caused outrage 
with affected customers.
How did Ryanair passengers react to digital boarding pass charge?
One Ryanair customer posted online: "I just can-t believe your new policy of not allowing passengers to create a 
boarding pass (mobile or print-out) unless they buy a seat, forcing them to join a check-in queue (30m or longer) to 
do so for no other reason for you to make a few quid. Scandalous."

the airport early to collect a boarding pass in person is RIDICULOUS".

boarding pass in person is RIDICULOUS pic.twitter.com/536ANqBlw9
- Denis (@the_kneeees) December 2, 2023
Frustration was evident among many people, with another posting: "@Ryanair why have I now got to buy a seat to 
access a digital boarding pass that was free for years you're disgraceful and do nothing but congest airports and 
damage your reputation inexorably".
Speaking to The Mail on Sunday Ryanair spokesman said: "Passengers have the choice of choosing a seat for a 
small fee or be randomly allocated a seat free of charge."
The latest fee does not appear to affect all travellers, with some saying they got a digital boarding pass for free.

Ryanair has been criticised for a "ridiculous" and "disgraceful" add-on charge where some customers are reportedly 
having to pay a fee to access their digital boarding pass.
The budget airline already charges for add-ons such as checked baggage and booking a seat in advance.
Now it appears that some are being stuck with having to pay a fee to access their digital boarding pass, otherwise 
they will have to queue to collect a printed one from the airport.

random seat in advance at a cost of between 8 and 21 if they wish to download their digital boarding pass.

out) unless they buy a seat, forcing them to join a check-in queue (30m or longer) to do so for no other reason for 
you to make a few quid. Scandalous. pic.twitter.com/48SMNrbMSV

boarding pass (mobile or print-out) unless they buy a seat, forcing them to join a check-in queue (30m or longer) to 
do so for no other reason for you to make a few quid. Scandalous."

the airport early to collect a boarding pass in person is RIDICULOUS".

Ryanair customers rage at 'disgraceful' and 'ridiculous' new add-on charge
Ryanair customers rage at 'disgraceful' and 'ridiculous' new add-on charge
The National (Scotland)
December 4, 2023 Monday
Copyright 2023 NewsQuest Media Group Limited All Rights Reserved
Length: 407 words
Byline: Carlo Simone
Body
RYANAIR has been criticised for a "ridiculous" and "disgraceful" new add-on charge.
Some customers are reportedly having to pay a fee to access their digital boarding pass.
The budget airline already charges for add-ons such as checked baggage and booking a seat in advance.
Now it appears that some are being stuck with having to pay a fee to access their digital boarding pass, otherwise 
they will have to queue to collect a printed one from the airport.
Passengers have shared screenshots on Twitter/X, with the airline-s app instructing them to select a random seat in 
advance at a cost of between 8 and 21 if they wish to download their digital boarding pass.
@Ryanair I just can-t believe your new policy of not allowing passengers to create a boarding pass (mobile or print-
out) unless they buy a seat, forcing them to join a check-in queue (30m or longer) to do so for no other reason for 
you to make a few quid. Scandalous. pic.twitter.com/48SMNrbMSV
- Ell- To Pay (@Ell2Pay) December 2, 2023
Airport staff told The Mail on Sunday the change, which has been rolled out in recent days, had caused outrage 
with affected customers.
How did Ryanair passengers react to digital boarding pass charge?
Ryanair customers rage at 'disgraceful' and 'ridiculous' new add-on charge
One Ryanair customer posted online: "I just can-t believe your new policy of not allowing passengers to create a 
boarding pass (mobile or print-out) unless they buy a seat, forcing them to join a check-in queue (30m or longer) to 
do so for no other reason for you to make a few quid. Scandalous."
Another person shared: "@askryanair I know that you're cheap but forcing me to pay for a seat or having to go to 
the airport early to collect a boarding pass in person is RIDICULOUS."
@askryanair I know that you're cheap but forcing me to pay for a seat or having to go to the airport early to collect a 
boarding pass in person is RIDICULOUS pic.twitter.com/536ANqBlw9
- Denis (@the_kneeees) December 2, 2023
Frustration was evident among many people, with another posting: "@Ryanair why have I now got to buy a seat to 
access a digital boarding pass that was free for years you're disgraceful and do nothing but congest airports and 
damage your reputation inexorably."
Speaking to The Mail on Sunday, a Ryanair spokesperson said: "Passengers have the choice of choosing a seat 
for a small fee or be randomly allocated a seat free of charge."
The latest fee does not appear to affect all travellers, with some saying they got a digital boarding pass for free.
Load-Date: December 4, 2023

IRISH STOCK REPORT
Ahead of this morning's market opening, Ryanair Holdings has shown some strength in recent days. Ryanair 
Holdings (I:RY4B), Ireland's largest Airline company by market cap, climbed 2.4% during its previous trading 
session to close at EUR18.0.

SECTION 1 TODAY'S BULLISH SIGNALS1.1 Other Bullish SignalsMCap/Total Assets:- Tobin's Q Ratio, defined 
as MCap divided by Total Assets, is 1.4. Compared with the rest of the market the stock is undervalued.- The 
company is cash rich with Cash to Market Capitalisation at 11.4%.
SECTION 2 ONGOING BULLISH PARAMETERS2.1 Satisfies one criterion of Benjamin Graham-"Total debt less 
than tangible book value"; total debt of EUR1.4 billion (US$1.5 billion) is less than tangible book value of EUR5.3 
Investors look to see if Ryanair Holdings ' recent rally will continue
billion (US$6 billion).-"Total debt equal or less than twice the net quick liquidation value"; total debt of EUR1.4 billion 
(US$1.5 billion) is 0.3 times the net liquidation value of EUR4.11 billion (US$4.7 billion).
SECTION 3 TODAY'S BEARISH SIGNALS3.1 Overbought/Bearish Signals:- The Relative Strength Index (RSI) of 
73.4 has penetrated the overbought line of 70, suggesting the price gain of 5.4% in the last 14 days is unusually 
high. - The stock is overbought according to the Williams % R indicator of -3.7, suggesting the price is close to its 
14-day high of EUR18.05.
SECTION 4 ONGOING BEARISH PARAMETERS4.1 Satisfies 3 out of 9 criteria of Joseph Piotroski [pass mark 5]:- 
Positive operating cashflow.- Good quality of earnings [operating cashflow exceeds net income].- Improvement in 
asset turnover [growth in revenue of 193.5% exceeded growth in assets of 22.9%].
But does not meet the following 6 criteria of Joseph Piotroski:- Positive net income.- Return on Assets 
improvement.- Improvement in long-term debt to total assets.- Improvement in current ratio.- Total shares on issue 
unchanged (or reduction in total shares on issue).- Improvement in gross margin.
SECTION 5 PEER COMPARISON & RANKING OF RY4B5.1 LONG-TERM FUNDAMENTAL RANKING: 3 OUT OF 
5 [5 is best]Ryanair Holdings is ranked number 1 out of 1 listed airline in the Ireland with a market capitalization of 
EUR20.5 billion ($22.4 billion). Within its sector it has a relatively high Price/Sales of 4.3. 
Stocks are scored on a set of parameters reflecting fundamental analytical tools involving valuation, size and 
financial performance. They are ranked according to the average values of those parameters. The highest ranking 
is 5 and the lowest ranking is 1.

The Public Prosecutor's Office asks the Audiencia Nacional to condemn Ryanair for violating the right to strike.
The Public Prosecutor's Office asks the Audiencia Nacional to condemn 
Ryanair for violating the right to strike.
CE Noticias Financieras English
December 4, 2023 Monday
Copyright 2023 Content Engine, LLC.
All Rights Reserved
Copyright 2023 CE Noticias Financieras All Rights Reserved
Length: 526 words
Body
The Public Prosecutor's Office of the Audiencia Nacional is requesting the conviction of the airline Ryanair for 
having violated the right to strike of workers belonging to the collective of cabin crew members (TCPS) in the 
stoppages called by the Unión Sindical Obrera (USO) and by the Sindicato Independiente de Tripulantes de 
Tripulantes de Cabina de Pasajeros de Líneas Aéreas (Sitcpla) between June 2022 and January 2023. The 
statement issued by the Public Prosecutor's Office also calls for the conviction of two other companies, 
subcontractors of the airline, for the same reason: Crewlink Ireland LTD and Workforce International Contractors 
LTD.
The strikes were called as a result of repeated claims of job insecurity. It was resolved in a trial held on November 
29, 2023 by the Social Chamber of the National Court that Ryanair "repeatedly and repeatedly carried out acts 
aimed at hindering and preventing the legitimate exercise of the right to strike through acts of different nature". The 
way in which the company acted to hinder the development of the strikes, according to the statement, was through 
the lack of information to workers about the scheduled flights, the abusive designation of the number of workers for 
the provision of minimum services, the use of workers from third states and the warning of disciplinary dismissals.
The unions took the first actions against Ryanair after it failed to comply with the Minimum Services Resolution 
established by the Ministry of Transport on the first strike days scheduled for June 24, 25 and 26 of this year. 
According to the complaint, Ryanair maintained as protected flights all those that were already scheduled, which 
resulted in an illegal setting of 100% of the minimum services. The unions USO and Sitcpla indicated that Ryanair 
workers had to operate those flights by obligation under the guise of minimum services, so they could not exercise 
their right to strike.
Another complaint was filed with the Special Directorate of Labor Inspection and Social Security against the airline 
by USO and Sitcpla, which brought to the attention "multiple irregularities" that Ryanair had committed "with total 
impunity", such as the assignment of guards, both at home and at home.
Background
In the middle of this year, the Supreme Court dismissed the appeal that Ryanair and the two associated firms 
Crewlink Ireland Ltd and Workforce Contractors Ltd filed against the 2021 General Court judgment. This body 
declared that the companies violated the workers' right to strike The stoppages had been called for 10 days in 
The Public Prosecutor's Office asks the Audiencia Nacional to condemn Ryanair for violating the right to strike.
September 2019. For this episode, the high court upheld the compensation to the trade unions UNO-STA and 
Sticpla for the violation of the rights of freedom of association, with the sum of 30,000 euros for each of them.
The decision also obliged the condemned companies to reimburse the workers who took part in the strike with the 
monthly productivity bonus in the amount of 150 euros, from which only the sum of 5 euros could be deducted for 
each day of participation in the strike.
Follow all the information of Economía y Negocios on Facebook and X, or in our weekly newsletter.
Load-Date: December 5, 2023
End of Document

- Denis (@the_kneeees) December 2, 2023
Frustration was evident among many people, with another posting: "@Ryanair why have I now got to buy a seat to 
access a digital boarding pass that was free for years you're disgraceful and do nothing but congest airports and 
damage your reputation inexorably".
Speaking to The Mail on Sunday Ryanair spokesman said: "Passengers have the choice of choosing a seat for a 
small fee or be randomly allocated a seat free of charge."
The latest fee does not appear to affect all travellers, with some saying they got a digital boarding pass for free.
Load-Date: December 4, 2023
End of Document
Ryanair passengers slam 'disgraceful' and 'ridiculous' new add-on charge
Ryanair passengers slam 'disgraceful' and 'ridiculous' new add-on charge
Swindon Advertiser
December 4, 2023 Monday
Copyright 2023 NewsQuest Media Group Limited All Rights Reserved
Length: 408 words
Byline: Carlo Simone
Body
Ryanair has been criticised for a "ridiculous" and "disgraceful" add-on charge where some customers are reportedly 
having to pay a fee to access their digital boarding pass.
The budget airline already charges for add-ons such as checked baggage and booking a seat in advance.
Now it appears that some are being stuck with having to pay a fee to access their digital boarding pass, otherwise 
they will have to queue to collect a printed one from the airport.
Passengers have shared screenshots on X (formerly Twitter), with the airline-s app instructing them to select a 
random seat in advance at a cost of between 8 and 21 if they wish to download their digital boarding pass.
@Ryanair I just can-t believe your new policy of not allowing passengers to create a boarding pass (mobile or print-
out) unless they buy a seat, forcing them to join a check-in queue (30m or longer) to do so for no other reason for 
you to make a few quid. Scandalous. pic.twitter.com/48SMNrbMSV
- Ell- To Pay (@Ell2Pay) December 2, 2023
Airport staff told The Mail on Sunday the change, which has been rolled out in recent days, had caused outrage 
with affected customers.
How did Ryanair passengers react to digital boarding pass charge?
One Ryanair customer posted online: "I just can-t believe your new policy of not allowing passengers to create a 
boarding pass (mobile or print-out) unless they buy a seat, forcing them to join a check-in queue (30m or longer) to 
do so for no other reason for you to make a few quid. Scandalous."
Ryanair passengers slam 'disgraceful' and 'ridiculous' new add-on charge
Another person shared: "@askryanair I know that you're cheap but forcing me to pay for a seat or having to go to 
the airport early to collect a boarding pass in person is RIDICULOUS".
@askryanair I know that you're cheap but forcing me to pay for a seat or having to go to the airport early to collect a 
boarding pass in person is RIDICULOUS pic.twitter.com/536ANqBlw9
- Denis (@the_kneeees) December 2, 2023
Frustration was evident among many people, with another posting: "@Ryanair why have I now got to buy a seat to 
access a digital boarding pass that was free for years you're disgraceful and do nothing but congest airports and 
damage your reputation inexorably".
Speaking to The Mail on Sunday Ryanair spokesman said: "Passengers have the choice of choosing a seat for a 
small fee or be randomly allocated a seat free of charge."
The latest fee does not appear to affect all travellers, with some saying they got a digital boarding pass for free.

43.2% of total shares on issue.

Activities
Ryanair Holdings PLC provides low fare passenger airline services to destinations in Europe. It is the International 
Depository Receipt (IDR) market's largest Airlines company by market capitalisation.

Ryanair has been criticised for a "ridiculous" and "disgraceful" add-on charge where some customers are reportedly 
having to pay a fee to access their digital boarding pass.
The budget airline already charges for add-ons such as checked baggage and booking a seat in advance.
Now it appears that some are being stuck with having to pay a fee to access their digital boarding pass, otherwise 
they will have to queue to collect a printed one from the airport.
Passengers have shared screenshots on X (formerly Twitter), with the airline-s app instructing them to select a 
random seat in advance at a cost of between 8 and 21 if they wish to download their digital boarding pass.
@Ryanair I just can-t believe your new policy of not allowing passengers to create a boarding pass (mobile or print-
out) unless they buy a seat, forcing them to join a check-in queue (30m or longer) to do so for no other reason for 
you to make a few quid. Scandalous. pic.twitter.com/48SMNrbMSV

Airport staff told The Mail on Sunday the change, which has been rolled out in recent days, had caused outrage 
with affected customers.
How did Ryanair passengers react to digital boarding pass charge?
One Ryanair customer posted online: "I just can-t believe your new policy of not allowing passengers to create a 
boarding pass (mobile or print-out) unless they buy a seat, forcing them to join a check-in queue (30m or longer) to 
do so for no other reason for you to make a few quid. Scandalous."

Ryanair breaks silence after claims passengers charged £21 to download boarding pass
Ryanair breaks silence after claims passengers charged £21 to download 
boarding pass
Express Online
December 4, 2023 Monday 10:42 PM GMT
Copyright 2023 Northern and Shell Media Publications All Rights Reserved
Length: 404 words
Byline: Astha Saxena
Body
Ryanair breaks silence after claims passengers charged £21 to download boarding pass 
Ryanair has dismissed the reports about the change to its charging policy and added that passengers have never 
been asked to pay to download boarding passes. The airline company had to issue a statement after there were 
several reports of the airline charging its passengers a fee of £21 to download the boarding pass.
Breaking its silence on the issue, the company said that all these allegations are false even though many travellers 
have complained on social media that they have had to pay a “scandalous” new fee to access their boarding 
passes online.
Many said that they were only able to download the electronic pass if they paid up to £21 for a seat first. The 
alternative was to queue for a paper boarding pass at the airport.
A Ryanair spokesperson said: “All Ryanair passengers can pay for a reserved seat if they so wish or if passengers 
wish to avoid this seat fee, they can select a randomly allocated seat entirely free of charge.”
However, several passengers have complained on social media that if they chose the option of a randomly 
allocated seat they were told they would have to pick up a paper boarding pass at the airport, a problem first 
reported in the Mail on Sunday two days ago.
A series of indignant posts on X, formerly Twitter, have addressed Ryanair directly. One wrote: “When and why did 
you start this carry on? I now have to QUEUE to collect my boarding pass at the airport?"
Another passenger said: "I just can't believe your new policy of not allowing passengers to create a boarding pass 
unless they buy a seat, forcing them to join a check-in queue to do so for no other reason for you to make a few 
quid. Scandalous."
Ryanair breaks silence after claims passengers charged £21 to download boarding pass
"This definitely happened to me," said Neil Buckley, who flew to Riga with Ryanair at the weekend and said he felt 
forced to pay £15.50 for reserved seats - the equivalent of 10 percent of the ticket price. The app said if I opted for a 
free random seat I'd have to go to check-in to get a paper boarding pass, which I've never seen before." 
The budget airline already charges extra for additional hand luggage, hold luggage and boarding pass printing, like 
most other carriers.
Brits travelling abroad or within the UK should be aware that airlines often add extra charges, for services such as 
putting luggage in the hold, booking a specific seat and requesting a seat with extra legroom.
Load-Date: December 4, 2023
End of Document

ADR Recap: Ryanair Holdings continues to outperform Japan Airlines
Activities
Ryanair Holdings PLC provides low fare passenger airline services to destinations in Europe. It is the International 
Depository Receipt (IDR) market's largest Airlines company by market capitalisation.

Ryanair passengers angry at new £21 fee for online boarding pass
Ryanair passengers angry at new £21 fee for online boarding pass
walesonline.co.uk
December 4, 2023 Monday 1:15 PM GMT
Copyright 2023 Reach PLC All Rights Reserved
Section: UK NEWS; Version:2
Length: 243 words
Byline: By, Neil Shaw
Highlight: The system has been rolled out in the last few days and if you don't pay, you have to queue
Body
Ryanair passengers say they are being charged an extra £21 if they want to get their online boarding passes -rather 
than queuing up to get them at the airport. Airport staff have told Mailonline and the BBC the change has been 
rolled out in the last few days.
The system means that you can check in online to get your boarding pass, but in order to print it you then have to 
pick a seat or request a random seat -which will cost you up to £21. To avoid the fee you instead have to queue up 
when you get to the airport to get your boarding pass -despite having checked in online.
Vivien Lovrin told the Mail she checked in but then had a message reading: "Check-in done! Get your boarding 
pass now and avoid queuing at the airport by adding a seat."
Securing a random seat costs £21. She said: "When you thought Ryanair couldn't sink any lower, they find a way to 
force you to buy a seat. How is this legal Isn't the whole point of online check-in to avoid people queuing at the 
airport"
Fabien Mauroy said on X: "Worse experience for people, long queue at airports, [and] polluting planet for money." 
Another passenger said: "When and why did you start this carry on I now have to QUEUE to collect my boarding 
pass at the airport"
Ryanair charges people £55 to print a boarding pass at the airport if you don't check in online.
 A Ryanair spokesman said: "Passengers have the choice of choosing a seat for a small fee or be randomly 
allocated a seat free of charge."
Ryanair passengers angry at new £21 fee for online boarding pass
Load-Date: December 4, 2023
End of Document
Ryanair passengers angry at new £21 fee for online boarding pass
Ryanair passengers angry at new £21 fee for online boarding pass
walesonline.co.uk
December 4, 2023 Monday 1:15 PM GMT
Copyright 2023 Reach PLC All Rights Reserved
Section: NETWORK TRENDING; Version:2
Length: 243 words
Byline: By, Neil Shaw
Highlight: The system has been rolled out in the last few days and if you don't pay, you have to queue
Body
Ryanair passengers say they are being charged an extra £21 if they want to get their online boarding passes -rather 
than queuing up to get them at the airport. Airport staff have told Mailonline and the BBC the change has been 
rolled out in the last few days.
The system means that you can check in online to get your boarding pass, but in order to print it you then have to 
pick a seat or request a random seat -which will cost you up to £21. To avoid the fee you instead have to queue up 
when you get to the airport to get your boarding pass -despite having checked in online.

Prosecutor's Office asks Ryanair to be sentenced for violating the right to strike
Prosecutor's Office asks Ryanair to be sentenced for violating the right to 
strike
CE Noticias Financieras English
December 4, 2023 Monday
Copyright 2023 Content Engine, LLC.
All Rights Reserved
Copyright 2023 CE Noticias Financieras All Rights Reserved
Length: 511 words
Body
The Prosecutor's Office of the Audiencia Nacional has requested that the company Ryanair be sentenced for 
violation of the right to strike of workers belonging to the collective of cabin crew in the stoppages called by USO 
and the Independent Union of Cabin Crew of Airline Passengers (Sitcpla) between June 2022 and January 2023.
This is stated in a note issued by the Public Prosecutor's Office, in which they also report in favor of the conviction 
of two other companies, subcontractors of the airline, for the same reasons: Crewlink Ireland LTD and 
Workforce International Contractors LTD.
The stoppages were the result of repeated claims for labor insecurity, and the Prosecutor's Office, after the trial 
held last November 29 in the Social Chamber of the AN, points out that it has been found that the airline 
"repeatedly and repeatedly carried out acts aimed at hindering and preventing the legitimate exercise of the right to 
strike through acts of various kinds".
Thus, it lists that there was "lack of information to the workers about the scheduled flights", there was an"abusive 
designation of the number of workers for the provision of minimum services", there was a "use of workers from 
third states" and there were warnings of disciplinary dismissals.
It should be recalled that the unions initiated the first legal actions after Ryanair breached, as they denounced, the 
Minimum Services Resolution issued by the Ministry of Transport on the first strike days scheduled for June 24, 
25 and 26 of that year. Ryanair included, they argued, as protected flights all those that were scheduled, resulting 
in an illegal setting of 100% of minimum services.
USO and Sitcpla pointed out that Ryanair crew members were forced to operate those flights under the guise of 
minimum services, so they could not effectively exercise their right to strike.
At the same time, USO and Sitcpla also filed a complaint with the Special Directorate of Labor Inspection and 
Social Security against Ryanair to bring to the attention of this body the "multiple irregularities" that, again, the 
airline would have committed "with total impunity", such as the allocation of guards, both at home and at home, 
which on that first day was 113% more than on any other Friday.
Prosecutor's Office asks Ryanair to be sentenced for violating the right to strike
The Supreme Court ruling
It so happens that in April of this same year, the Supreme Court dismissed an appeal by Ryanair and its 
subcontractors Crewlink Ireland Ltd and Workforce Contractors Ltd against the judgment of the National Court of 
2021 which declared that these companies violated the right to strike of the workers who participated in the strike 
called on 10 days in September 2019, as well as the rights of freedom of association of USO and Sitcpla.
The judgment ratified by the Social Chamber of the Supreme Court declared the radical nullity of several of the 
corporate actions, as contrary to the fundamental rights to strike and freedom of association, and sentenced the 
defendant companies to compensate the two plaintiff unions for moral damages caused with the sum of 30,000 
euros for each of them.
Load-Date: December 5, 2023
End of Document
A budget airline's fee is causing a storm of outrage
A budget airline's fee is causing a storm of outrage
TheStreet.com
December 4, 2023 Monday 5:48 PM EDT
Copyright 2023 TheStreet.com, Inc. All Rights Reserved
Length: 481 words
Byline: TheStreet Staff
Highlight: "I just can't believe your new policy," traveler James Harris wrote on social media.
Body
For low-cost airlines, the entire business model is  luring customers with a base fare for significantly lower than 
what is offered by other airlines and then  with extra fees for things that are also normally covered.
While someone traveling alone for a weekend in a nearby city with no bag can score a good deal, a very common 
complaint is that one  very much at all when fees for everything from baggage and seat selection to a bottle of water 
aboard the flight is factored in.
Over the weekend of Dec. 2 and 3, low-cost airline Ryanair  incurred much customer outrage after some travelers 
started reporting being asked to pay up to £21 ($26.53 USD) to download their boarding pass when checking in for 
their flights - the window that popped up after someone with the lowest ticket fare completes the check-in steps now 
reportedly reads "check-in done! get your boarding pass now and avoid queuing at the airport by adding a seat."
 Check-in pop-up causes a stir (but Ryanair denies making changes) 
Launched in 1985 out of Ireland, Ryanair rose to become the  by offering shuttle-style flights between nearby 
European cities for what in some cases could be as low as (EURO)19.99 ($21). The alternative for those who want 
to avoid the fee is, an airline spokesperson  the BBC, to come to the airport and line up for a physical check-in even 
if they have already checked in online.
More Travel:
"All Ryanair passengers can pay for a reserved seat if they so wish or if passengers wish to avoid this seat fee, they 
can select a randomly allocated seat entirely free of charge," the spokesperson said while denying accusations that 
it added a fee.
A budget airline's fee is causing a storm of outrage
Both budget airlines and mainstream carriers charge economy travelers to select their seat ahead of check-in but, 
in Ryanair's model, those who do not pay extra only get their seat assigned at the airport instead of during online 
check-in like with full-service carriers.
'I just can't believe your new policy,' travelers complain 
Perhaps because more passengers started noticing the fee due to the new pop-up windows, it caused some 
serious discontent among travelers who feel that a boarding pass is a basic part of a plane ticket and should not be 
treated as an "extra" by the airline.
Ryanair has so far not been answering questions on which flights have the ticket fee (most of the customers seeing 
the new pop-ups have so far been in the United Kingdom) but the fee seen by different passengers ranged from £8 
for shorter flights and £21 for longer ones. 
"I just can't believe your new policy," traveler James Harris  on X, the social media platform formerly known as 
Twitter. "Ryanair added friction so you either now pay extra in time or money for something that is standard 
everywhere, i.e. a check in process to receive a ticket that gets you to the gate. I don't mind random seat allocation, 
but this newly added extra step is just wrong."
Load-Date: December 4, 2023
End of Document
Ryanair passengers hit out at ‘new fee’
Ryanair passengers hit out at ‘new fee’
Belfast Telegraph Online
December 4, 2023 Monday 1:15 PM GMT
Copyright 2023 Independent News & Media (Northern Ireland) All Rights Reserved
Length: 271 words
Byline: Eimear McGovern
Body
Ryanair passengers have hit out after claims the budget airline has added a new fee to charge for e-boarding 
passes.
Some said they have been charged up to £21 to obtain the pass - or alternatively, queue for a paper pass at the 
airport, according to the BBC.
The development was first reported by Mail Online after passengers took to social media to vent their frustration. It's 
not clear when the charge may have been introduced.
Ryanair has been asked for comment by the Belfast Telegraph.
One passenger contacted the airline on X, formerly known as Twitter. "When and why did you start this carry on? I 
now have to QUEUE to collect my boarding pass at the airport?" he asked.
Another said: "So what's this forcing people to buy seats after purchasing a flight or queue for a boarding pass all 
about? I thought the option to take a random seat was to avoid extra queues? Another cash gathering exercise?"
Airline passengers are commonly asked to check-in online and confirm their intention to take the flight, often 
downloading an electronic copy of their boarding pass at the same time. Passengers can also choose to pick up a 
paper copy at the airport but are not usually charged to do so.
Ryanair now appear to be asking some passengers to book a seat, which costs between £7 and £21 before they 
can download their boarding pass. If they do not book a seat, they have to queue for a pass at the airport.
Over the years budget airlines have added on charges for add-ons such as putting luggage in the hold, booking 
seats or choosing a seat with extra legroom. Companies often claim it's a measure to retain a low-price structure.
Ryanair passengers hit out at ‘new fee’
Load-Date: December 4, 2023
End of Document

Ryanair Holdings PLC (O:RYAAY) last traded at $121.46 for a year to date return of 62.5%.Ryanair Holdings PLC's 
(O: RYAAY $121.47) ADR price hit a 52-week high of $121.78 during the day. In the past month the ADR has hit a 
new 52-week high nine times, pointing to a significant uptrend. 
Ryanair Holdings' ADR price lifted $1.30 (1.1%) from its previous trading session to close at $121.47. 
Compared with the BNY Mellon Composite ADR Index which fell 1.5 points (0.9%) in the day, the relative price 
increase was 2.0%. 
Ryanair Holdings PLC is the International Depository Receipt (IDR) market's largest Airlines company by market 
cap. 
Today its volatility (highest price minus lowest price/lowest price) of 2.6% was 1.2 times its average daily volatility of 
2.1%. The stock traded between its 657-day high of $121.78 and its three-day low of $118.67 today. 
There were 708,109 ADRs worth $86 million traded today.

Ryanair in hot water over new £21 charge and passengers say 'you are ridiculous'
Ryanair in hot water over new £21 charge and passengers say 'you are 
ridiculous'
birminghammail.co.uk
December 4, 2023 Monday 3:10 PM GMT
Copyright 2023 Reach PLC All Rights Reserved
Section: MIDLANDS NEWS; Version:1
Length: 346 words
Byline: By, James Rodger
Highlight: Until recently, the airline provided people with their digital boarding passes for free via their app.
Body
Ryanair passengers are being forced to pay £21 for a new hidden fee - or face huge airport queues. Until recently, 
the airline provided people with their digital boarding passes for free via their app.
But now passengers now have to pay between £7 and £21 for a randomly allocated seat, which will then allow them 
to have their pass on their phone before travelling to the airport. Those who don't pay up will have to wait in line to 
get their boarding pass at the check-in desks instead. 
"Charging for a mobile boarding pass You are ridiculous," fumed one user on Twitter/X in a tweet to the budget 
carrier. A second Ryanair passenger moaned: "I just can't believe your new policy of not allowing passengers to 
create a boarding pass mobile or print-out unless they buy a seat.
"Forcing them to join a check-in queue 30m or longer to do so for no other reason for you to make a few quid. 
Scandalous." A spokesperson from the budget carrier told Mail Online: "Passengers have the choice of choosing a 
seat for a small fee or be randomly allocated a seat free of charge."
Another raged: "If a passenger requires oxygen for medical reasons they are not allowed to bring their own and 
must pay 55 to use Ryanair's. WHAT !!!" Defending the carrier, one said: "If you don't like it don't use them. Last 
time we travelled overseas it actually worked out much cheaper and quicker to fly with a reputable airline when all 
the extras were taken into account."
Ryanair in hot water over new £21 charge and passengers say 'you are ridiculous'
Bambino agreed and said: "Have any of these negative commenting people flown regularly or flown ryan air If you 
holiday regularly via a third party then you don't get to choose the airline. I flew with on the beach and Ryan Air was 
already pre chosen. I flew to Crete with them in October. Got extra leg room, plane was fine, staff were polite. 
"Small hand luggage to fit under the seat as no overhead cabins which was fine for us. Only down side is you don't 
get any free food or drink or USB/C ports or tv's . But it wasn't a problem. They were fast to unload, turn around 
time and load the next lot on. No problems and efficient."
Load-Date: December 4, 2023
End of Document
Ryanair slashes 960 flights due to Middle East conflict as passenger numbers fall
Ryanair slashes 960 flights due to Middle East conflict as passenger 
numbers fall
Cityam.com
December 4, 2023 Monday 3:29 PM GMT
Copyright 2023 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Length: 240 words
Byline: Guy Taylor
Highlight: Ryanair cancelled 960 flights in November due to the conflict between Israel and Hamas, it has been 
revealed. In a report, the low-cost airline said it flew 11.7m passengers in November, a four per cent increase on 
the prior year and taking its 2023 total to 180.8m. The number marks a significant dip on October’s [...]
Body
Ryanair cancelled 960 flights in November due to the conflict between Israel and Hamas, it has been revealed.
In a report, the low-cost airline said it flew 11.7m passengers in November, a four per cent increase on the prior 
year and taking its 2023 total to 180.8m.
The number marks a significant dip on October’s figure of 17.1m. Load factor, the proportion of seats filled by 
passengers, sat at 92 per cent.
Airline shares dipped after Hamas invaded Israel last month, amid investor concern over route offerings and a spike 
in oil prices. The Irish carrier already cancelled over 870 flights in October due to the violence in the Middle East.
Ryanair has been one of the few major carriers to see shares continue rising in the quieter autumn months, 
following this summer’s record season of travel.
Budget rival Wizz Air reported a more measured fall in November’s passenger numbers this morning, carrying 4.8m 
passengers, down from 5.4m the priot month.
The Hungarian-based firm said it had decided to suspend operations in Israel until early January 2024, adding that 
it continues to “monitor the situation on the ground closely and stands ready to redeploy capacity should conditions 
stabilize.”
Chief executive József Váradi toldCity A.M. in early November that the war had created a “ripple effect” on demand 
across neighbouring countries in the region.
Ryanair slashes 960 flights due to Middle East conflict as passenger numbers fall
Read more
Ryanair and Wizz Air passenger numbers dip as Middle East conflict axes routes
Load-Date: December 4, 2023
End of Document

SECTION 1  PRE-MARKET CUES FROM ITS ADR TRADING: (RYAAY: US$119.91) 
+ Ryanair Holdings ADR (Ireland ADR: NASDAQ RYAAY US$119.91) hits year-high 8th time in one month; +$1.95 
[1.6%] Vol Index 1.2.STOCKS HITTING HIGHS
ADR Daily: Ryanair Holdings ADR (RYAAY: US$119.91) hits year-high 8th time in three months
Ryanair Holdings PLC's (O: RYAAY US$119.91) ADR price hit a 52-week high of US$120.19 during the day. In the 
last three months the ADR has hit a new 52-week high eight times, pointing to a significant uptrend.
Ryanair Holdings' ADR price lifted US$1.69 (1.4%) from its previous trading session to close at US$119.91.
Compared with the BNY Mellon Composite ADR Index which rose 0.9 points (0.6%) in the day, the relative price 
increase was 0.9%.
Ryanair Holdings PLC is the International Depository Receipt (IDR) market's largest Airlines company by market 
cap.
There were 441,436 ADRs worth US$52.9 million traded today.

SECTION 3  STOCKS HITTING CONSECUTIVE HIGHS
Ryanair Holdings (RY4B: EUR18.0) hits year-high 6th time in one month
Ryanair Holdings PLC's (I: RY4B EUR18.0) stock price hit a 52-week high of EUR18.05 during the day. In the past 
month the stock has hit a new 52-week high six times, pointing to an uptrend.
Ryanair Holdings' stock price climbed 42.0c (2.4%) from its previous trading session to close at EUR18.0.
Compared with the ISEQ Overall Index which rose 110.4 points (1.3%) in the day, the relative price increase was 
1.1%.
Ryanair Holdings PLC is Ireland's largest Airline company by market cap.

SECTION 5  TODAY'S BULLISH SIGNALS5.1  PAST WEEK: MODERATE MOMENTUM UPRY4B increases 3.9% 
on average volume 0.96 times average. Compared with the ISEQ Overall Index which rose 200.1 points (or 2.4%) 
in the week, the relative price increase was 1.4%.
Week 48 of 2023: Up 3.9%; Ryanair Holdings (RY4B) outperformed the ISEQ Overall Index in 3 out of 5 days. The 
price ranged between a high of EUR18.0 on Friday Dec 01 and a low of EUR17.13 on Monday Nov 27.
5.2  Uptrend
The stock traded at a thirty one-month high of EUR18.05 today.Price/Moving Average Price of 1.07 and positive 
MACD:- The Price/MAP 200 for Ryanair Holdings is 1.07. Being higher than 1 is a bullish indicator. It is higher than 
the Price/MAP 200 for the ISEQ Overall Index of 1.0, a second bullish indicator. The 200-day MAP has increased to 
EUR16.76, a third bullish indicator.- The Moving Average Convergence Divergence (MACD) indicator of 12-day 
Exponential Moving Average (EMA) of 17.36 minus the 26-day EMA of 16.83 is positive, suggesting a bullish signal. 
Both the 12-day EMA as well as the 26-day EMA are rising, another bullish signal.- The price to 50-day EMAP ratio 
is 1.1, a bullish indicator. The 50-day EMAP has increased to EUR16.41. An increase is another bullish indicator.
Past Month:- Rises to Falls: In the past month the number of rises outnumbered falls 15:5 or 3:1.
Ryanair Holdings (RY4B: EUR18.0) - PRE-MARKET CONFIRMATORY BULLISH SIGNAL FROM ITS ADR 
MARKET Monday December 04, 2023 06:12 GMT
- The shares had their best quarter in three quarters since the quarter ended March 01, 2023.In the last three 
months the stock has hit a new 52-week high six times, pointing to an uptrend. The Best 3 weeks in the past 
quarterThe past month witnessed the best 2 weeks in the past quarter. In the past quarter the week beginning 
Monday November 06 saw the highest weekly rise of 10.1% for a relative price increase of 13.1%. The rise was 
propped up by volume of 1.9 times average.
5.3  Other Bullish SignalsMCap/Total Assets:- Tobin's Q Ratio, defined as MCap divided by Total Assets, is 1.4. 
Compared with the rest of the market the stock is undervalued.- The company is cash rich with Cash to Market 
Capitalisation at 11.4%.
SECTION 6  ONGOING BULLISH PARAMETERS6.1  The Best Periods [3 Mo, 1 Yr] with Price Change % > 11.41-
Year price change of 38% for Ryanair Holdings outperformed the change of 16.5% in the ISEQ Overall Index for a 
relative price change of 21.6%.
6.2  Annualised Period-based Total Shareholder Returns [TSR %]: The Best Periods with TSR > 5.5%
6.3  Low Debt to Equity (%) and ReducingThe debt to equity ratio of 24.6% is under a safe benchmark figure of 
50%. Moreover, it has improved from 41.1% a year ago.
6.4  Increased VWAP, up 41% in 5 yearsIn the past five years Volume Weighted Average Price (VWAP) has 
increased by 40.6% to EUR15.42.
6.5  Increased share turnoverIn the past five years, average daily share turnover has increased 1.7% to EUR25.9 
million ($28.3 million). This suggests increased liquidity.
6.6  Satisfies one criterion of Benjamin Graham-"Total debt less than tangible book value"; total debt of EUR1.4 
billion (US$1.5 billion) is less than tangible book value of EUR5.3 billion (US$6 billion).-"Total debt equal or less 
than twice the net quick liquidation value"; total debt of EUR1.4 billion (US$1.5 billion) is 0.3 times the net 
liquidation value of EUR4.11 billion (US$4.7 billion).
SECTION 7  TODAY'S BEARISH SIGNALS7.1  Overbought/Bearish Signals:
- The Relative Strength Index (RSI) of 73.4 has penetrated the overbought line of 70, suggesting the price gain of 
5.4% in the last 14 days is unusually high.- The stock is overbought according to the Williams % R indicator of -3.7, 
suggesting the price is close to its 14-day high of EUR18.05.
SECTION 8  ONGOING BEARISH PARAMETERS8.1  Stock vs Index (Annual Percentage Change)
Over 5 years Ryanair Holdings is up a total 13.6% at an annualized rate of 3.2% compared to the Index being up 
29.7% at an annualized rate of 6.7%.
Ryanair Holdings has outperformed the ISEQ Overall Index in 2 of the past 5years: 2020, 2019.
8.2  Declining Volume, down 25% in 5 yearsIn the past five years, Average Daily Volume of Trading (ADVT) has 
decreased 24.7% to 1.8 million shares.
8.3  Satisfies 3 out of 9 criteria of Joseph Piotroski [pass mark 5]:- Positive operating cashflow.- Good quality of 
earnings [operating cashflow exceeds net income].- Improvement in asset turnover [growth in revenue of 193.5% 
exceeded growth in assets of 22.9%].
But does not meet the following 6 criteria of Joseph Piotroski:- Positive net income.- Return on Assets 
improvement.- Improvement in long-term debt to total assets.- Improvement in current ratio.- Total shares on issue 
unchanged (or reduction in total shares on issue).- Improvement in gross margin.

DAILY ADR AND DEPOSITORY RECEIPT REPORT
www.buysellsignals.com
Ryanair Holdings (O:RYAAY), the International Depository Receipt (IDR) market's largest Airlines company by 
market cap, has been up $28.82 (or 32.2%) in the past month to close at $118.22 on Thursday November 30. 
Compared with the BNY Mellon Composite ADR Index which rose 10.4 points (or 7.0%) in the month, this 
represented a relative price increase of 25%. 
The price ranged between a low of 89.5 on Wednesday, 1 Nov and a high of 118.3 on Wednesday, 29 Nov. In the 
past month the market cap has jumped by $7 billion to $26.9 billion.

2.2 Top 5 Institutional Ownership of Ryanair Holdings as at September 30, 2023
As at September 30, 2023, 251 Institutions (Funds) held investments in ADRs of Ryanair Holdings. Institutions 
increased their holdings to 43.2% of issued capital, up from 43.2% as at Jun 30. The largest ADRholder was Capital 
International Investors with 5% of Ryanair Holdings. The second largest ADRholder was Massachusetts Financial 
Services with 5%. 
*Note: Minimum Core ADRholding is computed on the basis of SEC filings over the last 12 quarters (3 years). A 
higher % of ADRholding above the minimum core holding may be indicative of a potential positioning by an active 
institution to overweight.

2.3 Institutional ownership of RYAAY at Sep 30: Cornerstone Planning Group top increase of 1,524% 
As at September 30, 2023, 68 institutions or 26.4% of RYAAY's institutional ADRholders had increased their 
holding of ADRs in Ryanair Holdings from June 30. The top increase was by Cornerstone Planning Group which 
increased its holding by 259 ADRs, or 1,523.5% to 276 ADRs.
