JP McMahon’s insider guide to Copenhagen
JP McMahon’s insider guide to Copenhagen
thetimes.co.uk
December 3, 2023 Sunday 12:01 AM GMT
Copyright 2023 News International Ltd All Rights Reserved
Length: 1077 words
Byline: Patrick Hanlon
Highlight: The culinary genius behind Galway’s Aniar and Cava Bodega, reveals his top spots for dining, drinking 
and mooching about the Danish capital
Body
                   The chef and restaurateur JP McMahon is the owner and culinary director of the Michelin-starred Aniar 
Restaurant (and Boutique Cookery School) and the Spanish restaurant Cava Bodega in Galway city. In 2015 he 
founded the international culinary symposium Food on the Edge and in 2022 launched the JP McMahon Culinary 
Consultancy. He has written two cookbooks:                   The Irish Cookbook                   The Irish Cookbook                  
and                   An Alphabet of Aniar                   An Alphabet of Aniar                   .                   
Copenhagen is a culinary mecca with an amazing density of wonderful restaurants, cafés and wine bars. I’ve 
always had a fascination with Nordic cuisine and Copenhagen is a huge inspiration for me. I travel there once or 
twice a year, squeezing so much into every trip. Food culture is to the fore in Copenhagen and it excels at food 
tourism, something I feel we could do way more here in Ireland.
It’s famous for “new Nordic cuisine”, but while many of Copenhagen’s Michelin-starred restaurants still maintain this 
unique approach, other restaurants do not limit themselves to this dogma. Copenhagen is also famous for its 
bakeries and pretty much pioneered the global resurgence in sourdough.
                   Getting there and getting around                   
Fly direct from Dublin on SAS or Ryanair. You can hop on the metro straight from Kastrup airport and reach the city 
centre in about 20 minutes. Taxis are very expensive.
What makes Copenhagen such a joy to get around is that you can cycle everywhere — simply rent a bike. The 
locals cycle everywhere and there are designated cycle ways across the city, but be careful in rush hour — it gets a 
little dog-eat-dog in the cycle lane.
                   When to visit and best places to base yourself                   
JP McMahon’s insider guide to Copenhagen
I love to visit at any time of the year, though I think early summer in Copenhagen is perhaps the nicest. It’s quite 
cold in winter, but the classically styled city centre amusement park Tivoli Gardens (
tivoli.dk/en
) is particularly fantastic and festive at Christmas time.
Public transport in Copenhagen is really good, so anywhere in the city centre — Indre By — is perfect as a base. 
However, I love Norrebro and Vesterbro is very good for nightlife. I often stay in the Wakeup hotels (
wakeupcopenhagen.com
). They’re cheap, clean and cheerful and may help towards offsetting the money you’re going to spend on food and 
wine.
                   One unforgettable restaurant                   
I think I’ve eaten in Noma (
noma.dk
) seven or eight times, but my most memorable meal was the first time I ate there — in its former location — when I 
first visited the city in 2015. That weekend we also ate at Geranium (
geranium.dk
) and several other Michelin-starred spots — quite a lot in two days, even for me! The sheer brilliance of the food at 
Noma will for ever remain with me. Aniar’s first head chef, Enda McEvoy [the co-owner of Ean in Galway and 
former chef-owner of Michelin-starred Loam], did a stage [chef internship] at Noma in 2011 and that influenced so 
much of what we do in Aniar, from zoning in on local and wild food to embracing seaweed.
                   Plus a couple more to try                   
While Noma is the most memorable, I’ve had some amazing meals at Kadeau (
kadeau.dk
), now one of my favourite restaurants on the planet, and others now sadly closed like Amass, Geist and Relae. A 
meal at the multisensory restaurant Alchemist (
alchemist.dk
) takes about six hours and is global in its molecular approach rather than new Nordic.
Christian Puglisi is a benchmark of good cooking in Copenhagen. He began with Relae and Manfreds — where I 
had the most transformative beef tartare of my life, so much so it inspired me to open Tartare in Galway His pizzeria 
Baest (
baest.dk/en
) is probably the best pizza in Copenhagen.
On my last trip we visited an Italian restaurant called Barabba (
barabba.dk
), where they make their own pasta and serve memorable small plates coupled with a great wine list. For my next 
trip, two Michelin-starred Koan (
JP McMahon’s insider guide to Copenhagen
koancph.dk
) is top of my wish list.
                   Where to get coffee                   
Copenhagen has a great café culture. A favourite spot for coffee or breakfast is Atelier September (
cafeatelierseptember.com
). Its smorrebrod (open-faced rye bread sandwich) is worth trying. If you want to splash out on brunch, check out 
Palaegade (
formelfamily.dk/palaegade
).
                   A great place for a drink                   
My favourite wine bar is Ved Stranden 10 (
vedstranden10.dk
) and as locations go it doesn’t get much better, right by the canal. It was at the forefront of the natural wine 
revolution that is now widespread across the world. Clubs open round the clock in the city but my dancing days are 
over! These days after a good meal, a couple of glasses of wine in a relaxed bar for the evening suits me.
                   Watching the budget                   
Copenhagen makes Ireland look cheap, so expect to pay more for everything, from your coffee in the morning to 
your glass of wine in the evening. I think budgeting a couple of hundred euros a day would cover everything. Fine 
dining is obviously the extreme end of the spectrum and can blow the budget, but even good casual dining spots 
will set you back about €200. They have a higher tax on food and wine in restaurants — 25 per cent, Ireland is 13.5 
per cent Also, wages are considerably better for chefs in restaurants over in Denmark so you pay the price of this 
difference.
                   One thing you must see or do                   
The boat around the canals is a little “touristy” but does give you a good bearing on the city. There’s lots of different 
ones, from eco-friendly GoBoat and kayak trips to the bigger Netto and classic canal boats — the latter two are 
included in Wonderful Copenhagen’s Copenhagen Card (
copenhagencard.com
; from €62 for 24-hour adult tickets). In terms of overhyped touristy things, I wouldn’t recommend 
                   The Little Mermaid                   
 statue.
                   Copenhagen summed up in one sentence?                    
A beautiful, historic city with some of the best restaurants, cafés and wine bars — a few days spent in Copenhagen 
will add more hygge to your life.
                   Interview by Patrick Hanlon                    aniarrestaurant.ie
; 
JP McMahon’s insider guide to Copenhagen
cavarestaurant.ie
; 
@mistereatgalway
Load-Date: December 2, 2023
End of Document
I know the perfect place: Copenhagen, Denmark JP McMahon, the culinary genius behind Galway city's Aniar 
and Cava Bodega restaurants, reveals his all-time top s....
I know the perfect place: Copenhagen, Denmark; JP McMahon, the culinary 
genius behind Galway city's Aniar and Cava Bodega restaurants, reveals his 
all-time top spots for dining, drinking and mooching about the Danish 
capital
The Sunday Times (London)
December 3, 2023 Sunday
Edition 1, Ireland
Copyright 2023 Times Newspapers Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: HOME;FEATURES; Pg. 15
Length: 981 words
Byline: Patrick Hanlon
Body
The chef and restaurateur JP McMahon is the owner and culinary director of the Michelin-starred Aniar Restaurant 
(and Boutique Cookery School) and the Spanish restaurant Cava Bodega in Galway city. In 2015 he founded the 
international culinary symposium Food on the Edge and in 2022 launched the JP McMahon Culinary Consultancy. 
He has written two cookbooks: The Irish Cookbook and An Alphabet of Aniar. aniarrestaurant.ie; cavarestaurant.ie; 
@mistereatgalway Copenhagen is a culinary mecca with an amazing density of wonderful restaurants, cafés and 
wine bars. I've always had a fascination with Nordic cuisine and Copenhagen is a huge inspiration for me. I travel 
there once or twice a year, squeezing so much into every trip. Food culture is to the fore in Copenhagen and it

and Cava Bodega restaurants, reveals his all-time top s....
classically styled city centre amusement park Tivoli Gardens (tivoli.dk/en) is particularly fantastic and festive at

as a base. However, I love Norrebro and Vesterbro is very good for nightlife. I often stay in the Wakeup hotels

you're going to spend on food and wine.
ONE UNFORGETTABLE RESTAURANT I think I've eaten in Noma (noma.dk) seven or eight times, but my most 
memorable meal was the first time I ate there - in its former location - when I first visited the city in 2015. That 
weekend we also ate at Geranium (geranium.dk) and several other Michelinstarred spots - quite a lot in two days, 
even for me! The sheer brilliance of the food at Noma will for ever remain with me. Aniar's first head chef, Enda 
McEvoy [the coowner of Ean in Galway and former chef-owner of the Michelin-starred Loam], did a stage [chef 
internship] at Noma in 2011 and that influenced so much of what we do in Aniar, from zoning in on local and wild 
food to embracing seaweed. PLUS A COUPLE MORE TO TRY While Noma is the most memorable, I've had some 
amazing meals at Kadeau (kadeau.dk), now one of my favourite restaurants on the planet, and others now sadly 
closed like Amass, Geist and Relae. A meal at the multisensory restaurant Alchemist (alchemist.dk) takes six hours 
and is global in its molecular approach rather than new Nordic.
Christian Puglisi is a benchmark of good cooking in Copenhagen. He began with Relae and Manfreds - where I had 
the most transformative beef tartare of my life, so much so it inspired me to open Tartare in Galway His pizzeria 
Baest (baest.dk/ en) is probably the best pizza in Copenhagen.
On my last trip we visited an Italian restaurant called Barabba (barabba.dk), where they make their own pasta and 
serve memorable small plates coupled with a great wine list. For my next trip, the two Michelin-starred Koan 
(koancph.dk) is top of my wish list.
WHERE TO GET COFFEE Copenhagen has a great café culture. A favourite spot for coffee or breakfast is Atelier 
September (cafeatelier www.september.com). Its smorrebrod (open-faced rye bread sandwich) is worth trying. If 
you want to splash out on brunch, check out Palaegade (formelfamily.dk/ palaegade).
A GREAT PLACE FOR A DRINK My favourite wine bar is Ved Stranden 10 (vedstranden 10.dk) and as locations 
go it doesn't get much better, right by the canal. It was at the forefront of the natural wine revolution that is now 
widespread across the world. Clubs open round the clock in the city but my dancing days are over! These days 
after a good meal, a couple of glasses of wine in a relaxed bar for the evening suits me. WATCHING THE BUDGET 
Copenhagen makes Ireland look cheap, so expect to pay more for everything, from your coffee in the morning to 
your glass of wine in the evening. I think budgeting a couple of hundred euros a day would cover everything. Fine 
dining is obviously the extreme end of the spectrum and can blow the budget, but even good casual dining spots 
will set you back about (EURO)200. They have a higher tax on food and wine in restaurants - 25 per cent, Ireland is 
13.5 per cent. Also, wages are considerably better for chefs in restaurants over in Denmark so you pay the price of 
this difference.
ONE THING YOU MUST SEE OR DO The boat around the canals is a little touristy but does give you a good 
bearing on the city. There's lots of different ones, from eco-friendly GoBoat and kayak trips to the bigger Netto and 
classic canal boats - the latter two are included in Wonderful Copenhagen's Copenhagen Card 
(copenhagencard.com; from (EURO)62 for 24-hour adult tickets). In terms of overhyped touristy things, I wouldn't 
recommend The Little Mermaid statue. COPENHAGEN SUMMED UP IN ONE SENTENCE? A beautiful, historic 
city with some of the best restaurants, cafés and wine bars - a few days spent in Copenhagen will add more hygge 
to your life. Interview by Patrick Hanlon
Graphic
 
I know the perfect place: Copenhagen, Denmark JP McMahon, the culinary genius behind Galway city's Aniar 
and Cava Bodega restaurants, reveals his all-time top s....
JP McMahon says that while Copenhagen is a foodie paradise, eating out is much pricier than it is in Ireland
Load-Date: December 3, 2023
End of Document
Ryanair in fake parts discovery
Ryanair in fake parts discovery
Daily Record and Sunday Mail
December 3, 2023 Sunday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2023 Copyright © 2021 Reach PLC All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 11
Length: 94 words
Body
Two Ryanair planes have been identified as having fake engine parts, the airline's boss has admitted.
It is the latest airline to be hit by the scandal which had already affected Southwest Airlines, American Airlines and 
Delta Air Lines.
Parts have been found during maintenance checks in Brazil and Texas.
Ryanair chief executive Michael O'Leary said the fake components are from UK supplier AOG Technics, which is 
not one of Ryanair's approved suppliers, it was reported.
Ryanair was asked for comment.
At the time of publishing AOG Technics website had been taken down.
Load-Date: December 3, 2023
End of Document
Cheapskate O'Leary in RTÉ would never take off DECEMBER 3 • 2023 The Irish Mail on Sunday COMMENT 
27 Mary Carr carr@mailonsunday.ie COLUMNIST OF THE YEAR
Cheapskate O'Leary in RTÉ would never take off; DECEMBER 3 • 2023 The 
Irish Mail on Sunday COMMENT 27 Mary Carr carr@mailonsunday.ie 
COLUMNIST OF THE YEAR
Mail on Sunday (London)
December 3, 2023 Sunday
Edition 1, Ireland
Copyright 2023 Associated Newspapers Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: FEATURES; OPINION, COLUMN; Pg. 27
Length: 197 words
Byline: Mary Carr
Body
IT seems improbable that Ryanair's Michael O'Leary is joining in the national wave of appreciation for Shane 
MacGowan's visionary flair and creative brilliance. For on the subject of his favourite RTÉ radio shows, the budget 
airline founder showed little patience for music or phone-in chat shows like Liveline, much preferring a diet of 
current affairs and news.
Comparing the State broadcaster with Aer Lingus in the 1980s, he said: 'RTÉ is probably overstaffed, it's certainly 
badly run. Would I like to see RTÉ survive? Yes, clearly, I think the area of news in RTÉ does a very good job, but 
there's lots of areas of RTÉ that frankly, if they disappeared tomorrow, I wouldn't lose too much sleep over it.'
O'Leary singled out Joe Duffy's religious programmes and Liveline as expendable, adding 'Ryan Tubridy playing 
records for an hour' was 'a complete waste of time'. Tastes differ, of course, and it behoves the State broadcaster to 
cater for all.
But isn't it ironic that the programmes Michael O'Leary values most are those that the ruthlessly commercial 
entrepreneur would probably take an axe to and replace with cheapas-chips chat shows had he the running of a 
broadcast service?
Load-Date: December 3, 2023
End of Document
O'Leary calls for new laws after fake jet parts scam
O'Leary calls for new laws after fake jet parts scam
Daily Mirror
December 3, 2023 Sunday
Edition 1, Ireland
Copyright 2023 Reach PLC All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 2
Length: 166 words
Byline: SHANE POWER
Body
RYANAIR chief Michael O'Leary has called for tighter regulations on aircraft parts suppliers after the budget carrier 
was hit by an international scam.
The airline found fake engine parts in two of its planes during maintenance checks in Texas and Brazil, which have 
since been removed.
Major US carriers Delta Air Lines, American Airlines and Southwest Airlines have also found suspect parts believed 
to have come from a bogus UK-based supplier.
Mr O'Leary said: "Given the level of paperwork that exists, I'm not quite sure how anybody was able to come up 
with dodgy parts."
The UK's aviation watchdog announced in August it was "investigating the supply of a large number of suspect 
unapproved parts" that could be traced to one supplier.
The Civil Aviation Authority issued a safety notice warning airlines that some of the parts were used in engines fitted 
to British planes.
The European Union Aviation Safety Agency said in August it was examining reports of parts with suspected 
falsified documents.
O'Leary calls for new laws after fake jet parts scam
Graphic
 
OUTRAGE Michael O'Leary
Load-Date: December 3, 2023
End of Document
A warning to prohibitionists
A warning to prohibitionists
Newstex Blogs 
Adam Smith Institute Blog
December 3, 2023 Sunday 6:01 AM EST
Copyright 2023 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 446 words
Byline: Tim Worstall
Body
Dec 03, 2023( Adam Smith Institute Blog: http://www.adamsmith.org/blog Delivered by Newstex)  
 This is true of booze, of drugs, of tobacco and, yes, jet engine parts[1]:  
Ryanair has found 'fake parts' in two of its aircraft engines during scheduled maintenance checks, becoming the 
latest airline to be impacted by a brewing scandal. 
The parts were discovered during assessment in Texas and Brazil over the past few months and have since been 
removed from the engines, the low-cost carrier's chief executive Michael O'Leary told Bloomberg News. 
It comes as the global aviation industry is grappling with a fake parts scandal that has left airlines and regulators 
scrambling to assess engines and trace equipment. 
We do not, of course condone this. But we do know quite a bit about it as a result of having been out there in that 
international and global economy for all these decades.  
The difficulty is that the nut, bolt or screw for a jet engine is worth 5x to 10x with the right piece of paper than it is 
without. Let's not make the situation more complicated than that. It's righteous that it should too, traceability of parts 
in something so complex, so horrendous in effects if failure occurs, is a very good idea indeed. 
But, it's always going to happen that people will try to trade across a 5x to 10x price difference. Note that this is not 
a result of markets or capitalism. This isn't neoliberalism run riot - this is just what happens among humans. This 
also doesn't mean that people who do even fake jet engine parts should not be righteously jugged, not that we 
should not investigate allegations of it - as here, allegations only so far. 
What it does mean is that governments simply cannot go around creating 5x and 10x price differences as will be 
true of banning tobacco and so on. Because people simply will trade across those differences. As they do with 
drugs, at large scale, and as currently also does happen with both tobacco and booze.  
With jet engines the consumers - the airlines - absolutely do not want fake parts at any price. For knowing use of 
them would likely violate both their insurances and also their licences. Now switch the model to one where 
consumers do desire the item on offer - drugs, booze, baccy. There is that demand, there is that profit margin, trade 
will happen across it. 
This then being the message for the prohibitionists. Even if it were true that society would be better without these 
things - it wouldn't - it still won't work. And there's absolutely no point at all in implementing a policy that won't work. 
So, don't. 
 [ 1]: https://www.telegraph.co.uk/business/2023/12/01/ryanair-caught-fake-airline-parts-scandal/ 
A warning to prohibitionists
Notes

IRISH END-OF-WEEK STOCK REPORT
www.buysellsignals.com
Ryanair Holdings (I:RY4B EUR18.0), Ireland's largest Airline company by market cap, has lifted 67.0c (or 3.9%) in 
the past week to close at EUR18.0. Compared with the ISEQ Overall Index which rose 200.1 points (or 2.4%) in the 
week, this represented a relative price increase of 1.4%. 
The price ranged between a high of EUR18.0 on Friday Dec 01 and a low of EUR17.13 on Monday Nov 27. In the 
past week the market cap has risen by EUR762.9 million ($832.1 million) to EUR20.5 billion. 
Total volume in the week equalled the average trading of 8.8 million shares. 
Bearish Turning Point
Relative Strength Index (RSI)The Relative Strength Index (RSI) of 73.4 has penetrated the overbought line of 70, 
suggesting the price gain of 5.4% in the last 14 days is unusually high. The RSI was previously 68.6.

Ryanair Holdings Share price was EUR13.04. EUR969 would have bought 74.3 Ryanair Holdings Shares on that 
day. Those 74.3 Shares would be worth EUR1,338 at today's Share price of EUR18.0. At today's exchange rate of 
USD1=0.92 EUR this is equivalent to USD1,459. PV$1000= $1,459.

Friday's price upRyanair Holdings hits year-high 6th time in one monthRyanair Holdings PLC's (I: RY4B EUR18.0) 
stock price hit a 52-week high of EUR18.05 during the day. In the past month the stock has hit a new 52-week high

increase was 1.1%. Ryanair Holdings PLC is Ireland's largest Airline company by market cap. There were 
2,530,000 shares worth EUR45.5 million ($49.7 million) traded today. Friday's price rise was propped up by robust 
volume of 1.4 times the average daily volume of 1.8 million shares.

1.3 UptrendThe stock traded at a thirty one-month high of EUR18.05 today. Price/Moving Average Price of 1.07 and 
positive MACD:- The Price/MAP 200 for Ryanair Holdings is 1.07. Being higher than 1 is a bullish indicator. It is 
higher than the Price/MAP 200 for the ISEQ Overall Index of 1.0, a second bullish indicator. The 200-day MAP has 
increased to EUR16.76, a third bullish indicator.- The Moving Average Convergence Divergence (MACD) indicator 
of 12-day Exponential Moving Average (EMA) of 17.36 minus the 26-day EMA of 16.83 is positive, suggesting a 
bullish signal. Both the 12-day EMA as well as the 26-day EMA are rising, another bullish signal.- The price to 50-
day EMAP ratio is 1.1, a bullish indicator. The 50-day EMAP has increased to EUR16.41. An increase is another 
bullish indicator.
Past Month:- Rises to Falls: In the past month the number of rises outnumbered falls 15:5 or 3:1. 
Past Quarter:
- The shares had their best quarter in three quarters since the quarter ended March 01, 2023. In the last three 
months the stock has hit a new 52-week high six times, pointing to an uptrend. The Best 3 weeks in the past 
quarterThe past month witnessed the best 2 weeks in the past quarter. In the past quarter the week beginning 
Monday November 06 saw the highest weekly rise of 10.1% for a relative price increase of 13.1%. The rise was 
propped up by volume of 1.9 times average.

2.11 Satisfies one criterion of Benjamin Graham-"Total debt less than tangible book value"; total debt of EUR1.4 
billion (US$1.5 billion) is less than tangible book value of EUR5.3 billion (US$6 billion).-"Total debt equal or less 
than twice the net quick liquidation value"; total debt of EUR1.4 billion (US$1.5 billion) is 0.3 times the net 
liquidation value of EUR4.11 billion (US$4.7 billion).

4.3 Satisfies 3 out of 9 criteria of Joseph Piotroski [pass mark 5]:- Positive operating cashflow.- Good quality of 
earnings [operating cashflow exceeds net income].- Improvement in asset turnover [growth in revenue of 193.5% 
exceeded growth in assets of 22.9%].
But does not meet the following 6 criteria of Joseph Piotroski:- Positive net income.- Return on Assets 
improvement.- Improvement in long-term debt to total assets.- Improvement in current ratio.- Total shares on issue 
unchanged (or reduction in total shares on issue).- Improvement in gross margin.
SECTION 5 CORPORATE PROFILE5.1 ActivitiesRyanair Holdings plc (Ryanair) is engaged in the provision of a

SECTION 7 TOP MANAGEMENT AND BOARD OF DIRECTORS
7.1 Profiles of Top ManagementMichael OLearyCEOMichael O'Leary has served as a director of Ryanair since 
1988 and a director of Ryanair Holdings since July 1996. He was appointed chief executive officer of Ryanair in 
1994.
David BondermanNon-Executive ChairmanDavid Bonderman has served as a director since August 1996 and has 
served as the chairman of the Board of Directors since December 1996. In 1992, Mr. Bonderman co-founded TPG 
(formerly known as Texas Pacific Group), a private equity investment firm. He currently serves as an officer and 
director of the general partner and manager of TPG. Mr. Bonderman is also an officer, director and shareholder of 
1996 Air G.P. Inc., which owns shares of Ryanair. He also serves on the boards of directors of the following public 
companies: CoStar Group, Inc. and General Motors Company and is a U.S. citizen.

last 10 years the average annualized return to shareholders was 12.2%. The present value of Euro1,000 (PV1000) 
invested 10 years ago is now EUR3,160, a gain of EUR2,044 and dividend reinvested of EUR115. 
Neil SorahanCFONeil Sorahan was appointed Chief Financial Officer of Ryanair in October 2014, having previously 
served as its Finance Director from June 2006. Prior to that, he was Ryanair's Group Treasurer from January 2003.

group (June 1992 to December 2002).

years ago is now EUR1,544, a gain of EUR544. 
Michael HickeyChief Operating OfficerMichael Hickey has served as Chief Operations Officer since February 2014. 
Michael has held a wide range of senior positions within the Engineering Department since 1988 and was Director 
of Engineering between January 2000 and February 2014. Prior to joining Ryanair in 1988, Michael worked as an 
aircraft engineer with Fields Aircraft Services and McAlpine Aviation, working primarily on executive aircraft.
Shareholder Value:Creation of shareholder value in Ryanair Holdings:Year of appointment: 2014In the last 5 years 
the average annualized return to shareholders was 9.1%. The present value of Euro1,000 (PV1000) invested 5 
years ago is now EUR1,544, a gain of EUR544. 
Juliusz KomorekCompany SecretaryJuliusz Komorek was appointed Company Secretary and Chief Legal and 
Regulatory Officer in May 2009, having served as Deputy Director of Legal and Regulatory Affairs since 2007. Prior 
to joining the Company in 2004, Juliusz had gained relevant experience in the European Commission's Directorate 
General for Competition and in the Polish Embassy to the EU in Brussels, as well as in the private sector in Poland 
and the Netherlands. Juliusz is a lawyer, holding degrees from the universities of Warsaw and Amsterdam.
7.2 Profiles of Board of DirectorsMichael CawleyDirectorMichael Cawley was appointed as a non-executive director 
of Ryanair in August 2014. Michael had served as Deputy Chief Executive Officer and Chief Operating Officer of 
Ryanair from 2003 to March 2014 and before that as Ryanair's Chief Financial Officer and Commercial Director 
from 1997. Michael also holds directorships in Paddy Power PLC and in Kingspan Group PLC. Prior to joining 
Ryanair, Michael was Group Finance Director of Gowan Group Limited, one of Ireland's largest private companies 
and the main distributor for Peugeot and Citroen automobiles in Ireland. Michael holds a Bachelor of Commerce 
degree and is a fellow of the Institute of Chartered Accountants in Ireland. He is an Irish citizen.

the average annualized return to shareholders was 12.2%. The present value of Euro1,000 (PV1000) invested 10 
years ago is now EUR3,160, a gain of EUR2,044 and dividend reinvested of EUR115. 
Mike O''BrienNon-Executive DirectorMike O'Brien was appointed as a non-executive director of Ryanair in May 
2016.Capt O'Brien has a long and distinguished career in the aviation industry having just retired as Head of Flight 
Operations with the Maltese Civil Aviation Authority whom he joined in 2001, having previously served for 10 years 
as the Head of Operations Standards with the Irish Aviation Authority. Capt O'Brien also served 4 years as the 
Chief Pilot and Flight Ops Manager of Ryanair from 1987 to 1991.
R. A. (Dick) MillikenNon-Executive DirectorAge: 62Dick Milliken has served as a director of Ryanair since July 
2013.
Howard MillarNon-Executive DirectorHoward Millar was appointed as a non-executive director of Ryanair in August 
2015. Howard had served as Deputy Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer from 2003 to December 
2014 and before that as Ryanair's Director of Finance from 1993. Howard is Chairman of BDO Ireland and a 
member of Irelandia Aviation's advisory board. Howard is a graduate of Trinity College, Dublin and is a fellow of 
Chartered Accountants Ireland. He is an Irish citizen.
Weekly: Ryanair Holdings (RY4B: EUR18.0) lifts 3.9% on average volume; +67c [3.9%]
James OsborneNon-Executive DirectorJames Osborne has served as a director of Ryanair Holdings since August 
1996, and has been a director of Ryanair since April 1995. Mr. Osborne is a former managing partner of A & L 
Goodbody Solicitors. He is also a former Chairman of Independent News and Media plc and a director of James 
Hardie Industries NV. He also serves as a director of a number of Irish private companies and is an Irish citizen.
Kyran McLaughlinNon-Executive DirectorKyran McLaughlin has served as a director since January 2001, and is 
also Deputy Chairman and Head of Capital Markets at Davy Stockbrokers. Mr. McLaughlin also advised Ryanair 
during its initial flotation on the Dublin and NASDAQ stock markets in 1997. Mr. McLaughlin serves on the Board of 
Directors of Elan Corporation plc, and he also serves as a director of a number of other Irish private companies and 
is an Irish citizen.
Louise PhelanNon-Executive DirectorLouise Phelan has served as a director of Ryanair since December 2012. Ms. 
Phelan is currently serving as VP for PayPal Global Operations Europe Middle East and Africa leading 1,800 
people in Dublin, Dundalk and Berlin. Louise has been part of PayPal since 2006 and prior to this she was a 
member of the Senior Management team for GE Money, a division of General Electric (GE), which specialises in 
small ticket lending for a client base comprising both consumers and commercial customers. Louise is also a 
member of the Board of the American Chamber of Commerce and a member of the Dublin Chamber of Commerce, 
CCMA Ireland, the Women's Executive Network (WXN) and the International Women's Forum and is an Irish 
citizen.
Julie O''NeillNon-Executive DirectorJulie O'Neill is a non-executive director at Ryanair, Europe's favourite airline. 
She served as Secretary General of the Department of Transport, Ireland from 2002 to 2009. During that time she 
delivered a successful IPO for the part-privatisation of Aer Lingus and oversaw the setting up of the Dublin Airport 
Authority to provide the basis for the subsequent independence of Shannon Airport. In a career that spanned 37 
years in the Irish public service, she worked in strategic policy development and implementation in eight 
Government Departments.
Declan McKeonNon-Executive DirectorDeclan McKeon has served as a director since May 2010. Mr. McKeon is a 
former audit partner of PricewaterhouseCoopers and continues to act as a consultant to PricewaterhouseCoopers. 
He is currently a director, chairman of the audit committee, and a member of the compensation committee of Icon 
plc and is an Irish citizen.
Charles McCreevyNon-Executive DirectorCharles McCreevy has served as a director since May 2010. Mr. 
McCreevy has previously served as EU Commissioner for Internal Markets and Services (2004-2010) and has held 
positions in several Irish Government Ministerial Offices, including Minister for Finance (1997-2004), Minister for 
Tourism & Trade (1993-1994) and Minister for Social Welfare (1992-1993) and is an Irish citizen.

GLOSSARYADVT: Average Daily Volume of shares TradedAnnual Return: Dividends Paid In a 12-Month 
Period/Price at the Beginning of the Period + Capital Gain or Loss over 1 Year/Price 1 Year Ago (%)Cash/MCap: 
Cash plus Liquids/Market Capitalisation (times)Current Ratio: Current Assets/Current Liabilities (times)Debt/Equity: 
Net Debt/Net Assets %EBIT Margin : Earnings Before Interest and Tax/Revenue (%)Moving Average Price (n 
periods): Sum of Prices for each Period/Number of PeriodsPV1000: Present value of 1000 invested 1 year/'n' years 
Weekly: Ryanair Holdings (RY4B: EUR18.0) lifts 3.9% on average volume; +67c [3.9%]
agoPrice Close/Moving Avg Price: Latest Price/Moving Average PricePrice/NTA: Closing Share Price/Net Tangible 
Assets Per Share (times)Price/Sales: Share Price/Sales Per Share (times)Relative Price Change [RPC]: Relative 
price change is price change of stock with respect to Benchmark IndexRelative Strength (6 Months): Price close 
today/Price close 6 months ago, then ranked by percentile within the entire market.Return on Assets: Net 
Profit/Total Assets (%)Return on Equity (Shareholders' Funds): Net Profit/Net Assets (%)TSR: Total Shareholder 
Returns is expressed as an annualized rate of return for shareholders after allowing for capital appreciation and 
dividendVolume Index (VI): Number of shares traded in the period/Average number of shares traded for the 
periodVolume Weighted Average Price (VWAP): The Volume Weighted Average Price (VWAP) is the summation of 
turnover divided by total volume in the same period.

Holidaymakers fury at Ryanair as budget airline charges passengers a whopping £21 for an e-boarding pass
Holidaymakers fury at Ryanair as budget airline charges passengers a 
whopping £21 for an e-boarding pass
MailOnline
December 2, 2023 Saturday 8:02 PM GMT
Copyright 2023 Associated Newspapers Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Version:1
Length: 479 words
Byline: Andy Jehring
Body
•
Passengers told by budget airline to pay to reserve a seat or queue at the airport
Having charged passengers to reserve a seat, stow a suitcase and print a boarding pass, you might have thought 
Ryanair had run out of add-ons to squeeze out of its customers.
But now the budget airline appears to have come up with yet another wheeze, with fliers told they must pay to add a 
random seat if they wish to receive their digital boarding pass. Those who refuse to pay between £8 and £21 are 
told to queue at the airport to receive a printed boarding pass.
Airport staff told The Mail on Sunday the change, which has been rolled out in recent days, had caused outrage 
with customers.
Vivien Lovrin booked to fly from London to Germany last Thursday and having opted not to pay extra to reserve a 
seat, proceeded to check-in with a randomly allocated spot.
But after filling in her details, the Ryanair app told her: 'Check-in done! Get your boarding pass now and avoid 
queuing at the airport by adding a seat.'
On clicking through she was told to pay a fee to secure a random seat - or else face yet another airport queue to 
get her boarding pass.
She said: 'When you thought Ryanair couldn't sink any lower, they find a way to force you to buy a seat. How is this 
legal?
'Isn't the whole point of online check-in to avoid people queuing at the airport?'
Holidaymakers fury at Ryanair as budget airline charges passengers a whopping £21 for an e-boarding pass
Ciaran Murtagh was faced with the same issue. He said: 'So Ryanair, you are making travellers, who do not wish to 
book a seat, queue up at a desk and have their boarding pass printed. That's great for the environment and another 
cheap shot at passengers to pay more to travel. A new low for Ryanair. Absolutely disgraceful.'
Fabien Mauroy, who was flying out of London on Friday, commented about Ryanair on X (formerly Twitter): 'Worse 
experience for people, long queue at airports, [and] polluting planet for money.'
The new fee makes a mockery of a £55 fine the budget firm imposes on passengers to print out their boarding pass 
at the airport if they don't check-in online.
Italian traveller Marcello Maggio said: 'Ryanair says I must check in online, but it doesn't give me the boarding pass 
online to force me to pay for a seat. What am I buying with the ticket if not a seat to fly?'
Other add-ons for those who book online include £4 to £15 to reserve a seat, while bags cost between £20 and 
£60, with an excess fee of around £10 per kilo. 
If a passenger requires oxygen for medical reasons they are not allowed to bring their own - and must pay £55 to 
use Ryanair's. 
The latest fee does not appear to affect all travellers, with some saying they got a digital boarding pass for free.
A Ryanair spokesman said: 'Passengers have the choice of choosing a seat for a small fee or be randomly 
allocated a seat free of charge.' 
The firm did not respond to claims that it was effectively forcing customers to pay for a digital boarding pass.
Load-Date: December 3, 2023
End of Document
Weekly: Ryanair Holdings ADR (RYAAY: $120.17) rises for a fifth consecutive week, a five-week rise of 35%; 
+$2.71 [2.3%] Vol Index 1.3 [1 is avg]
Weekly: Ryanair Holdings ADR (RYAAY: $120.17) rises for a fifth 
consecutive week, a five-week rise of 35%; +$2.71 [2.3%] Vol Index 1.3 [1 is 
avg]
Global Round Up - ADRs and Depository Receipts
December 2, 2023 Saturday
Copyright 2023 Jupiter International (Australia) Pty Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 5596 words
Body
DAILY ADR AND DEPOSITORY RECEIPT REPORT
www.buysellsignals.com
Ryanair Holdings (O:RYAAY $120.17), the International Depository Receipt (IDR) market's largest Airlines 
company by market cap, has risen $2.71 (or 2.3%) on high volume to close at $120.17. The ADR rose for a fifth 
consecutive week on Friday bringing its a five-week rise to $31.0 or 34.8%. Compared with the BNY Mellon 
Composite ADR Index which rose 12.9 points (or 8.8%) in the five weeks, this represented a relative price increase 
of 26.0%. 
The price ranged between a high of $120.17 on Friday Dec 01 and a low of $117.51 on Monday Nov 27.[Volume 
Index (VI); 1 is average] In the past five weeks the market cap has jumped by $7.1 billion to $27.4 billion. 
The volume was 1.3 times average trading per week of 2.4 million ADRs. 
Bullish Turning Point
New 52-week HighThe price increase of 1.6% was fuelled by a new 52-week high. On the previous day, the price 
decreased by 0.1%. The price swing indicates a bullish trend might be sustained in the short-term.

A year ago the exchange rate was USD 1 = 0.97 EUR. USD1000 would have bought EUR969. A year ago the 
Ryanair Holdings Share price was EUR13.04. EUR969 would have bought 74.3 Ryanair Holdings Shares on that 
day. Those 74.3 Shares would be worth EUR1,338 at today's Share price of EUR18.0. At today's exchange rate of 
USD1=0.92 EUR this is equivalent to USD1,459. PV$1000= $1,459.

Friday's price upRyanair Holdings ADR hits year-high 8th time in three monthsRyanair Holdings PLC's (O: RYAAY 
$119.91) ADR price hit a 52-week high of $120.19 during the day. In the last three months the ADR has hit a new 
52-week high eight times, pointing to a significant uptrend. Ryanair Holdings' ADR price lifted $1.69 (1.4%) from 
Thursday's close of $119.91. Compared with the BNY Mellon Composite ADR Index which rose 0.9 points (0.6%) in 
Weekly: Ryanair Holdings ADR (RYAAY: $120.17) rises for a fifth consecutive week, a five-week rise of 35%; 
+$2.71 [2.3%] Vol Index 1.3 [1 is avg]
the day, the relative price increase was 0.9%. Ryanair Holdings PLC is the International Depository Receipt (IDR) 
market's largest Airlines company by market cap. There were 441,436 ADRs worth $52.9 million traded today.

2.2 Top 5 Institutional Ownership of Ryanair Holdings as at September 30, 2023
As at September 30, 2023, 251 Institutions (Funds) held investments in ADRs of Ryanair Holdings. Institutions 
increased their holdings to 43.2% of issued capital, up from 43.2% as at Jun 30. The largest ADRholder was Capital 
International Investors with 5% of Ryanair Holdings. The second largest ADRholder was Massachusetts Financial 
Services with 5%. 
*Note: Minimum Core ADRholding is computed on the basis of SEC filings over the last 12 quarters (3 years). A 
higher % of ADRholding above the minimum core holding may be indicative of a potential positioning by an active 
institution to overweight.

SECTION 3 TODAY'S BULLISH SIGNALS3.1 PAST WEEK: MODERATE MOMENTUM UPRYAAY increases 2.3% 
on firm volume 1.3 times average. Compared with the BNY Mellon Composite ADR Index which rose 0.1 points (or 
0.1%) in the week, the relative price increase was 1.7%. 
Week 48 of 2023: Up 2.3%; Ryanair Holdings (RYAAY) outperformed the The Bank of New York Mellon Composite 
ADR Index in 3 out of 5 days. The price ranged between a high of $120.17 on Friday Dec 01 and a low of $117.51 
on Monday Nov 27.[Volume Index (VI); 1 is average]

3.3 UptrendThe ADR traded at a thirty one-month high of $120.33 today. Price/Moving Average Price of 1.09 and 
positive MACD:- The Price/MAP 200 for Ryanair Holdings is 1.09. Being higher than 1 is a bullish indicator. It is 
higher than the Price/MAP 200 for the BNY Mellon Composite ADR Index of 1.05, a second bullish indicator. The 
200-day MAP has increased to $110.31, a third bullish indicator.- The Moving Average Convergence Divergence 
(MACD) indicator of 12-day Exponential Moving Average (EMA) of 115.59 minus the 26-day EMA of 109.7 is 
positive, suggesting a bullish signal. Both the 12-day EMA as well as the 26-day EMA are rising, another bullish 
signal.- The price to 50-day EMAP ratio is 1.1, a bullish indicator. In the past 50 days this ratio has exceeded 1.1, 
seven times suggesting further upside. The 50-day EMAP has increased to $105.01. An increase is another bullish 
indicator.
Past Month:- Rises to Falls: In the past month the number of rises outnumbered falls 19:3 or 6.3:1. 
Past Quarter:
In the last three months the ADR has hit a new 52-week high eight times, pointing to a significant uptrend. The Best 
3 weeks in the past quarterThe past month witnessed the best 3 weeks in the past quarter. In the past quarter the 
week beginning Monday November 06 saw the highest weekly rise of 13.5% for a relative price increase of 22.1%. 
The rise was propped up by volume of 2.1 times average.

Rising Relative Strength:
- The ADR has a 6-month relative strength of 82 in the International Depository Receipts market of 1,130 units 
which means it is beating 82% of the market. - A price rise combined with a high relative strength is a bullish signal. 
- Also, the relative strength percentile is rising at 82 for 6 months, 94 for 3 months and 97 for 1 month.
3.4 Other Bullish SignalsMCap/Total Assets:- Tobin's Q Ratio, defined as MCap divided by Total Assets, is 1.6. 
Compared with the rest of the market the ADR is undervalued.

4.9 Satisfies one criterion of Benjamin Graham-"Total debt less than tangible book value"; total debt of EUR1.4 
billion (US$1.5 billion) is less than tangible book value of EUR5.3 billion (US$6 billion).-"Total debt equal or less 
than twice the net quick liquidation value"; total debt of EUR1.4 billion (US$1.5 billion) is 0.3 times the net 
liquidation value of EUR4.11 billion (US$4.7 billion).

6.4 Satisfies 3 out of 9 criteria of Joseph Piotroski [pass mark 5]:- Positive operating cashflow.- Good quality of 
earnings [operating cashflow exceeds net income].- Improvement in asset turnover [growth in revenue of 193.5% 
exceeded growth in assets of 22.9%].
But does not meet the following 6 criteria of Joseph Piotroski:- Positive net income.- Return on Assets 
improvement.- Improvement in long-term debt to total assets.- Improvement in current ratio.- Total shares on issue 
unchanged (or reduction in total shares on issue).- Improvement in gross margin.

SECTION 9 TOP MANAGEMENT AND BOARD OF DIRECTORS
9.1 Profiles of Top ManagementMichael OLearyCEOMichael O'Leary has served as a director of Ryanair since 
1988 and a director of Ryanair Holdings since July 1996. He was appointed chief executive officer of Ryanair in 
1994.
David BondermanNon-Executive ChairmanDavid Bonderman has served as a director since August 1996 and has 
served as the chairman of the Board of Directors since December 1996. In 1992, Mr. Bonderman co-founded TPG 
(formerly known as Texas Pacific Group), a private equity investment firm. He currently serves as an officer and 
director of the general partner and manager of TPG. Mr. Bonderman is also an officer, director and shareholder of 
1996 Air G.P. Inc., which owns shares of Ryanair. He also serves on the boards of directors of the following public 
companies: CoStar Group, Inc. and General Motors Company and is a U.S. citizen.
Shareholder Value:Creation of shareholder value in Ryanair Holdings:Month of appointment: December 1996In the 
last 5 years the average annualized return to shareholders was 7.9%. The present value of $1,000 (PV1000) 
invested 5 years ago is now $1,460, a gain of $460. 
Neil SorahanCFONeil Sorahan was appointed Chief Financial Officer of Ryanair in October 2014, having previously 
served as its Finance Director from June 2006. Prior to that, he was Ryanair's Group Treasurer from January 2003. 
Before joining Ryanair, Neil held various finance and treasury roles at CRH plc, the international building materials 
group (June 1992 to December 2002).
Shareholder Value:Creation of shareholder value in Ryanair Holdings:Year of appointment: 2014In the last 5 years 
the average annualized return to shareholders was 7.9%. The present value of $1,000 (PV1000) invested 5 years 
ago is now $1,460, a gain of $460. 
Michael HickeyChief Operating OfficerMichael Hickey has served as Chief Operations Officer since February 2014. 
Michael has held a wide range of senior positions within the Engineering Department since 1988 and was Director 
of Engineering between January 2000 and February 2014. Prior to joining Ryanair in 1988, Michael worked as an 
aircraft engineer with Fields Aircraft Services and McAlpine Aviation, working primarily on executive aircraft.
Shareholder Value:Creation of shareholder value in Ryanair Holdings:Year of appointment: 2014In the last 5 years 
the average annualized return to shareholders was 7.9%. The present value of $1,000 (PV1000) invested 5 years 
ago is now $1,460, a gain of $460. 
Juliusz KomorekCompany SecretaryJuliusz Komorek was appointed Company Secretary and Chief Legal and 
Regulatory Officer in May 2009, having served as Deputy Director of Legal and Regulatory Affairs since 2007. Prior 
to joining the Company in 2004, Juliusz had gained relevant experience in the European Commission's Directorate 
General for Competition and in the Polish Embassy to the EU in Brussels, as well as in the private sector in Poland 
and the Netherlands. Juliusz is a lawyer, holding degrees from the universities of Warsaw and Amsterdam.

of Ryanair in August 2014. Michael had served as Deputy Chief Executive Officer and Chief Operating Officer of 
Ryanair from 2003 to March 2014 and before that as Ryanair's Chief Financial Officer and Commercial Director 
from 1997. Michael also holds directorships in Paddy Power PLC and in Kingspan Group PLC. Prior to joining

Mike O''BrienNon-Executive DirectorMike O'Brien was appointed as a non-executive director of Ryanair in May 
2016.Capt O'Brien has a long and distinguished career in the aviation industry having just retired as Head of Flight 
Operations with the Maltese Civil Aviation Authority whom he joined in 2001, having previously served for 10 years 
as the Head of Operations Standards with the Irish Aviation Authority. Capt O'Brien also served 4 years as the 
Chief Pilot and Flight Ops Manager of Ryanair from 1987 to 1991.
R. A. (Dick) MillikenNon-Executive DirectorAge: 62Dick Milliken has served as a director of Ryanair since July 
2013.
James OsborneNon-Executive DirectorJames Osborne has served as a director of Ryanair Holdings since August 
1996, and has been a director of Ryanair since April 1995. Mr. Osborne is a former managing partner of A & L 
Goodbody Solicitors. He is also a former Chairman of Independent News and Media plc and a director of James 
Hardie Industries NV. He also serves as a director of a number of Irish private companies and is an Irish citizen.
Howard MillarNon-Executive DirectorHoward Millar was appointed as a non-executive director of Ryanair in August 
2015. Howard had served as Deputy Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer from 2003 to December 
2014 and before that as Ryanair's Director of Finance from 1993. Howard is Chairman of BDO Ireland and a 
member of Irelandia Aviation's advisory board. Howard is a graduate of Trinity College, Dublin and is a fellow of 
Chartered Accountants Ireland. He is an Irish citizen.
Louise PhelanNon-Executive DirectorLouise Phelan has served as a director of Ryanair since December 2012. Ms. 
Phelan is currently serving as VP for PayPal Global Operations Europe Middle East and Africa leading 1,800 
people in Dublin, Dundalk and Berlin. Louise has been part of PayPal since 2006 and prior to this she was a 
member of the Senior Management team for GE Money, a division of General Electric (GE), which specialises in 
small ticket lending for a client base comprising both consumers and commercial customers. Louise is also a 
member of the Board of the American Chamber of Commerce and a member of the Dublin Chamber of Commerce, 
CCMA Ireland, the Women's Executive Network (WXN) and the International Women's Forum and is an Irish 
citizen.
Kyran McLaughlinNon-Executive DirectorKyran McLaughlin has served as a director since January 2001, and is 
also Deputy Chairman and Head of Capital Markets at Davy Stockbrokers. Mr. McLaughlin also advised Ryanair 
during its initial flotation on the Dublin and NASDAQ stock markets in 1997. Mr. McLaughlin serves on the Board of 
Directors of Elan Corporation plc, and he also serves as a director of a number of other Irish private companies and 
is an Irish citizen.
Julie O''NeillNon-Executive DirectorJulie O'Neill is a non-executive director at Ryanair, Europe's favourite airline. 
She served as Secretary General of the Department of Transport, Ireland from 2002 to 2009. During that time she 
delivered a successful IPO for the part-privatisation of Aer Lingus and oversaw the setting up of the Dublin Airport 
Authority to provide the basis for the subsequent independence of Shannon Airport. In a career that spanned 37

+$2.71 [2.3%] Vol Index 1.3 [1 is avg]
years in the Irish public service, she worked in strategic policy development and implementation in eight 
Government Departments.
Declan McKeonNon-Executive DirectorDeclan McKeon has served as a director since May 2010. Mr. McKeon is a 
former audit partner of PricewaterhouseCoopers and continues to act as a consultant to PricewaterhouseCoopers. 
He is currently a director, chairman of the audit committee, and a member of the compensation committee of Icon 
plc and is an Irish citizen.
Charles McCreevyNon-Executive DirectorCharles McCreevy has served as a director since May 2010. Mr. 
McCreevy has previously served as EU Commissioner for Internal Markets and Services (2004-2010) and has held 
positions in several Irish Government Ministerial Offices, including Minister for Finance (1997-2004), Minister for 
Tourism & Trade (1993-1994) and Minister for Social Welfare (1992-1993) and is an Irish citizen.

GLOSSARYADVT: Average Daily Volume of shares TradedAnnual Return: Dividends Paid In a 12-Month 
Period/Price at the Beginning of the Period + Capital Gain or Loss over 1 Year/Price 1 Year Ago (%)Current Ratio: 
Current Assets/Current Liabilities (times)Debt/Equity: Net Debt/Net Assets %EBIT Margin : Earnings Before Interest 
and Tax/Revenue (%)Moving Average Price (n periods): Sum of Prices for each Period/Number of PeriodsPV1000: 
Present value of 1000 invested 1 year/'n' years agoPrice Close/Moving Avg Price: Latest Price/Moving Average 
PricePrice/NTA: Closing Share Price/Net Tangible Assets Per Share (times)Price/Sales: Share Price/Sales Per 
Share (times)Relative Price Change [RPC]: Relative price change is price change of stock with respect to 
Benchmark IndexRelative Strength (6 Months): Price close today/Price close 6 months ago, then ranked by 
percentile within the entire market.Return on Assets: Net Profit/Total Assets (%)Return on Equity (Shareholders' 
Funds): Net Profit/Net Assets (%)Volume Weighted Average Price (VWAP): The Volume Weighted Average Price 
(VWAP) is the summation of turnover divided by total volume in the same period.

Ryanair Holdings plc ( NASDAQ :RYAAY) Shares Sold by Immersion Capital LLP
Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) Shares Sold by Immersion Capital 
LLP
Newstex Blogs 
Watchlist News
December 2, 2023 Saturday
Copyright 2023 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 746 words
Body
December 2nd, 2023 ( Watchlist News  — Delivered by  Newstex )
Immersion Capital LLP reduced its position in shares of Ryanair Holdings plc ( NASDAQ:RYAAY  - Free Report ) by 
16.0% in the 2nd quarter, HoldingsChannel.com  reports. The firm owned 489,870 shares of the transportation 
company's stock after selling 92,980 shares during the quarter. Ryanair comprises approximately 18.1% of 
Immersion Capital LLP's portfolio, making the stock its 2nd biggest holding. Immersion Capital LLP's holdings in 
Ryanair were worth $54,180,000 at the end of the most recent reporting period.
Several other hedge funds have also added to or reduced their stakes in the company. Simplicity Solutions LLC 
lifted its holdings in Ryanair by 1.3% during the 2nd quarter. Simplicity Solutions LLC now owns 7,692 shares of the 
transportation company's stock worth $851,000 after purchasing an additional 98 shares during the last quarter. 
Cetera Advisor Networks LLC increased its stake in Ryanair by 4.6% during the 2nd quarter. Cetera Advisor 
Networks LLC now owns 2,458 shares of the transportation company's stock worth $272,000 after acquiring an 
additional 108 shares during the period. Financial Gravity Asset Management Inc. bought a new position in Ryanair 
during the 2nd quarter worth $76,000. Private Advisor Group LLC increased its stake in Ryanair by 4.4% during the 
2nd quarter. Private Advisor Group LLC now owns 3,086 shares of the transportation company's stock worth 
$320,000 after acquiring an additional 129 shares during the period. Finally, Rehmann Capital Advisory Group 
increased its stake in Ryanair by 3.0% during the 1st quarter. Rehmann Capital Advisory Group now owns 4,910 
shares of the transportation company's stock worth $463,000 after acquiring an additional 142 shares during the 
period. 43.66% of the stock is owned by institutional investors and hedge funds.
Analyst Ratings Changes
Separately, StockNews.com  lowered Ryanair from a 'buy' rating to a 'hold' rating in a research note on Tuesday, 
November 7th. One investment analyst has rated the stock with a hold rating, six have issued a buy rating and one 
has issued a strong buy rating to the stock. According to data from MarketBeat.com, the company currently has a 
consensus rating of 'Buy' and a consensus target price of $59.00.
View Our Latest Stock Analysis on RYAAY
Ryanair Price Performance
Ryanair Holdings plc ( NASDAQ :RYAAY) Shares Sold by Immersion Capital LLP
Shares of NASDAQ RYAAY  traded up $1.95 during mid-day trading on Friday, hitting $120.17. 590,592 shares of 
the stock traded hands, compared to its average volume of 738,950. The company has a debt-to-equity ratio of 
0.31, a current ratio of 1.19 and a quick ratio of 1.19. Ryanair Holdings plc has a twelve month low of $73.50 and a 
twelve month high of $120.33. The company has a market cap of $27.37 billion, a PE ratio of 11.39, a price-to-
earnings-growth ratio of 0.80 and a beta of 1.53. The firm has a 50 day simple moving average of $101.28 and a 
two-hundred day simple moving average of $102.70.
Ryanair ( NASDAQ:RYAAY  - Get Free Report ) last released its quarterly earnings data on Monday, November 
6th. The transportation company reported $7.21 earnings per share for the quarter, beating the consensus estimate 
of $7.13 by $0.08. Ryanair had a return on equity of 34.37% and a net margin of 17.65%. The company had 
revenue of $5.36 billion for the quarter, compared to the consensus estimate of $5.14 billion. As a group, equities 
research analysts forecast that Ryanair Holdings plc will post 8.87 EPS for the current fiscal year.
About Ryanair
( Free Report )
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, Italy, Spain, and internationally. It is also involved in the provision of various ancillary services, 
such as non-flight scheduled and Internet-related services, as well as in-flight sale of beverages, food, duty-free, 
and merchandise; and markets car hire, travel insurance, and accommodation services through its website and 
mobile app.

during the second quarter, according to the company in its most recent filing with the SEC. The fund owned 3,086 
shares of the transportation company's stock after acquiring an additional 129 shares during the quarter. Private 
Advisor Group LLC's holdings in Ryanair were worth $320,000 at the end of the most recent reporting period.
A number of other hedge funds have also made changes to their positions in the business. Simplicity Solutions LLC 
increased its holdings in shares of Ryanair by 1.3% in the 2nd quarter. Simplicity Solutions LLC now owns 7,692 
shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $851,000 after acquiring an additional 98 shares during the 
last quarter. Cetera Advisor Networks LLC boosted its position in shares of Ryanair by 4.6% in the 2nd quarter. 
Cetera Advisor Networks LLC now owns 2,458 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $272,000 
after purchasing an additional 108 shares during the period. Financial Gravity Asset Management Inc. acquired a 
new stake in shares of Ryanair in the 2nd quarter valued at about $76,000. Rehmann Capital Advisory Group 
boosted its position in shares of Ryanair by 3.0% in the 1st quarter. Rehmann Capital Advisory Group now owns 
4,910 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $463,000 after purchasing an additional 142 shares 
during the period. Finally, LPL Financial LLC boosted its position in shares of Ryanair by 2.5% in the 2nd quarter.

purchasing an additional 153 shares during the period. Hedge funds and other institutional investors own 43.66% of 
the company's stock.

one has given a strong buy rating to the company. Based on data from MarketBeat, Ryanair presently has an

Ryanair Trading Up 1.6 %
Private Advisor Group LLC Raises Holdings in Ryanair Holdings plc ( NASDAQ :RYAAY)
NASDAQ RYAAY  opened at $120.17 on Friday. Ryanair Holdings plc has a 52-week low of $73.50 and a 52-week 
high of $120.33. The firm has a 50-day moving average price of $101.28 and a 200 day moving average price of 
$102.70. The stock has a market capitalization of $27.37 billion, a P/E ratio of 11.39, a P/E/G ratio of 0.80 and a 
beta of 1.43. The company has a quick ratio of 1.19, a current ratio of 1.19 and a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.31.
Ryanair ( NASDAQ:RYAAY  - Get Free Report ) last issued its earnings results on Monday, November 6th. The 
transportation company reported $7.21 earnings per share (EPS) for the quarter, topping analysts' consensus 
estimates of $7.13 by $0.08. Ryanair had a return on equity of 34.37% and a net margin of 17.65%. The business 
had revenue of $5.36 billion during the quarter, compared to the consensus estimate of $5.14 billion. Equities 
research analysts expect that Ryanair Holdings plc will post 8.87 EPS for the current year.

( Free Report )
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, Italy, Spain, and internationally. It is also involved in the provision of various ancillary services, 
such as non-flight scheduled and Internet-related services, as well as in-flight sale of beverages, food, duty-free,

Immersion Capital LLP Trims Stake in Ryanair Holdings plc ( NASDAQ :RYAAY)
Immersion Capital LLP Trims Stake in Ryanair Holdings plc 
(NASDAQ:RYAAY)
American Banking and Market News
December 2, 2023 Saturday
Copyright 2023 American Banking and Market News All Rights Reserved
Length: 833 words
Body
Ryanair logo Immersion Capital LLP cut its position in shares of  Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY  - Free 
Report ) by 16.0% during the 2nd quarter, according to its most recent disclosure with the Securities and Exchange 
Commission (SEC). The fund owned 489,870 shares of the transportation company's stock after selling 92,980 
shares during the quarter. Ryanair accounts for about  18.1% of Immersion Capital LLP's investment portfolio, 
making the stock its 2nd largest holding. Immersion Capital LLP owned about 0.22% of Ryanair worth $54,180,000 
at the end of the most recent quarter.  
•
Is Ryanair Overbought? Earnings Say Not Likely  
Several other large investors have also recently added to or reduced their stakes in the company. HighTower 
Advisors LLC lifted its stake in  Ryanair by 10.3% in the first quarter. HighTower Advisors LLC now owns 3,047 
shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $265,000 after buying an additional 285 shares during the 
last quarter.  Private Advisor Group LLC lifted its stake in  Ryanair by 16.8% in the first quarter. Private Advisor 
Group LLC now owns 4,758 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $414,000 after buying an 
additional 683 shares during the last quarter.  Citigroup Inc. lifted its stake in  Ryanair by 1.2% in the first quarter. 
Citigroup Inc. now owns 39,970 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $3,483,000 after buying an 
additional 483 shares during the last quarter.  Bank of Montreal Can lifted its stake in  Ryanair by 8.2% in the first 
quarter. Bank of Montreal Can now owns 11,691 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $984,000 
after buying an additional 884 shares during the last quarter.  Finally, Raymond James Trust N.A. lifted its stake in  
Ryanair by 16.2% in the first quarter. Raymond James Trust N.A. now owns 3,406 shares of the transportation 
company's stock valued at $297,000 after buying an additional 476 shares during the last quarter. 43.66% of the 
stock is currently owned by institutional investors. Analysts Set New Price Targets
Separately, StockNews.com  cut shares of Ryanair from a "buy" rating to a "hold" rating in a research note on 
Tuesday, November 7th. One analyst  has rated the stock with a hold rating, six have assigned  a buy rating and 
one  has issued  a strong buy rating to the stock. Based on data from MarketBeat.com, the company  has a 
consensus rating of "Buy" and a consensus price target of $59.00.

Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY  - Get Free Report ) last issued its quarterly earnings results on Monday, November 6th. 
The transportation company reported $7.21 earnings per share for the quarter, topping analysts' consensus 
estimates of $7.13 by $0.08. The firm had revenue of $5.36 billion for the quarter, compared to analysts' 
expectations of $5.14 billion. Ryanair had a return on equity of 34.37% and a net margin of 17.65%.  Equities 
research analysts anticipate that  Ryanair Holdings plc will post 8.87 earnings per share for the current year. About 
Ryanair (Free Report ) 
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, Italy, Spain, and internationally. It is also involved in the provision of various ancillary services, 
such as non-flight scheduled and Internet-related services, as well as in-flight sale of beverages, food, duty-free, 
and merchandise; and markets car hire, travel insurance, and accommodation services through its website and

Tartan barmy: Air prices rise 600%
Tartan barmy: Air prices rise 600%
Scottish Express
December 2, 2023 Saturday
Edition 1, Scotland
Copyright 2023 Express Newspapers All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 23
Length: 280 words
Byline: Paul Drury
Body
THE Tartan Army will need more Euros for Euro 2024 as air fares jumped 600% - even before fans know where 
they are going.
Qualifying for the first foreign tournament in a quarter of a century has seen prices go through the roof for 
supporters desperate to follow Steve Clarke's men to Germany next summer.
It's thought up to 25,000 Tartan Army footsoldiers will cross the North Sea for the first mass gathering on the 
continent since the World Cup in France in 1998.
The draw to determine who and where Scotland play won't be made until this evening in Hamburg, yet airlines have 
already responded to surging Scottish demand by sending air fares sky-high.
For example, German carrier Lufthansa is charging £410 for a one-way ticket from Glasgow to Frankfurt on June 
13, the day before the tournament begins.
Wily Scotland fans who anticipated that their team would qualify booked the same flight last September - for £98.
Ryanair are charging £342 for a seat on the Edinburgh to
Dusseldorf flight the same day. That is 600% up on the price the week before, just £47.
The same can be seen with hotel prices, up in some cases by 300% for middle-ranking establishments. In Berlin, a 
night's stay at the three-star Amano Grand Central, Mitte, will cost 302 Euros (£260) on June 15, the day the capital 
hosts its first group game.
The next night, the price falls to 92 Euros (£80).
Legendary Tartan Army footsoldier John Low, 77, awarded a SFA honour for attending 100 Scotland internationals, 
said: "These companies are profiting from the desire to see Scotland play."
Tartan barmy: Air prices rise 600%
A spokesman for Lufthansa said: "Our prices are largely determined by supply and demand."
Ryanair has been approached for comment.
Load-Date: December 2, 2023
End of Document
Waterford Airport to receive multimillion-euro investment
Waterford Airport to receive multimillion-euro investment
Transportation Monitor Worldwide
December 2, 2023 Saturday
Copyright 2023 Global Data Point. Provided by Syndigate Media Inc. All Rights Reserved
Length: 317 words
Body
Waterford Airport is to receive a multimillion-euro investment, seven years after the departure of its last commercial 
flight.
An announcement of a combination of public and private investment is expected on Friday, with the focus to be an 
extension to the airports runway.
It is understood that up to 20 million will be committed by private investors, with overall investment possibly topping 
30 million when public funding is added. The board of the airport is known to have begun negotiations with the 
billionaire Galway brothers Luke and Brian Comer that could see them taking a majority stake in the facility. The 
Waterford News & Star title reported earlier this month that this could amount to an 80 per cent holding.
A 150 metre extension to the airports runway, funded by the Department of Transport, was planned a decade ago 
but never came to fruition. Planning permission was granted last year for a runway extension and associated works, 
but private investment stalled.
Minister for Finance Michael McGrath is due in Waterford on Friday to make an announcement about the airports 
future.
Waterford Airport opened in 1981, with Ryanair operating its first scheduled flight four years later. In its final year of 
commercial flight operations seven years ago, the facility handled 13,511 passengers. The Irish Coast Guard Air 
and Sea Rescue helicopter is based at the airport.
Last September, Minister for Transport Eamon Ryan poured cold water over the commercial future of Waterford 
Airport, pointing to the number of aviation facilities already in the southeast and noting the Government had not 
seen a detailed redevelopment proposal for the facility.
Waterford Airport to receive multimillion-euro investment
We have so many airports in the country... Knock, Shannon, Kerry, Cork, Dublin, Belfast, he told local radio station 
WLRFM at that stage.
It is not an easy commercial proposition to start getting the base that would give you a commercial service.

The 'quiet and inviting' Manchester Airport bar with a runway view that not many people know about
The 'quiet and inviting' Manchester Airport bar with a runway view that not 
many people know about
manchestereveningnews.co.uk
December 2, 2023 Saturday 11:33 AM GMT
Copyright 2023 Reach PLC All Rights Reserved
Section: WHAT'S ON NEWS; Version:1
Length: 559 words
Byline: By, Federica Bedendo & Adam Maidment
Highlight: "Not only do you get a view, you also don't have to face anyone else while sitting there"
Body
Passengers flying from Manchester Airport may all know about The Lion and Antelope pub, but there's also another 
bar that has less queues and a runway view that people often miss. 
Situated in Terminal 3, there's a reason why the Lion and Antelope is so popular: It's open until 3am or whenever 
the last departure is and it serves classic dishes alongside a wide array of drinks. But that also means it comes at 
the cost of long queues and lengthy waits for a table.
But one frequent traveller, who visits the Airport a number of times a year, has shared their top drinking spot in the 
terminal that they say is little-known and often has no queues.
Not far away from the Lion and Antelope lies the Nook, which Lancs Live's Federica Bedendo has revealed to be 
her new favourite place to visit whilst waiting to catch a flight.
Federica says she often flies from Terminal 3 to travel to her hometown of Venica via Ryanair so has become well 
trodden with the terminal over the years. She writes: "This means I often find myself at Terminal 3, where I'd like to 
enjoy a pint alone and in peace.
"Now, that can sometimes feel like a mission. The Lion and Antelope is the biggest bar in the terminal once you 
pass security and naively, for a long time I thought it was the only bar where you could get a draught beer -
WRONG.
"I've often found myself queuing for ages for a pint, only to then have to sit next to a tipsy couple who want to talk 
about their upcoming Canaries trip, with a stag do loudly enjoying their pre-flight drinks behind me.
The 'quiet and inviting' Manchester Airport bar with a runway view that not many people know about
"Don't get me wrong, I'm not anti-social, but when I travel alone I only ever have a maximum of two drinks, so I'm 
often not at the same level of merriness as the people trying to have a chat. And at the Lion and Antelope, it's often 
the case you have to share a table because of how busy it is and limited seating space.
"You can imagine my shock when one day after enjoying my pint at that bar, I walked towards the nearby loos, only 
to see that beyond the toilet areas there was.... Another bar serving draught beer, called The Nook.
"Not only was this bar quieter, with little to no queue, but there is also a long bar-type seating area with stools 
overlooking the runway. Not only do you get a view, you also don't have to face anyone else while sitting there."
Federica said the bar also has plugs to charge your phone or laptop, as well as a handful of tables which can be 
just right for a small family. Speaking about the bar, she adds: "You can also access the bar by following directions 
for gates 49-44 and you'll see the bar on the left, just before reaching the gates.
"Quiet, inviting and serving a range of beers, wines and soft drinks, and with the free entertainment of watching the 
planes land and take-off -what's not to like.
"I was there just this past weekend, killing a bit of time before my flight. On draught they had a Brooklyn Pilsner and 
Manchester Craft lager from the J.W. Lees brewery.
"When I sat myself down on one of the stools, I just popped my headphones in and enjoyed my podcasts, while 
sipping on my beer and watching the luggage being loaded on to a departing plane. It was very relaxing.
"If like me, you'd never clocked the Nook -you're welcome. And if you had and were trying to keep this quiet, don't 
worry, I doubt the kind of people you are trying to avoid have read past the headline!"
Load-Date: December 2, 2023

Ryanair finds ‘fake parts’ from London company in engines
Ryanair finds ‘fake parts’ from London company in engines
thetimes.co.uk
December 2, 2023 Saturday 12:01 AM GMT
Copyright 2023 News International Ltd All Rights Reserved
Length: 404 words
Byline: Lara Wildenberg
Highlight: Michael O’Leary calls for tighter control over third-party suppliers
Body
Ryanair has become the latest airline to find “fake parts” in two of its aircraft engines amid an unfolding safety 
scandal in the United States.
The low-cost carrier confirmed that components with falsified certification documents had been discovered in two 
aircraft engines in Texas and Brazil in recent months. 
The fraudulent parts were found during scheduled maintenance checks and have been removed from the engines.
Ryanair, Europe’s largest short-haul airline, is the fourth carrier to find suspicious parts after Delta Air Lines, 
American Airlines and Southwest Airlines.
The scandal was first reported by Bloomberg in September after a Portuguese maintenance and repair company 
noticed in June that spare engine parts labelled “new” in their paperwork showed signs of wear. Since then aviation 
industry regulators have launched an investigation into AOG Technics, a London-based company that is thought to 
have sold thousands of engine parts with fake certification for Airbus and Boeing models.
The
Civil Aviation Authority
issued a warning in August advising British-based airlines to thoroughly investigate their records for any parts 
acquired directly or indirectly from AOG Technics.
Michael O’Leary, the chief executive of 
Ryanair,
Ryanair finds ‘fake parts’ from London company in engines
 told Bloomberg that he believed the allegedly fraudulent parts found in the engines had been supplied by AOG 
Technics. He clarified that the airline did not buy components directly from AOG Technics but had done so through 
third parties. He added that the two engines remained in workshops and that the suspect parts had been sent to the 
bodies investigating AOG Technics.
O’Leary, 62, said Ryanair remained “largely unaffected” by the scandal. The airline has reported strong half-year 
profits of €2.18 billion after dealing with record summer traffic.
However, the tycoon called for tighter control over the third-party suppliers of engine parts. “Given the level of 
paperwork that already exists, I’m not quite sure how anybody was able to come up with dodgy parts,” he told 
Bloomberg.
AOG Technics is a parts buyer and seller registered at a high-end office location near London Victoria station. The 
company deleted its website and LinkedIn profile after Bloomberg’s initial report on the story in September.
Companies House shows the business was incorporated in 2015 and lists Jose Alejandro Zamora Yrala, 35, as the 
sole director.
AOG Technics did not respond to a request for comment.
Load-Date: December 1, 2023
End of Document

Earnings jump to (EURO)316m at aircraft operator Avia
Earnings jump to (EURO)316m at aircraft operator Avia
Irish Independent
December 2, 2023 Saturday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2023 Independent Newspapers Ireland Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 34
Length: 414 words
Byline: JOHN MULLIGAN
Body
Dublin-based Avia Solutions Group, the world's largest aircraft leasing, crew, maintenance and insurance (ACMI) 
firm, said it generated earnings of (EURO)316m in the third quarter of the year, as revenue rose to (EURO)1.64bn.
The figures were up 31pc and 22pc respectively.
Avia, which moved its headquarters to Dublin from its home country of Lithuania earlier this year, has customers 
including Lufthansa, Turkish Airlines, Wizzair, Ryanair and SAS. Avia is the parent company of SmartLynx Airlines, 
Avion Express, BBN Airlines, Klasjet and Magma Aviation.
The company is ultimately controlled by businessman Gediminas Ziemelis, the group's chairman.
Avia Solutions Group chief executive Jonas Janukenas said that the third-quarter performance was a reflection of 
the "substantial demand" for ACMI services across the world.
"The year 2023, especially the extremely active summer season, demonstrated the tremendous need for ACMI 
services in the aviation industry worldwide," he said.
Europe accounted for 69pc of revenue in the third quarter, while Asia accounted for 19pc. Its revenue in Asia rose 
just over 9pc in the period. The group now has a fleet of 197 passenger and cargo aircraft and plans to expand in 
the Asia-Pacific region. It has set up new companies in Thailand and Indonesia to underpin its development and 
aims to have a total of five operators in Asia by the end of next year. It is also expanding in South America.
"Expanding in south-east Asia and South America is a key strategic direction for the group, allowing us to balance 
the reduced seasonal demand in Europe during the winter by shifting aircraft to these regions," said Mr Janukenas. 
"During the past few years, we have become a major aviation player in this part of the world and plan further 
expansion.
Earnings jump to (EURO)316m at aircraft operator Avia
"Additionally, significant investments are being made in MRO [maintenance, repair and overhaul] infrastructure for 
the group's aviation companies providing ACMI services. The total investment in the initial development phase in 
the region amounts to (EURO)25m."
Avia Solutions has begun the construction of a 20,000 sqm aircraft maintenance hangar in the Dominican Republic 
and a 17,000 sqm aircraft maintenance hangar in Bali. The group's subsidiary, Avion Express, has established an 
ACMI airline in Brazil to serve clients in Colombia, Chile, Brazil, and the Dominican Republic.
This year, Avia freed up almost (EURO)1.5bn in capital that could potentially be made available to distribute to 
shareholders.
Graphic
 
Avia's customers include Lufthansa, Turkish Airlines, Wizzair, Ryanair and SAS. Photo: Getty
